Winter tomatoes usually disappoint.  Luckily, this Caprese was Excellent - and lightly drizzled with an olive-oil/balsamic/pesto that was bread-dippin' worthy.

The special fishes that night were Branzino and Sole - so just for kicks I asked - and (as expected) the price was super-high - $41!  I could not order it.

Both of us ordered veal dishes which both had flaws - but luckily - delicious thinly-pounded tender veal.  My dish came with 2 tiny lumps of succulent crabmeat.  (So after giving one to my friend - I basically got one bite of crabmeat.  Oh well.)  My dish was also drowning in a heavy butter and lemon sauce - that almost seemed like "Knorr" Hollandaise from a packet.  I nearly ordered the dish "Light on the sauce" and now, I wish I had.  My friend's Veal Saltimboca was great.

By now, the place was hoppin' - so our service began to suffer.  At $8 - $10 each (and $9 for a single cannoli) we skipped dessert.  I really, really wanted a latte - but they were $5.25 (yikes) - so we both ordered decaf coffees.

FAIL!  My coffee had coffee grounds all over the rim of the mug.  The coffee itself was not hot - and tasted awful.  My friend had to ask for cream multiple times (I had wanted milk, and she cream - but they brought only milk.) At $2.50 percup/mug - we were glad to not be charged for coffee we could not drink.

Note:  This place is a BYO - which I had forgotten, and seems odd given the name (Bellini) is a cocktail.

Also Note:  They added a 20% "Service Charge/Gratuity" without us asking.  In this case, I would have left maybe 18% given the service decline at the end of the evening.  That kind pissed us off. 

When all is said and done, I would return to Bellini - but I would order dishes lightly sauced and ask more questions before ordering.  I also would NEVER order coffee nor dessert here.  (At my local Italian bakery I can get a small cannoli for $1.75, large for $3.00 - but I am very lucky to live right near one.)

Blue Mercury is a chain and a pricey one at that - but this is where I get my Caudalie and Fresh fix. Today I literally spent 2 minutes in the store - got my 6.7 ounce $24 bottle of Caudalie Eau de Raisin (a must have - read my reviews on makeupalley.com).

But not before spritzing myself with Jo Malone's classic orange blossom fragrance.

I. Love. Cosmetics.

Blue Mercury is a good place to pick up hair, skin and cosmetic products from higher-end brands.

Noisy, Crowded and way way way overpriced.
My lunch today was $33 ($66 for 2 - we split it) no alcohol, no dessert.

The Shrimp salad (delish) was $18.50 and we shared a tuna tartare $10.50
She had a beet salad and a $5 Coffee.

How this adds up to $66 is beyond me.

Anyhow I will NOT be back anytime soon.
Wonderful food and people watching but just too $$rich$$ for my blood.

Left hungry and broke.

.

Better than Granite Run (now defunct), Better than the $h!tty Gallery in Philly, but not as nice as K of P.  It's a MALL!  This one has a Target and an Ulta as well.  The era of the "80's mall-mecca is darned near over.

Disney Store, Claire's, Build-A-Bear, Children's Place - all stuff our 8 year old appreciates.

It's fine - and I am glad it's here (I live in Target).
No issues from me.

Updated 2018 - Granite Run Mall has been demolished to build a new shopping/dining area.  Springfield Mall is hanging on for a few more years.  Target and Ulta (and possibly Macy's) are keeping things alive.

They screw up orders here alot so be specific and be careful to check your order before you leave (if you are doing take out).  That said, they always fix it if they mess up but time is money and I need to go, go, GO!

We ordered a few items for 2 diners (to go) and it was accidentally entered as dine-in so we had to wait  (additionally) while they packed it.
My kid is a vegan so there are always specifics like "no cheese" and switching of the bread.

Another time they got a few items flat out wrong.

Again, check, check, check your order.

Front desk clerks/cashiers - please be diligent in your order entry.
Again - this is fast food run by teens so do not expect "the Ritz".

Moderately clean restrooms.  Dining room was fine.  (Although we rarely dine in - we are to-go people.)

One of the disgruntled ex-Chick-Fil-A people works here now.
Please smile - you look so much better if you smile.

OK, I am going to be generous and give Carousel Flowers (the NEW Carousel Flowers) 3 stars.  If it were the old owner, Frank Grau - I would give him 1 or even ZERO Stars.)

Years & Years ago - as a young tween/teen I worked for Frank Grau's Carousel Flowers and he was a complete jerk to me.  It got so bad I had to have my dad come with me when I quit (I was probably 13 years old).

Before that I had worked at a different florist (a few of them, actually) in Doylestown and had a great experience.  My goal back then was to become a floriculturist.

In any case, it was a learning experience - and it is amazing that even after 2 location changes, Carousel Flowers is still there.

Just Salad is Just OK.  It wasn't bad and it wasn't mind-blowing.
It was a bit pricier than Saladworks but also had a few more "yuppie type" ingredients.

That said, the "California" salad I ordered (kinda like a Cobb without bacon) was romaine, chicken, tomatoes, avocado and egg whites.  The lady serving it had quite a 'tude.  Not friendly service at all.

Meanwhile I enjoined the Maple Cider (read sweet as sugar) vinaigrette.
The teeny blue plastic fork was a joke.

In the mean time I prefer other salad chains better and will not be rushing back here - however 2 of my coworkers love it so I bet - I just bet we'll be back.

Not a holy grail, but not an epic fail.

Just Salad.
Just OK.

We come here for tax-free Home Despot.
Lighting supplies, household repairs, tools, etc.
We had our interior paint mixed here, as well.

We'll be back.  It's a neccessary evil.

I have a love/hate relationship with DB (David's Bridal.).
While I elected in the end NOT to get my bridal gown through them, my bridesmaids both got decent (cheap - but hell, they'll NEVER wear them again - let's face it) bridesmaids dresses there.

The customer service can run the gamut from "fend for yourself, bitch" to "your humble servant".  It depends on who you get and WHAT DAY AND TIME (i.e. do not TRY to get good service on a weekend in "bridal/prom" season).

Meanwhile - you can buy color swatches here for $1 a piece and go have a dress made in whatever color your bride has forced upon you.  I had my girls wear a cobalt/royal blue shade called "Royal Velvet".  They were allowed to pick any dress they wanted as long as it met 2 criteria:

1.  Had to be floor length
2.  Had to be Royal VElvet.

Surprisingly enough both gals selected strapless styles - and they are NOT small women.  They both needed fitting and the alterations were done correectly the first time.

A-men.  Thank god the weddig planning is over.

P.S.  Do NOT give them your email address, like I did, or your will be on Every frikkin' bridal/newlywed email spam list around for months and months.

My wedding was in June 2008 and I still get emails from DB related businesses.

I am dithering back & forth between 3 & 4 (yes, really - 4 stars) stars.  I am giving it 3 stars because it's mall susho - but I gotta say for mall sushi - it is pretty damned good.  I had an American Dream roll, which is basically a shrimp tempura roll, draped in avocado & fresh salmon.

The salmon was fresh and tasty, and the roll was garnished with an abundance of masago and 2 sauces, unagi (eel) sauce and spicy mayo.

In future I will ask for the sauces on the side - or just for less sauce - it was a little too gloppy for my taste.

I wish I had noticed they have brown rice - or I woulda had that for sure.

I would definitely choose Yanagi over other food court options.

As with many Starr joints, - it is style over substance to (a-hem) justify a higher price.  Continental is a solid choice for brunch - and OK for lunch or dinner.  We enjoyed the super fresh Vietnamese-type "Summer Roll" - but at $8.50 it should not be filled with surimi (imitation crab).  It was also very light and I could have eaten 2 of them myself.  

For $9.50 the udon and wonton soup came with 3 wontons and a few slivers of scallion.  NOT worth the high price, but tasty.

Edamame was $6.50.  OUCH!!!!!  

Server, Katie, was gorgeous and attentive.  Hot (and likely gay) barkeep had beautiful tattoos on Saturn on his arm.

A fun place - but bring MONEY.

My (now) husband and his guys (and the fathers) all got stuck getting there tuxedo rentals at MW.

I mean, what choices do you have (read:  Venteresca's in Doylestown kicks MW's a$$, but anyhow) if you have any guys who live outside of your local area, do them all a favor a get MW tuxes.

The groom's Tux is "free" if the wedding party is 4 or more.  (They all have to pay for and return their tuxes before the groom gets credited for his.)

Customer service really varies - and is completely  sales associate dependant.  et a good associate, you'll have a better experience.

They STILL managed to f**k up part our order on wedding day.  One guy had no shirt and one guy's shirt was the wrong size.  The store manager saved the day (literally) by shlepping the correct shirts to the Inn where we got married.

Thank God that's over!

P.S.  Don't give them your email address, unless you want to be on every frikking mailing list wedding-related or not, known to man.

We came here with a party of 5 for a late lunch and on a tight time-frame.
Unfortunately, we were seated in a booth (the place was not busy so we should have asked for a table - and will do so if we ever return).

That booth was so uncomfortable especially for our 8 year old.
"Smushy", she said.

In any case, our server Bryan (Brian?) was very accomodating.
The food was just OK - lunch menu items - we mostly all had sandwiches (burger, filet on foccacia and Prime rib pieces with onions on a kaiser roll).

Kiddo had (again) the "Mac-a-roo" but this time did not like the cheese sauce (too rich and thick this time.)

Oh, well.  I was never a big fan of Outback - but we had such a great experience the last time we came, we thought we'd give it another go.

Tips:  Come during NON peak hours, Sit at a TABLE not a booth - especially for parties of 5 or 6.

Bonner's rennovated the back dining room and our group was treated like royalty for a private event.  Food was still pretty "meh" - but Dan (the man) is a great and generous host and Liz  runs the show, pretty much.

Bonner's is a standard, solid Irish pub with good drinks and lots of good times.
It's a PECO hangout for many, for sure!

I have stopped in at Burlap & Bean twice now - once in the afternoon for an iced coffee which was very good and once in the morning for an iced latte which was so strong and bitter I could only drink about half of it and threw the other half out.

The place is very nice, clean and spacious and I will definitely come back to hear some music in the evenings, but I am gun-shy of thei espresso drinks now, which is a shame, as I love a good latte/iced latte etc.

Could be a 4 star place but that latte really tasted bad.

Service was friendly.

Went here for a desperation dinner - and needed something the 7 year old would like.  (She suggested it). 

The good:  The black & white milkshake ($4.05) was freshly made and big enough for the 3 of us to each have a good bit of. - really big enough for 2 to share.  The chicken sandwiches were fried - but freshly fried.  Very pleasant service - an older lady took the orders, a younger gal cooked and served and a teen guy spun milkshakes and got us fountain drinks.

The bad:  Waffle fries are just OK.  Onion rings are tasteless and above a 1/2 step about BK quality.  I wanted the real deal - and this ain't it.

The ugly:  NASTY horrid bathroom.  Used - again - out of a 7 year old's desperation.

We'll be back - in the spring/summer when the weather is nicer.

A junk food paradise.  There is NOTHING remotely healthy on the menu.  Not even an iceberg side salad.

Just OK.  Not great.  The nail services are OK.  A few of the many floors could use a makeover.  Looks a little dated.  I bet it's been around a LONG time.  Nice selection of retail and jewelry/accessories.  CUTE stuff.  Nice owners.

My mother in law loves this place and has given Douglas Jewelers a ton of business over the past few years.

She bought me a 10 K white gold and Garnet pendant - and while it is lovely - i KNOW it was overpriced.  She also convinced my husband to buy me a piece of Blue Topaz Jewelry here that was $800 and worth about 3.  I made him return it.

They have lovely items - but for quality vs. value I prefer to shop at Caroll's jewelers.  The "deals" at douglas are not deals at all.

Still only 3 stars.  Stopped in alone and the bar was hopping - but the dining room was deserted.  Server was pleasant but often disappeared just when I needed her.

Delicous bread (baguette) and butter garnished with garlic chive blossoms.  Cute Amuse.  

Best thing?  Salad of rainbow chard and too-salty duck confit with a poached egg.

Leat favorite?  Mushroom vol-au-vent.  Too earthy for me.

$38.50 for dinner for just me - NO BEVERAGE NO DESSERT.

Ouch.

Lydia R. sums it up.

The manicurist is the best part - (Carol??) she is a gem and a great technician - but my polish chipped 6 hours later. (Which seems odd seeing that she used CND products.  That said - I returned a few weeks later to see Carol for a mini facial (30 minutes, Dermalogica Products).

The hairdresser, Elle, did just an OK job on my blowout. She did not listen to what I wanted.

Manager/Receptionist Jamie was very pleasant and friendly.

One suggestion:  Please have a water cooler or water available.  I was told I could fill up my own water bottle in the bathroom.  Not too classy for an otherwise classy salon.

Decor is beautiful but B2 has some kinks to work out.
4 star manicure, 4 star facial, 2 star blowout.

Decor is very nice and food is passable.
I had a Salmon Lover lunch special ($15) and it came with an iceberg salad and good miso soup.  Salmon was fresh but rice for the maki was a little gummy.
I also tried the Lotus In Roll - and that was much better - with fresh yellowtail - but I forgot to ask for "sauce on the side" and it was smothered in wasabi mayo.  (Too much for my tastes - next time I gotta remember "sauce on the side")

Not Nobu - but very good considering the area.

I will be back for sure.
Chinese dishes and Chicken Teriyaki lunch special looked good - might try a Faux-Thai dish (Pad Thai) next time.  

Note:  I also tried the Sesame Shrimp - and it was very good (albeit deep-fried).

3.5 stars max for average food.
I was very disappointed in that I had been to Avero a while back for a private event and the food for that was terrific.

Came here last night for Happy Hour - which was great for the $4 drink specials (vodka drinks or beer or a few house wines) and 1/2 price pizzas/flatbreads.

I ordered a chicken picatta entree and it was just LOADED with capers - even after I had asked for "light on the capers".  I can not imagine what the "normal" amount of capers would have been?  Anyhow it made the dish exceedingly salty/vinegary.

The drinks were fine and service was fine, too (not crowded at 4:45 PM on a Wednesday).

Not sure I'll be rushing back here.

Stopped in for a free (coupon) beverage at an odd hour (5:15 PM) and got in and out relatively quickly, however it took over 45 seconds (seems like longer than it is) to be acknowledged by the single overworked staffer.  I chose an iced macchiatto. (I bet I spelled that wrong.)

No issues - and for free?  That was fine.
Oh - and they have a drive thru here.

Olive Garden - ah yes - Faux-talian.
Went here for a nice lunch (this is as good as an OG can get IMO) with 2 friends.
One had the "tour of Italy", the other had the stuffed Chicken Marsala which looked entirely too cheesey for me to attempt eating.

I played it safe and ordered the shrimp scampi app over pasta instead of crositini.

The portion was HUGE and that was more than enough.

Salty breadstcks and overly dressed iceberg salad came free (as it always does at OG.

Not a holy grail - but a "safe' choice when you are in the area.

We had a very nice and extremely reasonable meal of wings on "Wing Wednesdays"  (60 cents per wing - and we ordered 16 of them).

The wings are better than the  pizza and come in 3 varieties - Traditional Bone-in, Bone-in Breaded and Boneless. (We got traditional with Honey BBQ sauce (a little too much sauce) and Blue Cheese (or ranch).  The wings are smaller and not as good as Hooters - but they were so cheap!

NO CELERY - that is very bad.

Meanwhile, our server Jackie was a doll and treated us well.  For $18.50 for dinner for two - including tax & tip it was a junk-food fest.

Stay away from the greasy Pizza Hut Pizza - but do consider "Wing Wednesday" - oh and BYOC - Bring your own celery.

PLEASE GET SOME CELERY STICKS!

I hope they'll make it but I fear they will not.
Only one size smoothie and it is $7 - so i get my 10 year old and a friend to split it.

Wish they had a kids size for about $4 or $4.50.

Friendly service and great ideas and products but it is almost always empty and I wonder how they'll make it?
I fear the end may be near.

Stopped in for a non-coffee beverage and wound up with a winner - the Watermelon (non-alc.) mojito (sans simple syrup and it's still very sweet).  4 stars for the great beverage - 2 stars for the icy reception from the (female) barrista.

Again - this place is just OK.

Ok, my best friend calls this place Icky Vicky's - because if you are a big gal - this is NOT the place for you.  Victoria's secret is a place to buy "every day" underwear.  It is mall-quality, mass produced bras, panties, sleepwear, loungewear and now - really poor quality fragrances and cosmetics that bilk thousands of teens and young 20-somethings out of millions each year - and their mama's too!

If it sounds as though I am being harsh - well...

...I Kinda am.

anyhow, I get my typical five for $25 plain cotton string bikinis there and whenever I get a "free panty" coupon in the mail I run right over.

I am definitely not a a Power Shopper at VS - I much prefer high end lovelies like La Perla or Agent Provacateur for the specialty goods.  But for an everyday comfy cotton undie?  VS is my go-to spot.

Just don't ask for help from the teen-aged, undereducated, underpaid staff (although they'll probably offer to help you).  Come here during off hours when there are no lines to check out.

Nope.  We're sticking with Da Shin.  This place is good for certain items - but on the whole very greasy.  And you can't dine in (card table, eew. Just, no!) so for delivery yes to Jing Fong, for dine in?  Da Shin.

Jeff is about as good as you can find in Philly (far better than Hahnemann! Kinder than HUP).

My father went here for an outpatient procedure and it was handled well.
Administratively (as with most large hospitals) it's kind of a nightmare.

Allow ample time - your 8 AM (or 9 AM) appointment - when you show up at 7:30 AM may not start until past 10 AM!!!

Lots of hurry-up-and-wait.

I vacillate between 3 & 4 stars because there are, indeed, numerous kinks (mostly service related) that need ironing out.

I came to Amuse with a group of 13 women, and we sat at the large high-top communal table in the bar area.

Service was scattered from the get go - they only brought out 3 menus, we asked for more.  They did not give us water until we asked.  Many of us had no cutlery nor napkins.  Again, we asked.

Sasha - one of our servers, was lovely - but stretched too thin to accommodate all of us, who ordered (partially separate checks) bar items, bar menu items and dinner menu items.  Items and courses sometimes came right away and other orders were lost in the shuffle and never arrived.

Meanwhile, my partner (on the same check) and I shared the $3 Parisienne Gnocchi (Paris is not known for Gnocchi, by the way), the $5 Mac & Cheese (both from the BAR menu) and a $7 side of sauteed brussels sprouts.  All were delicious - but the gnocchi was SWIMMING in butter and I would not order it again.  The brussels sprouts were the high point for me.

Others at the table had the Quinoa/Ratatouille dinner entree - and the Quinoa was way, way undercooked.  It was crunchy.  Fortunately the ratatouille was excellent.

Decor is sleek & gorgeous (I mean, the place is brand new.) and the food is NOT "Mariott-era" hotel fare.

I am pleasantly surprised and plan to return - but I will allow ample time and expect erratic and weird service.

It's nice but not a holy grail.  They offer soups and a few sandwiches - I kinda wish they had more lunch options as I am not much for coffee drinks.

Very clean and brand new.

As usual, I agree with Steven B. word for word.
We were flying Southwest and in dire need of sustenance - and NOT fast food if at all possible.

My husband has a decidedly 2 star beef fajita salad - but my Enchiladas were actuallly good!  So pleased.  So surprised.

This will be where we drop our $40 on crappy airport food from now on.  Not so crappy.

This Maggiano's is not nearly as nice as the one in the Cherry Hill mall, but my parents and little girl and I go there sometimes when we want to sit down, however, the food is so much better at the Reading Terminal Market - which is just a block away.

Pasta dishes are a good value at lunch - but I ask them to go lightly on the sauce(s) - the garlic load is pretty intense.

An OK place for a "family meal" - no, it's not earth-shattering - and it can feel a bit "cafeteria-like" as it gets loud and the acoustics are pretty awful. 

Also the ladies room could use a spruce-up.

Dunkin Donuts at Philly airport - a safe choice which does not have over-inflated "gotcha" prices.

America may run on Dunkin, but I walk.
Slowly.

I guess I got the decaf.

I found out about this place through Clare H. - a fellow yelper and friend.  She loves it here - I thought it was 3 or 4 stars for food and the decor is certainly not bad - but not terrific either.  Service was great.

OK - maybe I will cave and give them 5 stars?

I enjoyed my $14 lunch special of shortribs with brown rice - but the 3 grape tomatoes (and cucumbers) that came as a garnish were rotten inside.  Blargh!

Meanwhile the summer rolls & noodle soups here are far better than the place in Paoli that I frequent. (Er - used to frequent?)  So I will be pleased to come out here again.

Next time I gotta get some noodles!

We stayed here in the mid nineties and it was mediocre then.  I can't imagine how it must have declined since - so my generous 3 stars should really only be 2.

Rooms were passable - and concierge service was nearly non-existent back then when we stayed here.  (We were visiting friends who went to Penn.)  Location was the main reason we stayed here.

Brandywine Catering provides food services for "Dressage at Devon" and many other events.
3 stars is generous - as our food was both overpriced and underwhelming.

My 9 year old had a $10 pulled pork sandwich (came with an inedible side of vinergary 4 bean salad which no kid will ever eat - and no substitutions were available).  I had a $15 hunk of stone-cold (COLD) dried out baked ziti and a side salad.  (Salad was nice).

For $25 we ate sub par food amongst the blue-bloods for which this sum is no big whoop.

Meanwhile - we are glad there was something to eat other than "fair food" and fried things.

I just wish they could keep the hot foods hot. And add some seasoning.

I agree 100% with Ryan C.  I fall more toward the "chocosnob" in that to me, Godiva is not all that great.  The Eurpoean companies are superior for the most part.  But it beat's Hershey's!

My 5 year old loves the chocolate dipped strawberries - but at $5 a pop we are better off going to RTM or Little Italy for $2 berries.

They also now have a club where you can get 1 free piece (not a strawberry) from the chocolate case each month.  No purchase neccessary.

How sweet!

Our company often has happy hours here.
Drinks are fine - food is just average. It's bar food - wings, shipach/artichoke dip, hummus and pita, potato skins etc.

Meanwhile service was OK - not great and not bad - and we got great seats at a corner of the bar.  My "Ruby Red" was made with REAL grapefruit juice (I saw the bartender squeezing it), Cointreau and Grapefruit-flavored vodka.  Very summer-y and refreshing.

We also had a corporate lunch for 8 here - and the food was good - but not great.  Soups are very salty (Crab bisque) and salads, while BIG (the small was enormous) are mostly lettuce with a few of the "premium" ingreditents (Salmon and asparagus had 2 spears of asparagus, Beet Salad had one slice of Red beet (cut in half) and One slice of golden beet (cut in half).  While the beets were delicious - I would have appreciated more of them.  Crab cake ($6.95 additional) was good. Grilled fish entree was the best of the lot (fluke?) with jasmine rice and green beans.

I will be back with corporate events but given my own preferences I would not likely dine here on my own acccord.

Drinks?  Fine.
Lunch/Dinner?  Maybe go elsewhere. (Oh - but where???)

My 9 year old asked me to say this first...

"They have very cold bathrooms".  The ladies rooms was FREEZING.
Luckily the rest of the dining room was warm.
Service was unobtrusive and fine.

Decor is very lovely.

Food?  Not so fresh.  I had a hamachi sushi lunch special ($17) and the 4 pieces of nigiri 2 tasted off.  9 year old's shu mai (8 pieces) and california roll were fine - maybe even 4 star.  Our friend's Drunken noodles were not terribly spicy but very tasty.

If I ever return I will order cook dishes and not get sushi again here.
Which is a shame because I love good sushi.

Note:  We returned a few weeeks later (for business lunch) and I had tofu pad Thai (lunch special $11 with a green salad) and it was fine.  Good but not mindblowing.

Full bar.

Just OK as starbucks go.
Decent service - but I have yet to make a connection with a specific barrista.

Bathrooms are locked (you need to ask for a key) and filthy nonetheless.

Good location.

Yikes - I can't breathe.
The overwhelming fog of patchouli hit me like a wall the moment I walked in.

I tried to get past it - that and the chanting music in the background. (I thought they were singing "Trim the edges, Trim the edges" until I realized it was Sanskrit or something).

Anyhow, I loved the merchandise but I can't deal with the intense allergic coughing fit I have upon entry.

Need some sage smudge sticks?  This is your place!

This is a review for the Charbucks next to the Wyndham Garden Inn on Route 100 in Exton,

This Starbucks is walk-able from there and literally saved me throughout the weekend of a conference where I was forced to stay at the Wymdham.  I came here for breakfast - got some decent coffee and a breakfast sandwich which beat the heck out of the pre-packaged "Grab & Go" garbage that the hotel was offering.

I alsostopped in around 3 PM during a break in the conference and got a much-needed Macchiatto (sp??).  Thank you, FOURBucks.

Food quality and service - 4 stars, dining room (sooooo hot in here) 2 stars.

Get it to go!

Unlike Rachel, I was/am not thrilled with the D-town produce outlet.  yes - the prices are low - but often the fruit  (berries & grapes especially) is what I call, "eat now or forever hold your peace". Meaning it is about 16 hours away from becoming rotten.

Be very careful not to over buy here or you will end up throwing away alot of over-ripe produce.

Crowded on weekends and "after work" dead the rest of the week - check them out on a Tuesday or Wednesday AM when it's dead-empty.

Convenient Wawa heading up 252 - coffee/smokes/snacks - check/check/check.
And you can get a hoagie.

Wawa is the quintessential PA convenience store.

A friends and I both had Kalbi ($13) lunch boxes here.  Panchan was OK - not great. (Bean spouts were good, fish cake is not my thing and pickled cukes were ok.)  Kalbi itself was tasty.  Salad was iceberg and raw white onions in a mayo-ish dressing.

For $13, I'd rather get sushi at Vic or a bowl at Tampopo (which is also mediocre.)

I miss a really GOOD kalbi or bulgoki.

This place is OK - not bad but not great.
It is on par with what Miran was.

I stumbled upon Persian Grill on my way to a 7:00 meeting in the 'burbs.  I walked in at 6 PM on a Tuesday and the place was DEAD - in fact I thought it was closed from the parking lot - but went inside anyway.

No hostess, no wait staff, EMPTY diningroom - except for an elderly couple slowly eating in a front booth.  The rice platters they were eating looked good so I hung around.

Finally a lovely lady came out and seated me and I told her that I was on a tight time frame.  She said it would be no problem.  Then she disappeared for a long while and then came back and took my order.

The food - and I love Persian/Iranian food - was just Ok - yes the rice was 5 star stellar - but I paid $30 for a plate of rice and overcooked chicken (in a delicious sauce, though) thighs (Fesenjoon).  The chicken was so dried out and hard.

Yick.

Meanwhile the rice (and the crispy/burnt rice on top) was great.
I also enjoyed the Shirazi (cucmber/tomato/onion salad) but it was drowning in lemon juice and way too oniony.

I wanted to LOVE it here - and many people do, but the slow service, high prices, awful chicken and DATED ancient decor downgrade it for me. And $30 for basically rice and onion salad (no drinks, no dessert).  Other diners got baklava (not sure if they ordered it) but I never got any.

Needs a service and decor makeover.  STAT.
I will come back once more to try the lamb chops - but I won't be rushing back.

I am a sucker so I bought a Groupon - but silly me - I didn;t read the not-so-fine print and the groupon was for DINNER ONLY.  Thank goodness they honored it at lunch but you had to order off the dinner menu (no cheapie lunch specials for the groupon.).

That was fine by me.
I started my meal with an OK version of Tom Kha Gai (Thai Chicken Coconut Soup).  This is my favorite soup ever so I have to say this version was very nice - not too sweet and not overly rich with too much coconut milk.  4 stars.

An iceberg salad (gloppy ginger dressing on the side) came next.  Meh.  Fine.  There was ONE cherry tomato and ONE cucmber slice buried at the bottom. Whatever.

Next I got a specialty sushi roll (I can;t remember which one - I think it was the Lotus Inn Roll) that was just OK.  The sushi fish here is just OK.  Not bad and not great.  I also got an order of sake (salmon) sashimi ($6.50 for 3 thin slices) which I never should have gotten.  Meh.

For $14.95 I expect more than an alaskan roll with a few slivers of Escolar on top.  Escolar is NOT white tuna.  Albacore is white tuna. Thank goodness I remembered to get the sauce on the side.  Fish was good - but not superb. 


But whatdya expect?
Meanwhile the party of 6 next to were raving about their chicken & brocolli and shrimp chow mein.

Maybe I oughta stick to cooked foods here.
Or the Salmon Lovers Lunch ($14.95) which I have gotten a few times.

Atmoshpere is relaxing.

Good, greasy, basic pizza - a little expensive for what it is.
Plus they sell gelato, subs & salads.

This is a review for the Bacco (new location) in the Doylestown shopping Center.  I fully agree with Cheri C.  The food is excellent and the poritons are enormous.

But it took foreever to:

1.  be greeted
2.  be seated (we wound up seating ourselves)
3.  get menus
4.  have someone wait on us
5.  get our food (cooked to order so that was OK)
6.  get our bill

It was like pulling teeth getting service - and the place was not busy.

Our party of 4 ordered Pasta fagiole soup (huge bowl for $3.95), linguini with (REAL) clams - so good, Chicken parm (served with a delicious side of mezza-rigatti pasta in a crushed tomato sauce), and I had the Chicken florentine.  It was terrific.

We'd like to go back but only if we have lots of time to wait around (for the servers) and thus I would never bring my little kid here.

Marathon - you have redeemed yourself.  After years of boycotting Marathon (a close friend used to date one of the owners who treated her badly) I lifted said ban and attended a group function at this location - and honestly, truly - everything was A-OK!

Our group of about 60 people had a set meal.  As we arrive each place had a lovely salad (pre-set) with tomato, cucumber, lettuce and roasted beets.  Servers passed bowls of feta on the side.  Dressing was a sweet "buttermilk" style and was served along side.  Each person got a roll and butter.

The main meal was the same for everyone (unless you were vegetarian) - grilled salmon served in a square bowl atop a mound of farfalle with tomato/veggie sauce.  It honestly was really tasty.

Dessert platters of fruit and cookies/brownies/bars were passed afterward with coffee.

A cash bar was available.

Service was very good considering the crowd size.

I have now officially lifted my ban on Marathon.

Oh, the NBI - for me 3 stars is being very generous.  Mostly because my high school best friends younger sister used to LOVE this place.  We never did.  Standard pub grub and beer after beer.

OK When you're a teenager (Oh wait, they can't serve underagers any more - my bad!) but I've outgrown this place.

Its a basic bar.

I may be dating myself - but I went here when I was in college at Penn in the mid nineties.  Cav's is still kicking (and they also have the "River Deck".

It's your basic bar.  Bar food.  Bar Music.  Frat-boy (and college-gals) crowd.  Meat-marketing and bozzing of the basest nature.  Decent wings as I recall. 

I preferred Smokey Joe's.

Overpriced for sure - I mean, I spent nearly $20 (including tip) for a lemonade/ice green tea and a tomato-brie-proscuitoo omelette.  Sheesh.

Meanwhile the service was terrific (2 very nice gals) and I got to feel like a true "Lady Who Lunches" (Or rather breakfasts??) on a Friday at 9 AM.

Breads are stellar - and they serve a myriad of tasty confitures (apricot!!) and chocolate spreads (Noir, Noisette) to go with them.

Next time I will get a croissant to go and save $12.

I am not a big DD fan - but the coffee is fine.  I don't eat the donuts (which are not freshly baked - and usually taste stale to me) and NEVER eat the 400 PLUS calorie breakfast grease-wiches.

It's a good place to get a Vanilla Iced Decaf or a quick cup of joe when it's cold out.

But that's all.

I, too, have a love/hate relationship with Amtrak - seeing as I take it every 2 weeks like clockwork - it is a necessary evil in my life.

First of all the prices.  They're high.  Acela is a complete rip off saving you maybe only 20 minutes of time from Philly to NYC - and that is only if the trains are on time.  Don't bother.  Also you can skip upgrading to Business class - what a freakin' joke.  It's the same seats - just the front car.  BFD!!!

OK, now the schedules - IF they are running on time with no delays they would be adequate.  But you can forget about holidays - when crowded trains are OVERSOLD and running late.  Thanksgiving weekend is a NIGHTMARE,

Basically between T-giving and January 6 the weekends are all a colossal mess.

Bring your own food - many trains no longer have the cafe car.

I have been here 3-4 times over the past 2 years.  I have lunch here whenever I go to our Malvern Ofice.  I usually get a Chinese or Thai lunch special - as they are a bargain at 7-8 bucks each, but I am always tempted by the sushi menu.  

Alas, I only had sushi once.  It was good as I recall but not mind blowingly so.

I really enjoyed the Pineapple Thai Fried Rice.  Mango Shrimp was good - but a little too goppy and there was ketchup involved in the copious amounts of "sweet & sour" sauce.  I'd pass on it next time.

Choice of Soup or spring roll at lunch was also nice - with a crisp and only a tad too greasy spring roll.

I'll be back the next time I travel to Malvernia.

Oh - the parking lot in this "strip mall" is always JAMMED at lunch hour - so be forewarned.

I had not gone back to pot belly as I did not like it - but we had a corporate luncheon catered from there today and a few things seem to have improved:

1.  The chopped salad with cranberries and walnuts was not too bad (I'd get it without onions in future).

2.  The meatball sandwiches arrived hot and the sandwich boxes (Box 'o sammies) were cute and well organized with a variety of sandwiches.  If I ever go to potbelly again I'm getting the meatball sub.

3.  The dark chocolate chip cookies seemed to be freshly-baked - albeit a bit greasy (butter or margaine?) - they were DELISH.

Much improved.

I jokingly call this place "Oh So Mediocre" but  it really is pretty good.
It's the typical pay per pound hot & cold food bar.  The earlier you come - during the weekday lunch hour - the fresher and less "picked-over" the food is.

You can get salads, pasta, chicken, sushi (pre cut rolls) and chinese foods.

Not bad for a quick take out.

AVOID during festivals (Strawberry Fest, July 4th weekend, Teddy bears Picnic).  A tourist-packed cluster-f&@k.

Jully 4th weekend was an absolute zoo.

They need someone INSIDE the parking lot to direct people after the fireworks.  It took 40 minutes to exit the parking lot.  Unacceptable.

Absolute Mediocrity - but very reasonably priced.
Also note - the $4.99 Lunch special is for the regular Chicken teriyaki (not the teppanyaki/hibachi grill).  If you want Hibachi it starts at $6.99 (Veggies only) and goes up from there.

I came with a work group of 4 and the place was quiet on a Summer Friday at 12 noon.
Another group of 3 was at the other end of our table.  

I had the $8.95 Shrimp teriyaki lunch and it was fine.  They did the onion volcano and the "chuck the shrimp at the customer" thing and my 10 year old would have loved it.

VERY cheap bill - $65 for 4 people.

Simple, edible food.  Sushi looked OK - but the gal who ordered sushi only got an avocado roll.  I likely would not order nigiri or sashimi here.

Super Americanized from the gloppy mayo on the iceberg salad (I forgot to ask for dressing on the side) to having to ASK for chopsticks.

I am in no hurry to rush back - but that said, my colleagues have lunch here every other Friday.  WHATEVER.

I really wanted to LOVE Tir Na Nog and be "pleasantly surprised" by the tricked-out pseudo-Irish-stylized pub grub - but here's what really happened...

I went to Tir Na Nog last night as part of a private dinner party - there were about 14 of us.  We had a semi-open bar for 45 minutes - and beer on tap and house red or white wine.  I had the Pinot Grigio which I did not enjoy.  However, the barkeep (a lovely young lady) and hostess were attentive and very, very hospitable keeping everyone's glasses full.

I shoulda had a pint of Harp or Bass.  Oh well.  Next time.

Then we were ushered into a private dining area.  A choice of soup or Salad (this was - in my opinion) the best part of the meal.  The house salad was EXCELLENT - 4 stars easily - perfectly dressed fresh greens, lots of cukes & carrots and 2 perfect cherry tomatoes.  Accomanied by a basket of fresh warm bread.  I succumbed to the Irish Soda Bread with creamy butter.  Sooooo good!  A friend had the potato parmesan soup which looked awesome (and fattening as hell) and she just LOOOVED it.

But the entree failed me.  We had 4 choices - a burger (looked great), grilled salmon (looked OK - not earth shattering), a big greasy plate of delicious fish and chips (I tasted a friend's fish - which was begging for malt vinegar - a bottle quickly appeared.) - and my entree - the roast chicken.

Or should I say the dessicated chicken?  

This chicken was so dry and over cooked it was just not enjoyable.

UGH.  OK - Star off for that.

Dessert redeemed TNN - with a luscious banana split - with warm caramelized banana halves.

We had a lovely time and I will return (and maybe even give 'em 4 stars next time) but no WAY would I order the roast chicken EVER again.

Oh - you should also know that prior to our dinner - a colleague and I sat on the outdoor patio (we had arrive early) and were given water in FILTHY dirty glasses.  The server hastily replaced them - but it skeeved me out quite a bit.

Glassware in general is not well washed here.

Gallucio's is THE SPOT where my husband's law firm's (and many other Wilmington Lawyers) softball team meets after games.  They have an outdoor patio in the summer and a LARGE bar area.

The specialties (for us anyhow) are wings, pizza and beer.
The wings are decent - not too hot - but you can ask for hot ones.
The pizza is a GREASY, GREASY mess - think 3-4 napkins of blot per slice.  However, once you get passed the cheese, the sauce and crust are actually very tasty.

My 4 year old came with us one night after a game (she loves to watch her daddy play softball) and devoured 1.5 slices.  She didn't like the wings though.

In general - this is a BAR and not a kids place - so DD felt very special to be here and admired the tiny fountain on the back patio.

We had fun - and post-game - we'll be back.

Lori our server was friendly, timely and courteous.

Not a holy grail - but a decent place to gather for post-game grub.

Had a decent - and quickly served - lunch at Marathon and the place was (and always is) packed at 12:15 on a weekday.  Long line for a table!

My friend ordered her usual - the Smoked Chicken Quesadilla (next time I am trying this!) and I got a vegetable cappelini.  Would have been 4 star but my cappelini was loaded with some odd creamy sauce.  I wish I had known this so I could have had it omitted.  Tasted good - but a diet disaster.  (Kinda like a parmesan mayo - weird).

We come back from time to time but there are much better places (like Matyson and Vic Sushi Bar) for a better quality of food for lunch.

Good for expense account types.  Prices are a bit too high for the "Meh" quality.

Been there, done that.  This place has been around for decades.
Cheesy gag gifts but also some decent condoms.

Tourist trap.

A cutesy pink & purple paradise for tweens (and younger) to get prettied up (tarted up?) and parade around on a mock runway for a birthday extravaganza.

The one in Cherry Hill is even bigger.

They have a full service salon for girls (including hair, nails - pedicure thrones, make your own lip gloss, the works) and TONS of overpriced sparkley merch for eager 8 year old fingers to grasp at.

Hold on to your wallet, kids!  (PARENTS, too)

Parties for 8 kids START at $250.

It's a Wawa - and it's there when we need it.  My DH must have his revered Marlboro lights.

Like most Wawa's - it has alot of coffee and flavored creamers.

We are glad it's here.  Alot of Wawa's are closing due to this weird economy we are in.

As always - Louis B.'s review is spot-on!  This old-school Sears is bright, airy and packed with merchandise - but just try paying for it - we can NEVER find a cashier.

It's one of the "Anchor" stores of the now failing Grabbit 'n Run (Granite Run) Mall.
A good source for clothes and shoes for my kiddo and to try on Land's end garb or return it if I make a Land's End catalog boo-boo.

OMG - so expensive.  We were shopping for a sofa and loveseat.  Sofas alone (in microfiber) started at $1400.  You get a choice of fabrics and armrest designs.

Nice sales-lady.

Lovely store - just too high for a "family room" - better for a formal living room.
Everything is fried. Yeah, they have grillwd chicken, but served with fries.  Just ok. Not cheap, either. Limited seating.

We had terrific service on a slow Monday afternoon at 4:30 PM.
Yes, my friend and I are hard core (not!) but we did enjoy some shots of makers mark and So-Co with pints of Stella Artois).

Around 6 or so the place got busy - but our service was still great and by then we were hungry so we ordered some terrific seared tuna apps ($12 each and worth it) and a mediocre and overly-salted bowl of french onion - which I had to send back.  It's a shame because I love a good french onion. This one was like eating a salt-lick.

The cute blonde female bartender was very sweet and gave us terrific customer service (and did not charge us for the salty soup).

Can't wait to come back for a full meal. This place is hoppin' at most time of the week and is packed on Summer waednesdays for "Dining under the stars".  (AKA "Chaos out in the heat")

I like this place much better than Sligo so far.
A fun bar scene for middle-agers like me (ha ha!).
Similar to HoneyGrow, SweetGreen and other quick service salad/bowl joints. My basic Cobb was around $12 and tasted fine. I may be back.

Now that the Trenton Station has been renovated, America can still run on its Dunkin at the combined DD and Newsstand replete with junkfood and magazines.  

While I, personally, do not partkae of the stale-tasting trucked-in caloric confectios, it is a good place to get a light ice, half-caff, french vanilla, extra milk and 2 splenda.

Dr. Taylor was recommended to me by our pediatrician (Society Hill Pediatrics) as a place that would accept our Blue Cross Insurance.  My 4 year old had a small mole I wanted looked at . (Turned out to be, as I thought, no big whoop. Better safe than sorry.)

The administration of the office is very poor (long hold times on the phone, over booking, can't get an appt. for weeks, etc.)  - which is why I am giving her 3 stars.  Susan herself was a 4-5 star doctor though and was patient with my little one and gave (what I perceived to be)  sound advice.

Dr. Taylor was very, very nice during the 2-3 minutes she spend with us.  (Due to the rushed and over booked appointments of the aforementioned administration of the practice, Dr. T. had precious little time to spend with us.  This, alas, is typical, in the medical community.  Damned insurance!!)

Anyhow, I am glad we were able to see her and hope that she will be available should we need her services again. 

P.S.  She has a skin care line on sale at Sephora.
Bought some Hagar slacks for my elderly father - it's all he will wear any more.  No issues.

Cody Y. says it perfectly - the pumps are at an angle and it is crazy-busy at rush hour.
I really, really needed gas, so I was grateful to find it.

Stopped in here on a whim and ordered 1 pork belly Bao (very good) and a teriyaki Tofu Bento (Just OK, fried, too many carbs).

Good but not amazing.

This is not a juice bar - it is a smoothie/sugar laden. fruity treat place that your kids will like.  Is it good for you?  Not really.  Large sizes and decent prices - but way too high of a sugar content in most of the drinks.

Bright cheery location and friendly service.

Something has slipped at Chin's, I'm afraid.
And D-town has precious few Chinese places any more, so we are still using Chin's as our go-to take out spot.

The pepper steak with onions was mostly onions and peppers with very little (gristly) steak and drowning in salty brown sauce.  

Nope.

The hot & sour soup was not very hot, but quite sour (like 2% acetic acid sour).

Nope.

Thankfully the Shrimp with Snow peas was excellent (5 shrimp in a small order) and out 9 year old devoured the sesame (deep fried white meat chunks of) chicken.  Fried pork dumplings are doughy but satisfying.

Classic Chinese take-out (The eat-in dining room is rather dark) but they need to up their game.  Please!!!  We need you!
I had a good experience browse-shopping here - but the prices were cost prohibitive.  Oh well.

2 or 3.  I will be generous and give them 3 stars, as my little girl really enjoyed her short-stack of chocolate chip pancakes.  This is diner food - but alas, not at its finest.  My husband ordered a Chicken wrap with Ranch dressing and they got it wrong and gave him a Buffalo Chicken ranch with Blue cheese dressing, which he does not like.

The server was pleasant enough and the man (owner??) at the cashier desk was lovely, too, but the food just isn't that great.

They have an "odd" salad bar with some interesting looking prepared salads on it.  

The french onion soup was good - but a bit on the salty side - and they used packaged coutons in it, not a bread "crouton".

We were in a jam and needed to eat - so this served the purpose, but I would not rush back here.

I am not a big pizza eater, but I lknow Pina's stuff is fresh and good.  Try to order a whole pie and eat it there for the freshest and best atsting pie.  Sometimes the slices on the counter get a little old and dried out.

My 3 year old loves it here - and I'll usually run next door to saladworks and get something for myself.

The staff at Pina's has been very gracious to us.

We were dragged in here by our uber-artistic 7 year old and while there we got 4 pairs of fabric scissors (for $5 - SWEET), some fabric, embroidery thread, trimmings and a make-yyour-own "American Girl" style doll dress.

We though we were done when the "demo lady" (sweet as could be) who was cleaning up a beading workshop announced that they had free "make your own" head bands.

So we made some.
Free.

Time killer - and fun for the kiddos.

You can also rent the party roon ($50) to have a crafts party for up to 15 kids.
We'll think about this.

Just walking in here makes me feel so very "soccer mom".

The Chesterbrook Shopping Center is depressing with many vacant stores.  Aside from Diane's Deli (a hole-in-the-wall with dated decor but inexpensive and HUGE portions of classic deli), I only come here for Rite Aid.  And even then - only in a pinch.

I much prefer the Walgreens in Paoli (or maybe the CVS - but this Rote Aid is better than the Paoli CVS which has awful service and always has a line at check out even when the store is empty.  How is that even possible???

Anyhow this is your basic Rite Aid.  Pharmacy, OTC items, Candy/Snack & Beverages, Cosmetics.

No issues.

The whole area is being re-modeled (it sorely needs it) and there is a HUGE 2 year construction underway so parking will be a bit of a mess.  Be patient.  I bet the future will look brighter!

Ah, the ye olde Farm House Tavern - where (back - way back - in the day) one could get served alcohol underage.  Alas, those no-carding days are long over.

But the farmhouse seres decent bar food (it is by no means a gastro pub, and the regulars like it that way).

I preferred it here to Finney's back in the day - and often got a nice sandwich and fries to go with my beers or vodka-cranberry.

A good, old-time bar-lover's bar.

First of all - I think this placed is now OWNED by La Tolteca - because that is how my credit card went through.  (Said Casa Tropical on paper receipt but on computer said La Tolteca).

Very dark/old school interior.
Place was dead-empty for lunch on a summer Wednesday - even so my single order of mediocre ceviche took a while to be served.

Chips and salsa are fresh and delicious.
Not the greatest food - and oh, how I wanted to love it here.

Service was very good - nice young man.

I will not be rushing back here - which is a shame as I love me some good Maduros.

The average of these reviews is spot on - about 3.25 - 3.5 stars.
Please bear in mind that today was my first EVER experience with Positano Coast and I went for a luncheon as part of a group of 64 people.

We had a set menu - and service was quite good considering the difficult layout of the section of the room (PC does alot of large parties).

The meal cost $30 some dollars including tax 'n tip.
Included were a salad (very boring - lightly dressed), entree choice (Branzino or Eggplant Parm served with angel hair pasta or a Penne Priamvera), canolli and coffee/tea/soft drinks.

The eggplant was very tasty and the food was nice and hot.

Would I rush back?  Not really - but i would consider this place for a party (150 is easily done here - and you can rent the place out for a group of 300).

A solid place with decent service (Shout out to Perry - our server who worked her a$$ off!) and good, tasty (nothing spectacular) Iltalinaish/Mediterraneanish fare.

This place is adorable but the prices are obscene.  For the price of my latte it had better be exceptional.  It was good - but in no way mind blowing.  For a similar price (high) I can get a La Colombe.
Better yet I can get a small Au Lait here and it tastes better to me.

On par with Char-bucks, but slower service.
Very friendly male barista.

Pastries looked wonderful but again - too pricey and I can't eat carbs.
The almond croissant and almond biscotti (I sense a theme here) look so great.

Service was good - but a bit slower - it is a hand-crafted kinda place.

Average Acme at best.
Kinda small.  Average prices - some items seem high and others lower than Giant.

Lines move slowly, but checkers are friendly (and chatty - thus line takes time).

My little daughter & I stopped in here a few times for ice cream treats (they ahve alot of snacks for sale).

Nice to have them around - even if they close at 5 PM.

Saladworks is a hit or miss thing and varies location by rustied-lettuce location.  The one in my building (Commerce Square - was poorly managed and gross and went out of biz in 2007.)

If you get it on a clean day - and the lettuce looks fresh and green - go foor it, otherwise, skip the salad and stick to pasta or maybe a wrap. 

I don't like the paninis at all - too "bread-y".

The one at 18 & Market is OK, too.

We stopped by Scoop on the day after "Hurricane Irene" when lots of places were closed.  The little one wanted fro yo - but Sweet Ending was closed as well.

So I got her a small ($3.00) choc & van froyo topped (.75 cents) with mini m & m's (they were out of kit kats).

Not awesome and not awful - but the LINE was so long (likely because they were one of the only retail stores open and they were also under staffed).

In future we will stick to Sweet Ending (we love capogiro but it's pricey and they don;t have toppings and my kiddo's just gotta have her toppings).

This place is A-OK but not spectacular.

OK, maybe 3.5 stars - but not 4.

I just was not impressed with the food.  We had several small plates - and a really bitter greens-based salad.  Also a dessert panini which sounded much better on paper than it actually tasted.  The cheese selection was nice.

The service was fine, if a bit dis-interested,  and the decor and vibe call for a 4 or 5 star rating but the food was not worth the price, and not especially memorable.

This location I like better than the 11th Street location.  Not sure why - but we had a better time here.

Not nearly as nice as the Union League - but the food is good and maybe even better here - plus you have those gorgeous views of the city.

For a holiday party ofr networking event - it's a great spot.  As long as someone else is paying - I'll be there.  But there is NO WAY I'd join as a a member.  Too much money.

They easily accomodate large or small groups and have some meeting rooms that are cozy for the small ones.

This 3 star rating is for the Deli Department.  I give a MUCH higher rating to the produce manager.

I had a part and ordered (well in advance) a $59.99 cold cut tray and a $19.99 Chocolate-dipped strawberry tray (excellent and a great value).

There were many issues with both quality and presentation of the (medium sized) tray.
I spoke to the manager (LeighAnn) who was gracious and promptly refunded my $60 plus gave me a $10 gift card.  (Very nice to do that!).

5 star customer service - but I would have preferred a 5 star party tray.
Please "step up your game", Acme Deli.  

I am not likely to order trays from here again.

P.S.  We are still very, very grateful to this Acme for supporting our girl scout troop.  I would like to be supportive of Acme as well.  Sure wish that party tray had been good.

Food was fine - 4 star and service a little slow (2 star) by seasoned waitresses, like Eleanor.
Decor?  Ick.  Like an old cafeteria.

Decent for burgers or sandwiches.  I enjoyed my onion rings and patty melt but our 10 year old did not like the Chicken Caesar salad at all.  BLT looked great - at $4.99.

Decent prices.

Horrid parking lot when this place is busy.
Otherwise it's fine.

I was able to get the liquor I needed in a pinch for a Memorial Day party.

Usually we try to avoid PA and shop at Total Wine & More in Delaware.  Don;t get me started on PA's antiquated liquor laws.  I feel awful for bar owners, too!

I shopped here twice today first before a meeting (didn;t have enough time to try on) and again after the meeting ended AND after a trip to BCBG (see my review on them).

I tried on an exquisite hot pink $248 trench coat (yes, really) and some cute tops.  I settled on a strectch black knit top.  Decent price, too - reduced from 59.98 to 29.98.  SOLD!!!!

Note:  I cam back about 2 weeks later and the tank tops were on sale. ($19.99 each) snagged 2 of 'em and another cute sleeves top marked $49.98 but reduced by 30%. - Morale of story? The sales are good.

Ryan and the other lady at the front counter were very nice and helpful - but probably because the place was nearly empty both times I visited today.  I think they are HURTING for sales.

Went to CVS (across the street and down a bit) too get passport pictures taken.  Their camera was broken so I came here.

Should have came here first - much cleaner and emptier store.

Meanwhile the lady running their photo center could not get the proper label to print.  I waited and waited for my pictures.  Finally she just let me HAVE them.  Free.  

They need to figure out their photo procedures better.

OK, I will be nice and cut them a break.  It should be 2 or 2.5 stars, but I am hoping they will work out the kinks and improve.  The menu sounded sooooo wonderful and my friend was keen to try Root - so we went.  The place was dead empty when we arrived, but throughout our meal about 8 people were dining.  Definitely BYO something - they have NOTHING to drink but water.

Turns out this is the site of the former Palate BYOB.  I guess they just couldn't make it.

The food is really not great.  (Which is a shame because they claim to use sustainable and local ingredients and I strive to support it.  The tattoo-covered chef and the server (a nice gal) were hospitable.

Here's what made the food more like 2 stars.  I started with the poached shrimp salad.  It came with 2 large, overcooked a bit rubbery shrimp.   The greens were shredded and appeared to be romaine and napa cabbage in a tangy vinaigrette.  The drizzle of (good quality) balsamic around the plate edge was good.

Now the strange entree.  (We skipped dessert  -  didn't want to chance it.)  I ordered the rabbit and oxtail raviolo with uni cream.  The Oxtail was the best part - rich, and meaty with a delicious flavor.  The rabbit really did taste like dark meat chicken.  And the sauce was heavy - but tasty.  Here's a the bad part - the crepes were heavy as lead.  Kinda like a cross between home-made paste (flour & water) and Bisquick.  Really strange.  Not deelicate at all, and certainly not like pasta - more like a home-made leaden buscuit that fell flat.

It's really a shame.  I am hoping they can figure it out - and they really, really need A/C or at least a few more fans.

Sadly I am not one of them...
Convenient location but super crowded on weekdays during the lunch hour(s) as a result.  I got in and out fast.  THANK goodness they had what I needed.

I agree with Alice L.  (Though historically I have alsways enjoyed sampling the Violet and Rose flavors.)  The store is VERY old and has been a New Hope institution for years.  It COULD use a clean up.

I do enjoy the ice cream here - but willl not go during peak tourist season as I will NOT wait in a line for it.

The owner is a character - that said I have never had any bad experiences here.  Only tasy ice cream!

OK, I am only reviewing the front lobby bar and the meeting facilities and food - all of which were solid and good.  I did not stay overnight here so I can't comment on the rooms.

Meanwhile, I attended a nice corporate event here last night (with dinner included) and a colleague drove - so he knew exactly where it was - BUT even he mentioned that the signage is weak and it's very hard to find this place if you don't know where to look.

We started with drinks at the lobby bar.  I had a fairly weak and not too spicey 3 star Bloody Mary.  It came with a slice of lemon and when I asked the female bartended (very sweet lady) for celery she said they did not have it.

OK.  Points off for that.  If you want a kickin' Bloody Mary by the way - try Bar North Third. but I digress...  Mmmn.  Now  I want a bloody mary.

OK.  Next it was off to the dinner/meeting.  The tables were pre-set with very warm butter (had been sitting out for quite some time).  The immediately plated chilled caesar salads that were very good - basic and crisp.  Not overly dressed.  The rolls were hot - which was a nice touch.

My entree - wild mushroom ravioli - was very tasty - and looked much better that the chicken marsala (1/2 a semiboned breast with a wing drumette attached - looked very banquet - and ONE mushroom.)

I was glad I did not order the chicken - but people ate it and seemed 3 -4 star happy.

Dessert was a moist carrot cake garnished with a single wilted strawberry.  All in all - things could have used a bit more polish and freshening up.

Service was very efficient - a bit too "hurry up and let the staff leave" for my taste.

Coffee was fresh and very yummy.

Meeting rooms was nice - standard hotel corporate stuff.

I have a feeling I'll be back for future events here.

OMG! What a "scene"- if you want to people watch or have "dinner & a show" in tiny-cramped-Manhattan-style tables, this just might be the place for you.

A friend and I met for lunch - which wound up costing me $23.00 for an iced tea and a shrimp salad ($18.00 - ouch!).  She had a hair in her pizza - Eeeeew! Luckily the staff were gracious about it and whisked it away and didn't charge us for it.  The owners of Serafina chain (we used to go to the one on Madison in NYC and it, too, was a "scene"), were holding court with a bunch of leggy PR ladies.  Plus the Chairman of my old law firm was in the house.

What a freakish afternoon.

Decent, overpriced food served with a generous helping of hype - but so not my bag, baby.

Kudos to our lovely server Ayram - I pray does not have to suffer there too long.

Serafina should do well in Center City.   If you are a displaced Manhattanite and long for the old days - this place will do you right.  (Try the carpaccio - looks great.)

Somewhere between Meh and A-OK.
I attended a meeting here in the front bar area at the tables behind the bar.

Happy hour was ending so there were some luke-warm mozzarella sticks and dried out wings in a chafing dish.  Yuck.  (But free.)

The food I ordered (albeit a garden salad) was fresh but boring.
Others plates looked unappetizing - fish & chips was a huge piece of fish in a THICK coating of batter.  (And chips which I don't eat).

Servers were pleasant and owner is a wonderful supporter of the community and my kid's school - but I am not impressed by the "classic" pub fare.

Also it gets LOUD in there, but that is a sign of a good pub.

Blah.

i went there with my daughters girl scout troop.
the reason that i gave it a 3 is because the pancakes were sour and the fruit was
not sweet.the rest was fine

This place used to be called Zai Fa and was mediocre then and is a touch better (In my opinion) now.  We ordered about $100 worth of food which easily fed our crowd of 10 adults and 2 little kids.

Fried Dumplings were better than the steamed - average and a bit "doughy".  Eggrolls and Shrimp Egg rolls were crisp, contained actual shrimp and lots of shredded cabbage.

Spare ribs were meaty and EXCELLENT. (Even better than Hong Kong Jack's which is our family's go-to for D-town old-school Chinese).

House special fried rice was just OK - Hong Kong Jack's is better.
Chicken with Broccoli was ordered "light on the sauce" and thus was not nearly as greasy as it could have been.  They use brown sauce for their Chix 'n Brox.

My husband and Brother-in-law like hot food and enjoyed the General Tso's Chicken (looked very nice - text book Tso!) and Mongolian Beef.
Combo platters are a good value and while they are heavy on the fried rice - there is a hefty portion of the entree (in our case Kung Pao Chicken) in there, too.

Very good egg drop, wonton and hot 'n sour soups (all are text book 1975 recipe Chinese American).  While not mind blowing - I can definitely see ordering Quart of Hot 'n Sour or Wonton the mext time I have the flu.

It is take out only (They might have 2 tiny tables out front) and be sure to grab your packets of duck, soy and mustard sauces on the way out.

I wanted to love it here - and the owners are incredibly sweet - especially the owners mother - but the food just was not great.

I had the tulip dumplings which were slightly hard on top.
My husband's drunken noodles were over cooked (chicken was a little dry and noodles a bit mushy).  Also $7.95 for a salad of solely steamed snow peas with a few mushrooms on top is obscene.

I love Thai food and I liked the people here - but we won;t be rushing back.
Heng's Thai in Sprinfield or even Nooddi down the street had better food.

It's not bad - but nothing much to write home about.  Brunch is probably the saving grace and they are accomodating - somewhat- to my 3 year old daughter.  Not a fave for me - but OK for a brunch.

Oh, and it's moderately priced - so it's not horrible.

Average food and average service.  A neighborhood place but not a neighborhood RAVE nor FAVE.  (I almost gave 2 stars - but our burgers were quite tasty.)

It's kinda "meh"/"blah" on the decor too.  A bit shabby.

Need locally grown lavender for soap making or crafts?  Come here!   (But comeon a Saturday only and bring cash).

Not for kids (although my little one is nearly 8 and can now appreciate it here.)
Come here on your way to or from Solebury Orchards.

Well, they gutted the old Raindrop Cafe (thank god!). Sweet ending is a cute concept and since we don't have a PINKBERRY (or Red Mango) nearby and I had a BOGO (free) coupon, I caved.

You pay $0.49 per oz and can dispense your own self-serve fro-yo (very tart BTW) and toppings.

The yogurt was meh - but the fruit toppings were good.

Place is brand spanking new and clean - but not nearly as good tasting as pinkberry or red mango.

I predict it will fail in the long run.  Philly people won;t like this very acidic yogurt.  Service was good though and with the BOGO I got 2 small cups of yogurt with toppings for $2.18.

Oh - and the name reminds me of "Happy Endings" which kinda grosses me out - but if i can snag another coupon I'll get over it.

I wish them luck.  There gonna need it.
I much prefer the sorbetto at Capogiro (but that is not even a fair comparisson).

It's ok here.  Pub Grub and a long beer list - alas I don't touch the stuff.
So food wise they have Fries with various mayo-based dipping sauces and grill up a decent burger.

It's a bar.  Good - but not mind-blowing by any means.
I'd go again.
A beacon of light in downtown Harleysville.  Right on Main Street - easy to find and has everything you might need (not gas station - this is an old-school wawa in a strip mall).

Louis B., as usual, is right on the money with his review of this convenient but unglamorous Acme.  I get my nails done at Trendy Nails and sometimes use the dry cleaner in the same "strip" so it's way convenient.  Very old-skool.

Honestly - I much prefer the Giant in Aston or Trader Joe's or weekend sojourns to Whole Paycheck (ahem - Whole Foods) in Glen Mills, but in a pinch - this Acme's got what I need - most of the time.

Much improved now that they renovated (it was filthy from 2005 - 2008 or so).  A vast selection of beers, sodas, iced teas and other beverages.

Convenient.

My little one has nicknamed Asia Crafts the "Hello Kitty" store.  They specialize in Sanrio, gifts & stationery.  There is a wide array of Hello Kitty items including rare and hard to find Sanrio collections.  Prices run a bit high - but many items are on sale.

They also have a small beverage cooler in the front of the store stocked with multi-colored (and sugar laden) beverages from Asia.  If you have a little one and are in Chinatown, check out Asia Crafts for Hello Kitty and more.

OK.  Decent enough coffee - but by no means up to the standars of Old City Coffee, Peregrine or La Colombe (and not nearly as fun as Passero's).  A nice place to sit and chill and use a decent bathroom in Center City.

In the summer I opt for iced coffee, in winter/fall (mornings) I like a cafe au lait.

We have taken our car here twice for tire changes/rotations.
Drop off at 8 AM on a Saturday and picked up at 1 PM.

However, the first round of "cheap" tires we selected gave out at 45,000 miles.
Let's hope this next round lasts a bit longer.
Decent burgers, salads & sandwiches.  We came in winter, so no outdoor seating when we went, but service was perfectly fine and food was very good.  We'd return.

This is the Giant near Arch Road and 202 in East Norriton.
Salad bar, Hot food bar with decent fried chicken.

Not luxurious and no sushi but it's fine.

Glad it's here.
Nicer than ShopRite.

It seems just like Naked Chocolate Cafe before it - nothing has changed much.

I got a big box of truffles as a gift - very nice.

I have my daughter's 5th birthday party here (at this location) when it was Naked.
I hope the new folks are as easy and pleasant to deal with.

I have alot of nostalgic memories about Willow Grove Mall.  (You see, Montgomery Mall was our default Mall until Willow Grove came around.)

We take our daughter here to ride the $2.00 (adult can accompany for free) carousel - which is the highlight of our experience.

This place is now past its prime for sure. (Alas, as most malls are in the USA.)

The food court has a SaladWorks, Taco Bell, Sbarro, a cheesesteak place and a few other mid-range average choice.  Not great.

Less impressed than I wanted to be - I am dithering between 3 and 4 stars - and here's why...

A colleague and I had a lunch reservation.  Service was good - friendly and courteous.

He had the (last one) "Blue Plate" special - a crabcake (one) and salad.  I chose the heirloom tomato salad with (one lump of) burrata and an EXCELLENT balsamic and EVOO drizzle.

We split an order of WAY OVERCOOKED duck fat fries.  Awful.  Greasy.  Salted.  Burned.  Mess.

My first bite of the salad was of a red tomato and it was rotten.
Thankfully the rest of the salad was perfect.

The food is so close to being "as good as it gets" - in theory - but the puny portion size (my male colleague needed the fries as the crabcake plate was app sized.), rotten tomato bite and charred fries soured our experience. The burrata was the "real deal".  The ingredients are all great - they just need better execution.

Meanwhile, our male server was cheerful and terrific.
He even took the fries off the check.  ($40 for lunch for 2 - no apps, no dessert, no booze).

Garces - I love ya - but JG needs some tweaking, please.

This used to be one of my favorite places to go - when I was 10.
Really.

They have cards & stickers & gifts & godiva (limited selection) and they used to carry Crabtree 7 Evelyn products back in the day.

The owners may have changed - as Paper Unicorn has been a Doyletown institution for eons.

But I did used to LOVE it.

I do not eat this stuff but my 10 year old wanted fried chicken so we went through the drive- through on a slushy-snowy mess of a night.  Service was extra slow because of this and the person 2 cars ahead of us who needed to wait for her food pulled up but no far enough blocking the rest of the line.

A mess.

Meanwhile - the chicken and biscuit were both hot & fresh and my kid devoured the whole caloric mess right in the car.

So much for a healthy meal.

We'll likely be back - for her - not for me!

Eh. Meh.  It's relatively clean and comfortable - but the best part is that it is located near to my office complex - so we have ALOT of pharma-types staying here.

Food is just bad - so we order off premises.

It's big, it's got lots of show and it's right near my house.  How in the heck do you yelp something like this?  It's no Moscone Center - but it is very useful and they are now expanding it.

We attend the Auto Show and Flower show every year and other trade-related shows in between.

Whatevs.

The food was terrific at St. Stephen's green today - it just took so. so. so. long to get it.

Part of it might have been what we ordered - I had a divine braised shortrib (fell right off the bone) over fettucine.  "Does this come in a heavy sauce?", I asked.  "Oh, no." replied our server.  LIES!!!  I asked for light on the oil - and true enough there was very little oil.

Just tons of BUTTER on the fettucine.

Oh well.  My hips will thank me tomorrow.

The Isabella Salad is terrific and I will be getting that next time - if I can do a next time.  I get an hour for lunch and we wallked in at 1:05 PM and out at 2:20.  I bit too long for lunch, I'm afraid.

And a bit too pricey for lunch - if you order (as I did) a DINNER FOR LUNCH.  Next time salad or the grilled turkey wrap. 

Server was pleasant (a little slow) and one of the owners was there and he is a doll.

I am very close to giving them 4 stars.

But now I need a post osso-bucco nap .
It was (rich and) delicious.

Now that I am not in college anymore (ahem!), my J. Crew days are a bit behind me.  That said I did come into this branch of J. Crew (below liberty place - on Chestnut) and bought 2 fabulous T-shirts.

Yes, I said Fab & T in the same breath.

These were not any ordinary T-shirts, these were "Tissue" T-shirts - and they were super-light weight (yet not see-thru - thank g-d!) and soft and kinda like tissue papery.  Weird - but great.

I wear them only in the sweltering heat of the summer - when a "normal" T shirt is even too hot.

Good job, J. Crew!  I love those "Tissue T Shirts".

I am having bipolar love/hate feelings toward the brand-new Tierra Mia Organic Nail spa.  While I love and heartily endorse the concept of "natural", "green", and "Organic" nail treatments, I have not found the water based polishes/top/base coats to be long lasting.

I was assured that Karina's technique is unique and long lasting, that said
the services by Karina here are second to none, and organic and in a GREEN environment.

Meanwhile a simple polish change (called a Mimos) was heavenly in there one and only high-end "Sound therapy" chair - quite possibly the best pedi chair I have ever sat in.  You can tell Karina and her fiance have spent a bundle on equipment, products (Rich Hippe/Nature Girl is pricey stuff!) and renovating the space (Clay walls!!).  They have done a great  (and green) job.


Now for the bad news...

The icy-cold receptionist made me feel as though I was not trustworthy and she followed me around the salon, fearful that I would rip off a bottle of polish.

This tainted my experience in an extremely negative way.

I may or may not return.  Next time for a complete ritual.  perhaps now the receptionist won't be so nervous that I might steal products.  That really hurt.

Note: The day after my Mimos we went for our vacation in Cape Cod - the sun, salt & surf turned my sheer pink pedi - YELLOW within 48 hours. Sickly, ugly yellow.  Another example of how inferior the water-based top coats are.  I miss my CND and OPI.  I wonder if Karina would let me bring my own products and have her apply them? 

Mama ain't too happy with the end results of this polish change!

Probably more of a 2 star review - but I am feeling generous - and since this IHOP is one I am likely to re-visit I will try to be kind.  IHOP is the kind of chain that can vary greatly in cleanliness - but the food is EXACTLY the same in each and every location, as it is cooked via formula by disinterested underpaid teens and young adults.

Surprisingly enough we have never come here during the mad breakfast rush - but rather on Sundays after 4 PM when it is dead empty - and thus our service is usually good and food hot.

My hubby likes the flavored pancakes - and I really enjoy the crepes.
Not a Holy Grail by any means - but it is cheap and good in a pinch.

I truly think SEPTA has improved over the past 5 years - yes there are still problems.  The schedule on weekends, nights and mid-day (non rush hour) is awful (you can wait 60 - 75 minutes between trains), but if you are a "simple" 9 - 5 or 8 - 4 commuter and live on a shorter line (NOT Doylestown - the "slow boat to China") like Media/Elwyn - it's fairly painless.

Yes, the fares have increased.  So what?  Deal with it - try paying for gas and parking and dealing with the stress of driving every day?  No thanks.

I love public transportation - and just which there were more of it.

Wow - this place is enormous.  They have all the department's you'd expect at a grocery store - plus a sushi counter and a pizza oven area.

No issues - I got in and out relatively quickly.

Eh.  I was not thrilled by Banana Leaf - the service was pretty spotty.  Very little english spoken by our server in particular.  Manager Lady spoke well, but seemed pissed off.

The food?  Aside from the Roti appetizer (which was 5 star, fresh and tasty), it was less than stellar.

Fried shrimp with Yuca were HEAVY as lead, greasy and over-filling.
Green Curry in a Clay pot was fragrant - but just is not my bag, baby.
I tried the Ginger Duck Lo Mee - too much greasy sauce and I asked for it "dry".

Oh well.  Live and experiment.

Not horrible but not orgasmic.  I won't be coming back soon.  I think I like Thai and Viet Namese food better.

Underwhelmed by lackluster fish quality (not bad but not great - had hamachi and sake sashimi) and too many sauces on the Salmon Tar Tar masking "meh"minced fish.

Tom Kha Gai which I normally adore was cold and "gloopy" and had to be sent back.

The best bite?  The kiddo's chocolate fondue ($10).

Expensive to pay for average meal at best.
This is our 4th visit and it has gone down a bit each time.
Sad - as I loved it here at first and we all enjoy the ambience.

This is our go-to Wawa when we need "cheap Jersey gas" on our way from PA to or from NYC.

Decently clean ladies room and my 9 year old can get a chicken strip shortie with lettuce, tomato and cucumber (her "usual"),

Snacks, drinks, coffee and all the usual Wawa staples.

And in Jersey the gas is all full-serve (such a novelty).

After a 6 year hiatus (I was not working in Philly) I am back and I guess I did not read my own review because I needed some sushi (sashimi, actually) and for $9.99 I got 2 pieces each of Salmon (not that great), tuna (good) and Yellowtail (surprisingly good and not fishy tasting).  I also got a $2.99 side of cucumber salad.

I may be back - especially when I am in the Comcast Center, as Sook Hee's has sadly, closed.

We buy liquor here on occaision because it is convenient.
I think the PA liquor laws are really strange and generally nonsensical.
They did have some chilled prosecco, though and that was great as I was on my way to a BYO.

Not a GREAT store - but OK in a pinch.

This store has GORGEOUS merchandise and even offers a bridal registry.  Too bad it's out of my price range.  The owner has a friendlt dog - who is not always there.  It's a really neat place to look around and get ideas - but to actually purchase here?  Just not gonna work for me.

Sorry.

I like Havana's.  I don't LOVE it. I could easily give it 4 stars on a good (read: not packed with a zillion NY tourists) day.  OK - so it's a 3.5 star place.  Decent food and live music on weekends and it the summer.
