Although, frankly I avoid places like this during peak season.

It's been around forever and is not too overpriced.  We had a great birthday party here a few years back for a friend of mine and they accomodated our group of 16 with ease.  (And got all our food orders right - the first time.)

Not sure if it's still on the menu - but the "Day after Thanksgiving" sandwich (Cold turkey, stuffing, cranberry sauce and other things) was a big hit and so yummy.

It's a target - but not the best one.  It's got alot of pick-over merchandise, but all in all we can usually get what we need.

We shop here 1-2 times per month and never fail to drop at least $100 on household products, toddler gear and assorrted crap we don't really need EVERY time we walk thru the door.

We came on a sale day (25% off just about everything in the store) and managed to battle the choking throngs of people to get bras & shapewear.

The shoe department was so overcrowded that shopping was just not possible.

Great values (on sale day) but be prepared to power-shop!

Not bad - for a deli/hot food buffet.  Especially oif you get here at 11:30 or so when the food is still fresh and has not yet been picked over by the lunch crowd.

Nice guys behind the counter/grill for breakfast, too.

Reminds me alot of my deli in New Yawk.

I like it, OK for a cheap, quick fix.

So sad - just called to book a lunch-time banquet and was told they no longer offer banquets on the weekends.  (And now that they are renovating part of the building they may not offer them at all for a while.)

Boo.

Wanted to have an event here.

I was part of a large party (about 33 people) with a set meal and it was good but not great - I have a feeling ordering off the "regular" menu would have yielded better results.

Meanwhile, service was good - especially by Will & Anna - and the lady at the reception desk is very kind also.

Tofu & Veggie soup was good.
Salad was your basic iceberg with ONE slice of cucumber and one small wedge of pale tomato.  Kinda blah. (Got the overly sweet ginger dressing on the side).

Sushi was the best part and the tuna avocado and salmon avocado maki were both good (4 star for that).  Salmon teriyaki dinner was a bit too well done for me - but again it was part of a "set" meal and if I ever went back i would have ordered it more on the rare side.  

I dither between 3 & 4 stars but dated decor and food improvements that are needed prevent me from giving a higher review.

In the mean time for a cost effective group party they can accommodate about 30 -35 people in the back dining area.

We went here - believe it or not- for our neighbor'd 5 year old daughter's birthday party.
Um - OK - a 5 year old.  FIVE.

F.I.V.E.

OK.  We brought our 3 year old.  There were about 14 kids from ages 3 - 12 and their assorted parents.  It was a Saturday during the afternoon.

This place is really neat - but it's more like a club-slash-bowling alley.

It is NOT where I would have a kids party - but surprisingly it all worked.  The adults had drinks and lots of fried-bad-for-you apps.
The kids ate a grocery-store cake that they brought and Lucky Strikes made little cheese pizzas for each kid.

They did not have any milk for my 3 year old so she got all sugared up on a big glass of OJ.

Dudes, this is not a kids place.  A sweet sixteen (like Rumer Willis - allegedly had at the Lucky Stikes in LA) maybe - but not a freakin' five year old.

What?  I coulda sworn I already reviewed Pietro's.  I have been here several times but will base this 3 star review on my last visit which included a terrific basket of hot pizza dough rolls (and Olive oil for dipping) and a special salad with Poached chicken, avocado and eggs over delicious, crisp romaine.  Huge - and FRESH.  A winner.

Very affordable and good in a pinch when you are in the Rittenhouse area and don't have time/money for the swankier joints.

It's ginormous - but it really has suffered in recent years.  This crappy economy can't be helping.  Droves of bored teens roam the mall.

Be sure you remember where you parked - people have LOST there cars (or had them stolen) from the enormous parking lots.

The outlets can be a bargain but yo9u MUST shop carefully.  Some of the prices are standard retail.  Do your research before you go.

OK, so instead of a dollar store - we now have a fiver store.
5 below sells lots of cheap crap - some of it useful and seasonal - like we got a booogie board for our 5 year old here, and some silly bandz.
Now that she's 8 she can buy her nail polish and bath & body colorful items here.

My kids loves it here.
The CEO used to run Zany Brainy and went to Friends Select.  (He's a smart guy!)

I am not a huge fan of cheap crap - but hey - if it keeps her happy - so be it.

Oh - and you can get Good Humor and other ice cream treats for 1-2 dollars in the front freezer (cheaper than most Wawa's and far cheaper than the rip-off ice cream truck at the beach.)
Just  OK.  Good baked good.  Mediocre produce.  Sorry - but the peaches were sold out and the green pepper was old.  Not impressed, Tabora!

I was lucky - I came here right at 8 AM when the pharmacy opened and the place was empty - thus no waiting (lines here can be ridiculous.).  Plus I got a bottle of "SmartWater" for $1.  Score!

Wish they had more cashiers.  (They also have 4 self check outs that sometimes don;t always work.)

A necessary evil.

Grotty digs and no A/C, but even so, friendly staff and a family-run jawn.   An extensive menu of wraps, salads, hoagies, steaks and fried goodies. The food itself was just OK.  I had a wrap and the bacon tasted a wee bit sour.  (Odd) Plus it was drowning in ranch dressing.  Next time (if there is a next time) I will get less dressing or ask for it on the side.

I want to support and love local businesses - and Sleepy Hollow is a neighborhood fave, but for me it was just OK.

Have been back 3 more times and I need to just stick to the items I like.  (Salmon Spring rolls - a greasy but tasty indulgence)  Love the Quinoa salad - dressing (sugar-fest) and puree on the side.

Pizza is AWFUL.  (We tried the whole grain crust and it was weird tasting.)
Pasta dish was swimming in a greasy sauce.  (Never again.)
No substitutions on specials.  (Oh, well.)

It's formula cooking and for a bar - 4 stars but as a restaurant it's more like 3.

Service is sporadic and server-dependent.  We've had it great and not-so-great.

Just OK service and decent sashimi for a Saturday lunch. The place was deserted around 2 PM.  Salmon and tuna were fresh.  Escolar (Mock white tuna) was not.

All that said, I have now been here twice and I would come back, if in the area.

Now I gotta be honest - I havenb't visited B&I in YEARS, but back in the day it was a go too breakfast/lunch/brunch spot.  Bagels, eggs, the works.  My parents liked it - and had it been closer to Doylestown we woulda gone there much more.

Glad to hear they are still around.
I only like Saladworks if the lettuce is fresh - and sometimes at this one - it's not.  It's also like $7.000 for a salad.  Eek.

My 12 year old is obsessed with PINK and Adidas and other "name-brand" casual clothes.  Plato's closet is a hit-or-miss source for used, low cost clothing.  Be prepared to get your hands dirty (eew) and dig through the racks - but if you do find what you like it is a great value.

Plato's has many locations and this one seems grungier than the Paoli location or the Philly location.

Step it up, please! We need you.

If you've been to one CVS you've seen 'em all.

Pros:  small parking lot
Has everything you need

Cons:  Small parking lot - you better watch out!
Inept staff
High urban prices

I am not a big cheese-steak lover - in fact - I don't like them - but for Jim's I make an exception.  You can forgo Pat's and Geno's (and the rude "'Wiz 'Witout, fast-paced steak-nazi ordering techniques) and get me to Jim's after a night of partying.

Love the chicken cheese steak wityh provolone and 'shrooms.

Once or twice a year is MORE than I can handle.

I am vacillating between 3 and 4 stars - here's why...

I drove in (easy to get in - but hard to drive out - you must exit onto Route 1 and it is a divided highway there - so you have to go down to the next traffic light and then turn around to go the other way.

Located on a busy corner of Route 1 and 452, this place has been here 11 years!  It is freshly painted and bright and cheery inside.  WALK INS ONLY.  They do not take appointments.  NEVER.  (Really?  Yes, really.)

Meanwhile, It was not crowded on a Tuesday evening, but I bet there's a big wait on Saturdays.

Anyhow they offer many "tiers" of service from a basic $11 mani, to a cheapie $20 no-frills pedi to the $55 Delux spa pedi.

I went for the $36 spa pedi - a regular pedi with 10 minutes of extra massage (Ti-Kim - my technician - set a TIMER.).  So far, so good.  However, the polish selection are all no-name brands - with a few scattered bottles of OPI.  My suggestion - bring your own polish (and possibly your own base and top coat.)

The real test will be when I get a mani here.
Oh - and they do gels for $25.  

It's OK - but I have been spoiled by high quality/low cost NYC nail care (and more recently 4 sisters in Center City - the newer location).

Ti-Kim is  a lovely lady - so see if she is there if you go.

I will be back - this place is leaps and bounds ABOVE the other spots I've seen in Media/Aston.

Hit or miss - but when you hit, you can hit it big.
Good deals on hostess gifts/housewares too - but you need to be patient and pick through.

I did not find evelvation burger to be particularly "elevated" - in fact, the burger had no seasoning.  (At least it wasn't over seasoned).

I ordered a "create your own" single patty burger (I don't need 2 patties) with Lettuce (iceberg) tomato, caramelized onions (greasy but good) and guac ($1.50 extra) - came to about $6.

No fries, no drink.

Not bad but not great - Five guys is about the same, Smashburger is better.

Meanwhile, if you need a burger (or fried chicken sandwich) and you are at the dying Plymouth Meeting Mall, go for it.

Spacious, clean seating, icy-cold a/c system - the place was nearly empty at 12:15 PM on a Monday.  Not a great sign.  Bertucci's next door was hoppin'.

Kid friendly.

I am rating this based on the swimming pool and programs for children/toddlers.  The teachers were/are lovely but the facilities (locker rooms & pool) are just Meh.

Meanwhile, I am thankful that my (then) 3 year old (now 5) had 2 great sessions of lessons here for a decent ( a bit high but not horrible) price.  She loved it here!

Juicy - long the purveyour of pricey velour tracksuits - has opened a boutique at 17 & Walnut where the Bath & Body Work used to be.  Very nice things, but kinda young for me and not corporate enuf for work.

Good "knock around" weekend clothes and party dresses - but way too pricey for the junky fabrics they use.

Also the sales staff (range in age from 18 - 24) are very snotty.

Not  a fave for me.

They have remodeled but the service is still pretty abysmal.
Not to mention the low quality, artery clogging food.

My 13 year old likes to get the four for $4 deal about twice a month - You get a tiny sandwich (chicken or a mini burger), fries, a few chicken nuggets (more fried food) and a drink.  El kiddo like the chocolate frosty.

I am trying ever so hard not to be a food Nazi, but I would never eat this garbage.  I try to not take el kiddo here too often.

There is one guy who works here and has for a LONG time who live in our neighborhood.  Otherwise, I never get great service and the drive through line can back up in a hurry.

People, apparently, love Wendy's and this location is doing just fine.

We have seen a frew films here at the Franklin Institute's Tuttleman Imax theatre - ,ostly because we are members and have a 4 year old.

She loves it and would probably give it 4-5 stars.
We thought it was OK, but it can be crowded.  Luckily we got centrally located seats fairly high up and the views were great.

I miss the old days with Pink Floyd and Laser light shows.

I have had a couple of pairs of shoes shined here and one needed new heels/soles.
No issues from me.

I wish Philly had MORE shoe shine/shoe repair places.
They are a dying breed.

Bring money to pay the deposit.

I love crepes - and had walked by this place many times.
So I finally went in (even though I had not before due to the high-ish prices).
It was $4.95 for a plain crepe with butter and sugar (drizzled with chocolate or grand marnier had I desired.  I did not.  I wanted fresh lemon).

They had none. Do basically I had a plain butter/sugar crepe for $5.

Whipped cream is also a free option.

For $4.95 this was too miuch for a plain crepe.
That said, it was tasty - and the service was friendly.

I will go back once more for the $6.95 crepe bearnaise.

I hope its more substantial.

Tip:  Eat there - or only take out if you are right nearby.  I work 5 blocks away and it was too far to take it out and have it still be hot and fresh.

I wish Passero's was still here.

Hit or miss and you must be patient and willing to "pick through".
As Marshalls go - this one is average at best.  Disinterested staffers gabbing up front.

Not a great experience but - when you find a good deal you can hit big!

Soft fresh white bread (rolls) and decent cold-cut based sandwiches.
A decent value and yes, very fast service.

This location was clean and convenient when my kid & I needed a quick lunch.
Tuna is very good - for chunk light - not too mayonnaise-y.  Cucumber and tomatoe slices were fresh.

No issues.
Update:  I just found out a friend of mine works here.  5 stars for Danny - about 3 for the food.

I ate here one time about 18 months ago.  Service was great and the Thai ladies who served me were very cordial and friendly.  Food was only so-so - and now the Thai Chef is in business there is really no reason for me to go to My Thai,

However, I will say that Thai food is not as abundant in Philly - so I am glad they are here as they do meet a need - but I am still on a quest for truly awesome Thai in Center City - there is some great Thai in the Suberbs.

Maybe I should have given them 4 stars?  But that really is pushing it.

Sorry @Michael - but I disagree.  Yes, Stutz is an area landmark - they've been around for DECADES - but the candiesare just MEH.  (Better than Russell Stover - but not great.)

They are a fresher version of drugstore "assortment" chocolates.

ICK.

Once you've had fine chocolates (Michel Cluizel, Teuscher, Leonidas) you can't eat this dreck any longer.

No issues.  Got in and out quickly.
Took kiddo ext door to Yogurtland for fro yo.

Parking lot sucks - always a chaotic, crowded cluster.

This is now called Altitude.
My 13 year old had a blast here at a private group functions (Her group rented the space from 6 - 9 PM and brought in their own pizza, water and cake).

Staff is a bit disinterested and place is way dirtier than the "Sky Zone" we go to in Glen Mills, PA.

Not awful but not great.

Oh - and loud as heck in there.

Will write extensive comments after our honeymoon in October 2008 is completed.  They are handling it.

It's a touchy thing because my brand new sister in law is our agent - and I normally book all my own stuff.  She is a doll - but young and just learning.  We wanting to give her some business.

It doesn't look like the rating will go higher than 3.

My 10 year old came here with a good friend after seeing the Pope and got a stack of delicious banana pancakes.  It looks like this place has been here for EVER but it's actually pretty darned good.

Typical diner fare and family friendly.

Had a good chicken parm panini here.  I am not a big sandwhich eater.  Wanted to get a salad but the line was way too long and the cost too high.  ($4.00 just for the lettuce base and then add-ons at 50 - 1.25 each.)  To get the salad with th ingredients I wanted would have been $9.00.  (Although I am sure the ingredients are high quality - they have a selection of organic meats to choose from.)

So a plain salad of lettuce, carrots & celery is $5.00.

No thanks.  Not life altering for me - but OK.  Way nicer than fourbucks.

Baja Fresh is OK in my book.  I like Qdoba/Chipotle a bit more flavorwise, but i really like the concept of Baja's salsa bar.  You can load up on the different types of Salsa.

This location wasn't nearly as gross as Rafael made it seem on the days we came in.  They did announce order numbers over a loudspeaker, though - but I could discern ours.

I like the fish tacos at Baja - that is something that neither Qdoba nor Chipotle offer.  Reminds me a bit of the Maui Tacos chain.

They also do a decent salad in a bowl.
Baja Fresh is a good fast food alternative (watch the calorie counts of what you order) if you don't feel like a burger.

2 or 3 stars depending on which hair tech you get.  They do offer Phyto Products though and sometimes I will run in to get what I need (at full retail).  They also used to carry a Caviar Conditioner I liked - not sure if they still do.

The one lady I liked is gone (Cindy) - and you could tell she had "issues" - she was pregnant with spiky blond hair when I met her.  Gave me a decent cut.

The other lady I had claimed to be the manager.  She did me for a last minute updo and was very controlling (she did what SHE wanted to do, not what I wanted) and thus, I was not happy.

I have NEVER (and likely will never) had my hair colored here.  I only came here again (after Cindy left) because it was an emergency.

Oh - and the prices are pretty reasonable - it's a chain - they can do that.
And (thankfully) they can usually accomodate walk ins.

It is a classic Philly institution but honestly - not the greatest diner in the world.  What really is interesting are the waitresses and regulars - some who have been coming here for 45 years.  (And a few servers who have worked here that long.)

I had a classic patty melt and it WAS greasy and a dietary mess.  Not sure if it was worth it as the food is really 2-3 stars at best.

Plus:  it's very inexpensive.  Great People watching.

For food - I prefer the Oregon Diner.
PenRose is Also good.

This place was the shizzle back in the day.  I am amazed they are still here (and glad of it) and that they still serve that good (if slightly salty) Italian Wedding Soup.  (I think they call it Chicken Holiday - but it is basically IWS.)

In the old days, pre-Applebee's, this was a good place to grab a drink (they used to have a full bar and poured strong ones.) and have a some good food.  The pasta's were tasty back then.

The restroom could use an overhaul.  (One, might argue that the entire place could use a little sprucing up in the decor department.)

Rock on, Tomatoes!  Rock on!

Ridiculous prices for teensy portions served by a surly staffer who my companion has nickenamed "The Krusty Krab".

I love lobster rolls - and these (The Classic in particular) are tasty but sooooooo tiny.

And the only sides are soup or chips.
No side salad, no corb on the cob or steamed green beans.

I dropped $17 - on 1.5 rolls (got 1 low carb and 1/2 on bread).
And a pickle.

So glad i brought my water bottle as a bottle of Fiji runs $2.65.
I guess people love it here - and the brand-new decor is lovely but I need more food and more side choices, please.

This review is for CPK's corporate catering.  We eat basically the same 2 sandwiches at EVERY event my company hosts.  Turkey , Arugula & Brie or Grilled Veggie sandwiches.  Sometimes we will have a few pizzas but since they get cold quickly, the office opts for sandwiches.

We also get the salads - served in a large plastic bowl with dressings (herbal ranch is great!) in bottles on the side.

For a catered meal once in a while it's fine - but to  eat often?  Get's old quick.

Quality is slipping a bit at Scoogi's - but hey they've been around for 24 years.
Our server Maria was accomodating and understanding when i sent back my $6 (happy hour special) Fuzzy Navel for "dirty ice".  I think they need to clean their ice machines and filters.

Meanwhile the food was good - my friend had a mediterranean salad loaded with shrimp, scallops, salmon AND crab meat.  (I shoulda got that!)

I had athe $17 early bird special.  House salad was great - the balsamic vinaigrette was delicious.  Entree was just so-so.  Shrimp Scampi over mushy angel-hair.  (Again, I shoulda)  I should have asked for linguine or another type of pasta that doesn't over cook so easily.  The pasta was not only over cooked but over sauced.  Drowing in a lemony/buttery/oily/garlicky scampification.

So sad - as my friend and I loved coming here a few years back.
They need to give the place a good cleaning and tweak the recipes a bit.

Otherwise - solid.
Very lovely hostess.

Expensive but - they have alot of unique items including an egg-boiler that my dad really wanted.  THEY HAD IT (It was $9 and you can get them online for less - but we needed it).

Le Creuset selection is vast and normal prices (for that line).  Staff (male) was friendly enough and gladly took our $9.

Uh Oh.  For the first time ever sub par service and a big mistake (likely all my fault and I acknowledge this) that I caused.

Long story short?  I will not order chirasi here ever again.  (I got the blackbelt kind).
It had an uni on the top (and I forgot to tell them I don;t eat Uni) and usually features eel.  Luckily I remembered to tell the guy "no eel".

The fish was gorgeously fresh - but there were lots of things I don;t like to eat.
Next time I will just order sashimi and specify the fish types I like.

Server (young male - Chuck??) seemed downright annoyed with me (I was on my phone alot on business related calls over lunch).

Probably a fluke (no pun intended).  I will be back again as I truly love it here.  Next time I'll put the damned phone down.  Sorry.  Apologies.

Oh - and I can't wait to try the new spot on 33rd Street.

Alma - you disappointed me very much tonight - but redeemed yourself a bit in the end.

I had long been planning a cocktail party at Alma for (originally) 10-12 colleagues and friends.  I called the restaurant, as I have had 3 parties here before - and although I am aware they do NOT take reservations for Happy Hour/Bar, I wanted them to at least know we were coming at 4:30 so they would not be taken by surprise.

Well, we were taken by surprise when we arrived and the front door was locked - It' was about 4:10 PM.  So I thought - "maybe they don't open until 4:30??" and we went to a cafe and came back at 4:30 - and one of my friends was waiting at the door (since 4:15).  So I called them and they said "We open the bar at 4." and I replied, "Well, we're standing in front of the door".  So they apologized and came and opened the door.

And things went downhill from there (and then came back up).

We were seated and then told that happy hour ($6 Mojitos and Sangria) does not start until 5.  So basically if we ordered any drinks they'd be full price ($9).  Also there are no more 1/2 price apps - so we were stuck paying $12 - $15 for the apps. (Which greatly affected my plans - since I was to be paying for the food and my friends paid for their own drinks).  Oh - and any apps we ordered would not come out until after 5 because the kitchen is not ready until 5.

Finally 5 PM came and we began to drink and eat - and folks came and went (about 16 in our party in all - and we spent HUNDREDS of dollars.).

The handling of the bill was a huge cluster fiasco - I was able to pay for my drinks and the first rounds of apps on one bill - but Janel, our server, put all the other drinks on another (large) bill and then folks who left had to battle it out with cards and cash to figure out who owed what.

So then we had about 8 people remaining and things calmed down.
The manager brought us a small sampler of finger foods (tempura battered baby corn, fried chickpeas and something else) gratis.

A friend and I were still hungry so we split a (delicious) entree of duck breast.  The kitchen split and plated it for us at no charge which was great.

By now, poor Janel - who I really think hated us at the beginning of the night was getting much friendlier.  She brought us a Chocolate cigar (also complimmentary) and we ordered a few dark & stormies and were on our way.

We had fun - but the beginning of the night was very, very rough and we seriously thought about going elsewhere - but stayed since it would have confused the (12-15) other people in our group.

It's a shame really, in 2011 and 2010 I threw similar parties (with 1/2 price apps and split checks) with no issues and great service.

To ask your guests to wait 30 minutes (after waiting 15 at the locked front door) and not honor the Happy hour is poor form.

Next year?  There is NO WAY I will have my party here.
Too rich for my blood.

OK - I have figured out the secret:  Order the pizza for dine-in and eat it there.
For whatever reason the 15 minute car trip home kills it for me, but when I eat there the food tastes much better.

We ordered a special - any 2 pasta dishes for $13.99 (norrmally the chicken parm with spaghetti is $12/99) so my MIL and I each got parmed.  She got chicken and I tried the shrimp.  Both came with salad and a surprisingly tasty fresh hot garlic roll (made with pizza dough.

Is this gourmet?  No.
Fine Dining?  No way.
But for a cheap "I don't wanna cook" weeknight meal - it's fine.

Kevin - the manager was very kind to our party of 4.
And the 8 year old loves the pizza.  (Whatever.)

I agree spot-on with Geoffrey S.  
The Liberte is a sexy, upscale lounge with a French twist.

The happy hour special ($7 for a cocktail - mine was a Tom Collinsmade with Bombay Sapphire - delish) made it better as the drinks are $12 - $14 normally.

Food is just OK - the burger my friend had was a better choice than this odd "bacon and cheese" pastry-pizza tartine like thing.  Way too heavy.  Kinda gross, actually.

Complimentary wasabi peas, salty almonds and wonderful pitted green olives (salt, salt and more salt equals DRINK MORE.)

A fun place to take a date - lots of sexy couples at the bar and some not-so-sexy oldsters like me (LOL).

Skip the tartine.
Grab a drink here from 5 - 7 PM and then get dinner elsewhere.

Loud.
Ridiculously raucous and loud.

Bartender is a sweetheart and acted as our server - but he was spread too thin.

Menu has changed drastically.

Some things are good - mac 'n cheese.  Calimari with sage honey dip.
Some not - salt-crusted, over cooked burger.  (Great toppings though and only .50!) Briche bun (good.)

Awful cheap swill $5 (regularly $9) house prosecco = headache city.

Even the server/bartender warned us NOT to get the bitter, acidic ceviche.

We had a groupon but if not for that - I will not return.

Sorry, Coop.

It's somehow not the same as the store on Chestnut ot Italian Market - but you can get a decent sandwich here - or a breakfast pastry and they have a huge refrigerated case of beverages, yougurt and grab 'n go salads, sides and snacks.

The cooked foods are often dried out and under a heat lamp any time after 12:30.  If you can - get your lunch at 11:30 before the thundering herd.

And after 2:30 it's a ghost town.

I got a cheap (under $200) pair of glasses made back in early 2006 here.  Service took exactly 57 minutes, and prescription seemed accurate.  Frames were average, crappily made mall quality.  Now that I have eye site (and God bless Alain Mikli) I will probably only return in case of emergency.  Oh how jaded and spoiled I've become.

Oh - and if you're in NYC check our Gruen Optika.

Since I am now working about a block away I will be going here more often.  Today I got a burrito bowl with chicken and it was, indeed, good ($7.50 including tax) - but when I asked for guacamole on it she told me it would have been $2.00 more - WHAT????

Their guac is good - but not $2.00 good.

If I am feeling less lazy and MUST have a burrito - I'll trek down Chestnut Street a few more blocks to Qdoba.

OK, call me a peasant - but I liked my Naked burrtio (with the same mix of ingrediants) at Qdoba better than here.  And it was a bit cheaper - and a LOT more caloric.

El Fuego has done a great job re-doing the space with classy stools & a HUGE flat screen TV which was tuned to ESPN-HD.  

As I alluded to, I ordered a Bowl-burrito with Steak, Black Beans, Rice and Guac ($2.25 extra for guac by the way) and the mild pico-type salsa.
It was very tasty - but the guac was LOADED with lime juice to the point of  tasting sour.  (I guess all that extra lime juices helps retain the vibrant green color of the guac.

I dunno.  I think I will be back - as I enjoy the shorter lines and less frenetic pace of El Fuego - but Qdoba is a hard addiction to break.

I am glad they are open, though.  WE need more choices in this area.  (By the way - they are not at 24 & Chestnut.  The address seems wrong to me.)  They are at 21 and Chestnut.

Oh - and somehow they wangled a liquor license.  They serve beers and FROZEN MARGARITAS.  I couldn't have one - as I had to return to work - but one lady nearby was drinking one and it looked fetching.

P.S.  The also serve a lime-chicken-ginger soup which I would like to try one day.  (You can't get THAT at Qdoba.)
Yup.  In future I'll book vacations myself.

My parent's have friends who just LOVE it here - but I for whatever reason, do not.  It's ok.  2.5 stars at best (I gave 3 out of a feeling of generosity.)

I want to love it - as I love deli food and jewish-style deli specifically.

But something here just doesn't quite do it for me. I am still missing the New Yawk and Miami delis of my youth.

I am, however, glad they are here (or else there'd be NO jewish delis nearby) and glad they have the basics like Lox, Knishes, Kasha and Pastrami on Rye.

A good grocery store to stock up on non-perishables and bulk items.  They often have very low prices on items like tomato sauce, soda, cereal and other staples.  When I was in college I would stock up here - pasts for 3 lbs for $1.00 and other good deals.

This is NOT the place to go for yuppie-prepared foods nor is it strong on fresh produce.  Yes, they have produce - but alot is pre-bagged.

If you are on a tight budget, I'd definitely come here - but you won't be able to get everything you need here.  Leave room for Acme or Wegman's for the gourmet and fresh items.

Menawhile, now I am all embarrassed, because a friend of mine is super-close friends with the husband & wife team who own the place. She swears that they "Rock".

That may be so - but why would they leave the doors to their shop wide open and nobody was there?  We even called out for them a bunch of times.

Gorgeous flowers (Fresh cut in the coolers and dried and potted out on display).

I would really like to give them a try - so we'll stop back again and see if we can get better service next time.  (Or ANY service at all.)

this is for the golf shop and course.
The course gets crowded on spring weekends - so consider golfing mid week (if you can) to play through more quickly.

Pretty course and a friendly well-run shop.

This is DELI-sushi and I don't trust it.  
And I don't really like it.
I am tempted to give 2 stars but I will be nice and err on the 3 star side of 2.5 stars.

But in a pinch I have come here to get a quick roll or order of sitting-under-a-warner gyoza.

I mostly grab a green tea in a can, a cucumber salad (very sweet and good by the way) and run back to the office.

It's fast-food Japanese-American folks.  And that's that.  Beats the heck outta pizza or burgers for me.

Yes, it's a chain - but IMO it's wayyyyyy better than taco hell.
Be careful though - the calorie counts are ENORMOUS.  Try the Burrito Bol (no tortilla) to save 300 PLUS calories off the bat.

I also am a Qdoba fan.  (I find people usually pledge allegiance to one or the other.)  and I hate fast food - but Chipotle & Qdoba are actually good tasting to me.  You just MUST alter the burrito fixings to try and salvage the nutritional content.  (No cheese, No Sour cream, etc.)
Seasons is a safe choice for pizza. My 12 year old likes it here. Order a whole pie for the freshest taste. Slices are not recommended and (except for lunch) often not available.

OK Pizza. GREASY (like a quart of oil) Chicken Marsala (won;t be getting it again).  Side salad had fresh greens and cucumber but the 2 grape tomatoes were rotten.

Not impressed, but they are nearby so we've already been there twice and will likely be back.

Until we can find better.

A cutesy pink & purple paradise for tweens (and younger) to get prettied up (tarted up?) and parade around on a mock runway for a birthday extravaganza.

My daughter and I went here to look around just as 8-10 screaming, giggling, bubbly little girls with BAD updos ran by on the way to the shocking pink limo.  A birthday party?  Fo sho!

They have a full service salon for girls (including hair, nails - pedicure thrones, make your own lip gloss, the works) and TONS of overpriced sparkley merch for eager 8 year old fingers to grasp at.

Hold on to your wallet, kids!  (PARENTS, too)

Parties for 8 kids START at $250.

3 or maybe 4 stars.  I actually liked Vinny T's - for a CHAIN faux-talian they are OK in my book.  They were very accomodating to our little daughter who loved her ziti and meatballs.  I'd go back.  Way better than Olive Garden and less obnoxious than Bucca di Fake-o.

Manager was very nice.
Parking is a sham - meters are broken.

Talbots has conservative (bordering on old lady) clothes for the suburban housewife.  Event the Center City branch has these "classic" types of clothing.  Tailored, neat and clean.

I almost never buy anything here unless its on a sale.

My mama would approve.
No issues - just the same as any Jimmy John's - all cold subs and as they say "Freaky Fast" service.  $6.50 and out the door.

Oh my!  Hooray for Jose - he's on a roll row!

Garces Trading Company (a market/coffee bar and rest-o in one) offers chi-chi cheeses, wines, coffees, pastries and charcuterie/olives etc.

The olive oil tasting area is amazing!

Not sure how the sit-down food is - but it looks lovely.  Tried a chocolate madeleine and it was a bit dry.  Quel Dommage.

The macaroons and lemon drop cookies are heavenly, though.

I wish y'all much success!  Foodie heaven!

I went back for one and one reason only - I somehow managed to get a $50 eversave (or groupon or some deal) for five bucks.

That's right.  $5 for $50 worth of food.
So I went back - with the same friend and we had a much better (and nearly free - we tipped based on the real total) experience.

The $5 'mac 'n cheese (they use ditalini - really is good.  The calamari is also light, crispy and served with a honey dip.  Sweet!  Also the candied bacon on the bacon 'n eggs (deviled) app is really tasty stuff.

Salad?  (I got the greek wedge) Just ok.
Grilled Tuna was a better choice - served with broclli rabe and GIANT gigante beans.

Food seemed better tonight, service worse, loudness better (It was Tuesday - not Friday).

Still not a holy grail - but for $5???  Who could resist.

Get the mac 'n cheese.  It's gooooood.

Capri's Pizza - now Villa Capri (along with Nat's) was nearly the only game in down "back in the day".  The Mannino Family (who I think still owns and operates Capri) added the dining room and  classic Italian favorites on the Menu.

The location is great - Central Doylestown - and the prices are a bit high.  On weekends they sometimes have a pianist which is a nice touch.

My brother's all time favorite is the tortellini bolognese - which is a generous porion with a rich meaty sauce.  The Chicken & Veal dishes (I am partial to Francese) are quite good too.

I stayed here for a 2 day convention.
The hotel room was fine and our front desk clerk, Lincoln, was a doll.

We also got 2 free bottles of water in our room so the next day we asked for 2 more - not realizing they charge for them $2 a bottle.  (I can easily drink 6-8 bottles a day.)

Not the end of the world but I would have liked to have known.

Also the catering service for our group was just AWFUL.
"Cod" fish with mango salsa was so fishy and old tasting and many of the pre-sliced cakes on display were dry and old.

Not a wonderful hotel but not bad to stay over for a night.  (Loaded with families going to Sesame Place).
Just avoid having any catered events here.

Italian Delight really does make a nice pizza.  Not a holy grail - but they offer alot of choices like Tomato Pie, galic knots (that are not too greasy) and a really crispy chicken (or veal - real veal) parm sandwich.  NOTE:  We went again on May 9, 2009 and spilt a chicken parm sandwich (HUGE) and it was terrific.

We go there on occaision with my parents and 4 year old - and they treat us well.  And the 5 (or 6) of us can get out of there for very little money.

Can't wait to try the pasta dishes.

NOTE to parents;  They do not have any milk or juices - only sodas and "junk" beverages - so bring your own.

This mock-meat vegetarian chinese (is kosher, too) has take-out, delivery ($20 minimum) and friendly services.  That's a the good part.
Also the pineapple"chicken" is one of my little girl's faves.

The appetizers are a grease-fest.  The stuffed eggplant with inedible.
The spring-rolls were only fair (might be better to have these dine-in.) BUT the leek dumplings were delectable.

Hot & Sour soup was nice and spicy - but had a strange "ketchup-y" sweet note to it that I did not care for.

We will come here when our daughter demands it, but for now we shall stick to Square on Square for the BEST hot & sour around.

We had a solid 3 (maybe even 4) star experience for an early-bird dinner last night.  We ordered the 3 course special (which is a good value - and much less expensive than the $18 - $24 entrees.

For $14.95 - $16.95 you get a choice of soup or salad (a very boring, but fresh, lettuce house salad), entree (I had a tasty chicken parm, my friend got the crab cakes with potatoes & asparagus), and dessert (she had cheesecake and I had a decent freshly-filled cannolli).

Our server, David, was charming and attentive.

Considering that there are not too many options in this area, Scoogi's is a decent coice for a lunch, dinner or "early-bird".

Full bar - and $5.00 Burgers on Wednesdays during the summer.

What?  A line?  A super, duper long line - on a Saturday afternoon at the Springfield mall.

These people must love their pretzels.

They're OK (for junk food) but so not worth a 20 minute wait.

Anyhow - Auntie Anne's is keeping the malls of America in business. (And airports, train stations and other places).  The pretzel and lemonade obsession continues.
Carb-a-licious.

This place is just weird.  It's like a walk-up counter and sells Hotdogs, Lemonade & Brisket sandwiches.  Service is fast and prices are low.

No9t a holy grail - but OK in a pinch.

I've actually had decent experiences using the trolleys - especially when the Blue line (Market/Frankford El) ain't workin'.

I take the trolleys from 15th Street to 390th usually and not much else - plus during rush hour there are more of the trolley than there are of the El.
And you can get out to West Philly easily.

they also have a blue flashing "warning light" to let you know not to go down there if the light is flashing.  (Wish the Broad Street line had something similar.).

I am a BIG proponent of public transportantion and while it is easy (oh, so very easy) to criticize SEPTA - I think the trolley line it a great, great thing.

Please improve the Orange and Blue lines and clean up the stations.
And make token machines (better yet - switch to a swipe-card system like every other modern city {suppoedly in the works}) available at all stations.  (I can not believe the Race/Vine station has no place to buy tokens - but that is the subject for another review().

the green line?  It's running pretty well.

Needed some sneakers and didn't feel like paying $100.  Mission accomplished with my brand new Nike's from Finish Line ($70) and a cheap "Pastry" T-Shirt (Pastry is Russell Simmon's daughters Angela and Vanessa's destined-to-fail clothing line) for $6.99.

Sales person was surprisingly helpful and the store was nearly empty.

City Sports is a nicer store, but I scored cheap kicks here and that suits me fine.

SUIT UP!!!

This City Nails is the best of them.  It is relatively safe and me and my 5 year old get manis and polish changes here.  I am still leery about pedis anywhere in Philly.  (Tierra Mia is safe, as is Rescue, but the nail joints in general are not good for pedis in Philly.)

Market Way flowers has changed hands numerous times over the years - and I really can't comment accurately about the current management.  Back int he '80's, however, they were very reputable.

In the mid nineties I wired an arrangement to my parents (who lived in Doylestown) and Market Way fulfilled the order.  And it was disappointing as the flowers, especially the gerbera daisies, did not last as long as we'd expected.  They did, however replace the bouquet free of charge.

I am not sure how to comment so I will award 3 stars as we experienced both highs and lows from dealing with Market Way Flowers.  (This is one of the few flower shops in D-town that I did NOT work for!)

OK, I hate to rain on everyone's Tinto Parade - and maybe I am overly critical - or maybe I just went too early in the game (I went 1 week after  they opened).  I am writing this review months later.  Or MAYBE I am just a jaded ex-NYC chick who can't tell good food when she tastes it anymore?

But, I was distinctly underwhelmed by the dark decor, lackluster service and overhyped food at Tinto.  Yes, there is true Galician cuisine to be had here - which is a rare and refreshing change.  The selection of cheeses and pork products (alas, i don't eat piggie meat) are awe inspiring - as are the tremendous prices for the small, small plates.  I do commend Jose for finding true authentic regional Spanish specialties like Membrillo and other accompanyments.  For that you should really get the 4th star.

For lunch - by myself I had the $16.00 grilled lamb chops (whic, indeed, were grilled to perfection - but HECK - I coulda made that at home.)  I also had the White asparagus gazpacho - which was a true disappointment.  It was far too rich - almost like eating a bowl of cream.  The pluche was the best part - microgreens - the only gree to be found in my $30.00 lunch (with NO BEVERAGE.)

Sorry Jose - but for the master that you are - I should not have to pay $30.00 for a single lunch *(no dessert, no drink) to sit at an elevated (and un-comfortable for short people), hard wooden stool, at cramped tiny tables.

Service was OK - but so NOT friendly.  I cam in a 12 noon on the dot and had the place nearly all to myself.

I have not since returned.  I grill a damn fine lambchop myself.

I wanted to love it here - and in theory I do - but in reality - I just CAN'T.
P.S.  If you are Kosher-ish or don't eat Pork or Shellfish - you may want to pass.

I have been here twice over the last 3 years.
Got my latte and got out.

No issues - but not a HG (Holy Grail) either.

Meh to OK.  Decent pizza - especially if you order a whole, fresh pie.
Chicken parm was deepfried tenders with sauce and cheese.  FAIL.
Spaghetti was well cooked (not over cooked).

Fries, chicken - basically anything that went into the deep fryer was over-fried and too dark.  Perhaps the oil was too hot today?

Anyhow the kiddo liked it so we were ok with it.

$34.20 including tax for lunch for 3.

A small, family-run shop.  They stock "the usuals" (roses, lilies, carnations, baker fern, leather leaf, bear grass) and can special order other species.

Timely and pleasant service.

A little pricey for balloons, though - latex ballons were over $1.00 each.  Something insane.  I did not buy any for my daughter.

They were STOCKED UP for mother's day (2009) and had tons of mini carnation bouquets for last minute pick ups.

A fun place to browse around for pet-gear and treats while on South Street.  Not a holy grail by any means - but they are there when you need them.  Also prices are a little higher than in the big chains like PetCo and MonsterPets.

Small, cramped, crowded and even more "picked over" than the "usual" TJ MAxx - for instance the one in Gateway Shopping Plaza inn Chesterbrook is much nicer.

Still, a good place to go for "seconds" and designer bags, accessories, fashions and cosmetics (great place for gift items) at a reduced cost.

Glad it's here - but not the greatest TJ Maxx ever.
Avoid pre-Christmas - this was my first mistake.
I will come back in February.

Honestly?  Way too expensive for what it is - especially after going to the National Aquarium in Baltimore and the Monterrey Bay Aquarium in CA, but it's still a great experience especially if you have children from ages 5 - 9.

The Penguins are always fun and the area with the touch pool (wash your hands!) has a friendly ray.

Beautiful to look at but stinky - especially the hippo exhibit.

The Melrose has renovated its booths and light fixtures (and ladies room - hooray) since I last went.

We (party of 6) had a nice breakfast here yesterday including omelettes, pancakes and all the usuall suspects.

Our pleasant waitress Janice went on break half way thru and our new waitress (Christina??) was even nicer

Not bad!

Slight upgrade for tonight's dinner here - my 6 year old LOVES it here - and I am a sucker so, of course, we went.

She knew immediately what she wanted to get.
Lobster & Crab mac 'n cheese.  $24 smackaroos.  Ouch.  Thank god it tasted really good tonight.  Sometimes, I swear, it tastes fishy.

I got a $9 plain-ole hamachi maki.  6 tiny pieces.  Ugh.   For that price Doma or even Morimoto are a better deal for freshness as well as price.

Dessert, of course, was the small $13 chocolate fondue.  This time we were smart enough to ask for "no melon" (who dips melon in chocolate?).  The fondue itself is delectable and the small is big enough for 3 people easily.  This time, also, the pound cake was not stale.  Thank G-d!

Service was just OK.  The owner/server (maybe she's not the owner but she was acting owner-ish) kindof ignored us and seemed annoyed when my little one dropped a piece of penne on the floor (though I can't say I blame her -but you could at least FAKE that you were happy to see an actual customer on a DEAD Monday at 5 PM.)

My little one and I listened to the friendly bartender count bottles of flavored vodkas in preparation for restaurant week.  

Finally more customers came - a couple in their 40/50's were MAKING OUT at the bar at 6 PM.  We left soon after.

Oy vey.

Verdict remians:  prices too high, for food that is just OK and COULD be stellar but seems as faded as the decor.

I am not a big fan of four-bucks, but - Chrissy - I know that lady of which you write.  She is such a nice lady that I have to give this four-bucks 3 whole stars.

I don't drink the coffee drinks but a light-ice 2 pump classic green tea lemonade is an occasional treat when my paycheck will allow it.

I am stuck between a 3 and a 4.
I came solo for an early lunch on a DEAD Saturday at 12 noon.

I asked for the special "drunken beef shortribs" (There was a big sign in the window $14.95 for dinner $7.50 for lunch but was told there was no lunch portion available.

The menu seemed old-school and limited, so I went with Moo Goo Gai Pan - and to my relief it was excellent.  So good, in fact, that the leftovers I brough home from my hefty $8.95 lunch portion were gobbled up by my 7 year old.

So I might bump them up to 4 stars once I get a taste of some other items, but so far it's a solid 3.

FYI - good, but greasy, fried wonton skins and duck sauce on every table.  GUILT-inducing yumminess.

4 stars for nostalgia and 2 stars for how it is today averages out to a 3 star mall experience.

Time for an overhaul, me-thinks.

Went in yesterday and hit BIG - a Tommy Hilfiger Dress for $40 and a Calvin Klein Dress - also for $40.  Restrooms are filthy, dressing room attended was not a happy camper, but I managed to get in and out - tried on 8 dresses and bought 2.

Not bad!

Gotta love that "no sales tax on clothing" in PA thing!

Wow there sure are alot of La Toltecas in DE.  We stopped for a quick lunch (and we were famished) at 11:45 AM on a Sunday on our way home to Philly.

DH enjoyed his Toleca Enchiladas.  Chicken burritos/enchiladas topped with white cheese sauce and green tomatillo sauce.  He borrowed the spicy sauce that came with my fish tacos to give it extra kick.  It was NOT a spicy dish.

I had the aforementioned fish tacos that were great but boring.  No veggies - only fish on tortillas (sauce and guac along side, but not enough).  So I asked the waiter (very nice and attentive man) to get me some lettuce & tomotao - which he did and then proceeded to harge us $3.99 for them - the price of a side salad.

Listen, had I known this, I would have ordered a salad and gotten more guac and pico.

This was a big buzz kill! (And we hadn't even had any of the ga-zillion margaritas they offer).

We enjoyed our (first basket free) of chips & salsa, and DH had a diet coke (with 1 free refill).

It was reasonably priced and reasonable quality.  If I lived near here I MIGHT return but I bet there are better choices.

When I grocery shop in Doylestown I usually go to Giant, Acme or Weis'.
Of the 3 Acme is my least favorite choice.

Meanwhile, it has been remodeled since I reviewed it in 2011 and I was able to get in and out (that parking lot - OMG - on a weekend it is cray-cray) relatively quickly.

They have everything you need.

Do I love it here?  No, my first choice for a chain supermarket is Giant in D-town.  But it is super-centrally located and I do come here from time to time.  (Weis' is one block away.)

It really depends on what you order.
Beef and Broccoli?  Great.
Beef with String Beans (special)?  Great.

Shrimp and Snow peas?  Gelatinous goo.
Shrimp toast?  Burnt.

I am going back to beef & broc. Every time I try something else I regret it.

Also - no ice, no water unless you BUY a bottle.
I try, try, try to remember to bring my water with me.  This is SUCH a take out place.  A lady came here to dine in with 2 little kids and asked for a cup of tea and they served it to her in a tupperware soup container.

Decent Chinese food, take out is the best way.
NOT a fine dining experience, or even a mediocre one.

We are big theatre supporters and wanted to support Hedgerow, however the Production we saw of "The Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy" was just not very good.

The parking lot is a mess - no lines - so you just park "anywhere you can".

The actual theatre was OK - odd seating - long benches.
Free coffee and water (from a cooler) at intermission.

Amateurish.
Just OK.

Arden Theatre or People's Light are so much nicer.
But it's close to our home so we'll be back - if there is a production we WANT to see.

Chekov's Uncle Vanya?  Not so much.

We were here for a private event and it RAINED.  Even so, this was a fun venue - and nice scenery on the pier - but the food is "average" bar food.

Drinks were strong and good.

My good friends go to this Chili's and took me there for dinner.  The 2 for 20 is the real value here - if you happen to like the food.

It's just not my thing.
Food is 2 stars at best.
Service here was good the evening we went - and we were on a tight timeline and were able to get in and out quickly on a slow Monday night.

The "loaded" french fry appetizer was good.  The steak was over-salted and over cooked.  Corn on the cob was surprisingly sweet and good (did they add sugar??).

Meanwhile, I am grateful to my friends for their generosity - but Chili's is just OK.

It's a Wendy's,  If you've been to one - you've seen them all.  This one is fairly clean and has a decent clientele - being that it is located in the Doylestown Shopping Center.  The only reason we even go here is to placate the 4 year old who simply must have nuggets.

Whatever.

I have been to far scuzzier Wendy's.  I loathe fast food.
BLAH.  3 stars is pretty damned generous on my part.

Listened to XPN alot growing up and in college.  Nowadays it just doesn't cut it for me, but for a college station it's pretty well run.  

For real.

It's old-faithful Acme in Doylestown.  The parking lot is a ZOO and the produce can really variable from great to "you're kidding?".  Staff are generally friendly and lines move quickly.  It can get crazy crowded on weekends - and now the SuperFresh of D-town is gone (yup - the recession at work) we are left with this or Genuardi's.

So acme - for 40 years we've known and loved/liked/hated you and now you're nearly all we've got!!!

Came here for the amazingly cheap breakfast with a friend while we were both unemployed.  We got a big pot of coffee and 2 breakfast plates of panckaes (she had bacon, I had one egg - man, one scrambled egg is kinda small, but when you're broke?...)

Enjoyable food, very cheap and they let us sit and linger for a while.

Luxurious?  No.  But it got the job done!

Had lunch here with a colleague and it was just OK.
She had a $7 cheese quesadilla and I had a $14 shrimp and pineapple salad.  Both were fine but the service was really weird.

They were nice but kind of ignored us.
We were on a tight time frame (lunch hour on a work day) so we really needed to pay our bill and go.

Not a bad place but not mind blowing either.

Kinda boring, actually.  You wait and wait (timed ticket entry plus a security tent) and then hear a lecture and then see 3 rooms.

Whoopie!

But it's HISTORY so you kinda have to do it.  I did it as a kid 30 years ago and did it again today with my 11 year old.

Done.

Got take-out out of desperation during the Covid19 Scare and thank goodness they were open, but I do NOT recommend take out from here.  The food gets cold (not their fault) and sushi gets warm (again not their fault) and its just so much better eating there.

But in any case we had a birthday celebration during a "lock down" so this was as swanky as we could get.

The salmon tartar is always a winner.
The beet salad (my go-to fave) was honestly not good.  The beets had a bitter taste to them.  Odd. I love this salad and order it many times but this time was a fail.

My husbands crab and cream cheese maki were cold and a bit soggy by the time we brought the food home.

You gotta dine in.
For the high prices to be at all worth it do NOT take out.
Once the Covid thing is over hopefully things will go back to normal.

THANK YOU FOR BEING OPEN at all.

My experience at this location of Jared was fine - the place was nearly empty which surprised me as it was the week before Christmas. They had a ton of staff available.  This seems like they focus on wedding/engagement rings.

I was seeking something very specific - a 14K (or platinum but budget won;t allow it) charm shaped like a number 3.  Believe it or not they had Pandora charms in 2, 4 & 6 but no 3.

In any case I may or may not return if I need something but I tend to buy online or even on ebay.

I will not be rushing back here - even though the service was great (I came early before the 12:15 hoards arrived) and the dumpling sampler ($14 for 8 dumplings - 2 each of 4 varieties) was great.

I got dan dan noodles to go.
What a disappointment,  Never again for that dish (Go to Han's for the real Dan Dan).  Sauce was awful.

Beautiful decor, pleasant service, overpriced "meh" food. I spent $26 for lunch (after tax and tip) and no beverages, no dessert.  Yikes.

Such a shame.
I had no issues - there was a long line but they quickly opened another register.  i did NOT have any prescriptions filled - just ducked quickly in and out to buy a few things.

This is the Saladworks in Liberty Place - and the lines get long but move quickly.  Everyone here works fast and constantly making salds, soups, pastas and sandwiches.  I usually get the Cobb Salad with a few substitutions. You can also do a "Create Your Own" - and it's usually around $10 - for a large salad and a roll.

A good choice when I need something in a hurry and the line is not too bad.

A step above Olive Garden and not as good as Carraba's in the scheme of faux-talian chains.

Our server Sean was kind and attentive at our casual business luncheon here last week.  Today's server, Meghan was just as nice.

My colleagues & I each ordered 1 soft drink and 1 entree each.  Some have "make your own" pasta - for $9.99 (Salad additional).  I had a delicious lunch portion of the chicken with artichokes & mushrooms in a (fattening) lemon sauce (Full of butter or oil - but tasty none-the-less).
I have also tried the "Antonio's Rigatoni"  (Rigatoni with braised beef - tender and delicious - in a tomatoe sauce with caramelized onions.) which is really good.  I have it with cremini mushrooms added.

My colleague's chicken parm looked good - but not spectacular - which is just how Romano's is.

Good but not spectacular.

Oh - and the Olive Oil they serve for dipping on each table is pure bitterness in a bottle.  It's cheap garbage. Please consider upgrading your olive oil.  It is literally inedible.  The bread (which comes out hot as a small square loaf) - is pretty good.

Desserts were very inexpensive ($1.99 - $3.99) but we were too full to partke (BIG portions even at lunchtime).

Old-school Chinese in ZERO atmosphere.
BBQ spare ribs were big and meaty.
Mango Chicken was awful - too much gloppy ketchup-based sauce
Steamed Chicken dumplings had a delicious wrapper and MSG-laden filling.

I won't rush back - there are far better places, but for a post-flower show respite with the fam, this was just fine - and inexpensive.
The renovations have REALLY helped this creepy old station to look alot nicer.  There are still a ton of creepy homelss folks hanging out here, though.  I try to go to Hamilton instead.

Our company sponsored the truck - with a limited menu - to provide lunch for 2 hours (12 noon - 2 PM) for over 200 people.  The choices were 1/2 a cheese steak (with our without onions), a crispy chicken sandwich (with cheddar cheese sauce and bacon, if desired) or a falafel and grain bowl to satisfy the vegetarian crowd.

I opted for the cheese steak and after about a 6 minute wait it arrive - the meat was cold.
Meanwhile the sauce was warm (Melted American) and the fries were piping hot.

Excellent service and OK food.
Not orgasmic, and no holy grail but for a corporate event, it was fine. (for "free"?  Bring it on!)
I would try a different item next time - the chicken sandwiches looked better than the cheese steak - so maybe I just ordered wrong?

#GratefulButHonest

Met up with an ex-yelper for a quick lunch today.  Had the $5.99 lunch combo - Tomato Bisque Soup (very good) 1/2 Chicken Avocado wheat wrap (good, but not awesome) and a terrific tall Cafe au lait.

This place is a good choice to get away form the crowds and relax for while.  It's very 3 star.

So I picked up my car and the interior windows were NOT done - all smudged and smeared (my dog leaves nose prints).  So the manager said I could bring it back next week and they will redo it.

We shall see...

Customer service so far is good, but for the high cost ($17 after tip/tax) - for INTERIOR ONLY) I would prefer that it be done correctly the first time.

I will report back after next week.
I want to LOVE IT, as it is so convenient and the guys seem hard working and friendly.

Closing for good/Going out of Business 12/22.
Everything at least 50% off - selling down to the bare walls.

I really, really, really wanted to give Happy Rooster more stars - especially since I know the chef - and his family and he is a really great guy and has re-vamped the menu.

The menu itself is very nice - we especially enjoyed the asparagus app - with a luscious poached egg on top and truffle-infused pecorino cheese (Oh yes, and Bacon.).  It harkened to a traditional French preparation - with a lemony twist.

I also really liked the house-made gnocchi, but the oxtail on top of it was very oily (even moreso - and yes, i know - oxtail is not a "light and healthy choice".)  That said, they offer an app & entree portion and I should have gotten the smaller app portion.  I took about 1/3 of it home.  It was very tasty.  (Just a wee bit oilier than I'd like.)

My friend had the (again house-made) agnolloti - which were good, but not spectacular.  After eating the asparagus salad - the sauce for the agnollotti (which also has butter and lemon in it) seemed a but redundant.  Maybe that was our fault for a bad ordering choice??  In any case, the fresh fava beans were EXCELLENT.  (I'm a fan of teeny-beanies!)  

The 2 (male) bartenders who also served us were prompt and couteous.  Alas, my chef-friend, had already left for the night - but he is doing a great job in turning this place around.

A vast improvement on the menu front.

Dinner for 2 ran us just over $50 - but we did not order drinks or dessert.  (Alas, no room for the home-made zeppole. )  Maybe next time.

This salon is featured on the stye networks show Split Ends.
It is located in a "Strip mall" type setting.  It is a busy, high energy salon.

They offer highlights, color and cuts.  The stylists all look very professional and wera high heels.

Not bad - but not great either.  The best part?  The super cheap price for the generous lunch special.  Mine came with Mediocre Miso, a tasty entree (Tofu with Eggplant in garlic sauce) and brown rice.  For a side I chose green salad (bad idea, and I should have known better) which was iceberd with 2 tomato slices and 1 cucumber slice.  Lame-o!  Next time (if there is one) I'll try the mushrooms.

Service was fine - efficient and quick.  Water was refilled promptly without asking (score).

OK, Maybe this place is 4 star foor/service but the 2 star decor needs a refresher pronto!

Roosevelt Memorial Park is a Jewish Cemetary and it is NOT closed - I attended a funeral there a few days ago.

I also attended a funeral there 5 years ago and sat under the SAME blue awning.

The rabbi officiating was very good and the service was a nice commemoration of a life well-lived.

Yes, it is a crowded, old cemetary - so maybe it lists as closed because maybe there are no new plots available?

Wow- nobody reviewed this?  I am close to giving them 4 stars.  I enjoyed my chicked dish and chatting with the chefs in the semi-open kitchen.

My husband, however hated it here and so we never have gone back.  he got a Pizza Margarita which was slightly burnt and not worth the high price in his opinion.

I would definitely go back there though - with a friend - not with DH!

OK I split the difference and gave 3 stars.  here's why:

Food selection - 5 stars
Beer selection - 5 stars
Food quality - 4 stars
Service - 1 star
Prices - 1 star - soooooo expensive!
Cashiers are rude and inconsiderate.

I dropped over $50 on random groceries and they rang it up incorrectly and swiped my card.  They then asked me to pay for the 2 items they forgot to ring up in cash.

It was a nightmare.  I basically spent $54 on a dozen eggs, an apple, an orange, a bowl of cut fruit, a chef salad, a turkey wrap, some hummus, a quart of OJ, 2 boxes of raspberries, a container of mixed nuts, a container of dried apricots, a package of sliced organic cheese.

$54!  Ack!!!!!  For one small bag of groceries.

That said - I am glad they were there when I needed them.  I paid the price for the convenience.  And for organic.

We ordered 3 large Cheese pies and 2 orders of Cinnamon Sticks (pizza dough with cinnamon sugar on top with icing). It was a veitable carb-fest for "Take your youngins to work" day.

Kids liked it - adults tolerated it.

Decent food - but not a holy grail.

3 stars is being pretty generous - but this location is better than the one in University City (but not by much.)

Yuck.  I really loathe chain restaurants and Chili's is no exception.  The one nice this about this Chili's is it's proximity to the Convention Center and the universally cheap and greasy burgers and other fried foods are the same at any Chili's nation wide.  My friend loves the Southwest eggroll app.

It's not so clean in here - and the place is run by illetrates and teenagers.

I guess it beats TGI Friday's - but again, not by much.

Wow - no reviews for Oggi?  They are pretty well known salon.
Haircuts are pricey.  They also offer single process color and highlights.
They seem to have CLOSED.

Downgrade.  Went to Lamberti's for abusiness lunch.
Service was too slow and food was just MEH.  I had the flounder lunch special which was swimming in an oily sauce.  The asaparagus pieces were a drab olive green and obviously over cooked.

Not great, guys.

Still - delicious bread that comes with the meal.

Could use a good cleaning, but the owner (a one-man show as far as i can tell) is very patient and kind with the kids.
A good assortment of "retro" candies, too.

Fun - but not a HG.

Pretty pricey for what they are - but the cap-sleeve Tee here fits me well and is very cute.  Certain articles they make should NOT be worn by anyone with any extra pounds - so if you are not a super model, steer clear of the skirts and ultra short shorts.

You can get AA stuff at lots of non AA locations.

Wait a second?  AA?  My name is Karen F. and I'm a tee-shirt-a-holic!
("Hi, Karen!")

I had a decent experience at the Wayne outpost of Blue Mercury.  Picked up some Caudalie and Kiehl's goodies plus a sample of MorrocanOil mask.  All wrapped nicely.

Pricey?  Yes.
Snooty?  Yes.
Still shopping here?  For now, yes.

My husband and I had dinner here last night.  We walked in at about 4:55 PM so there was NO crowd yet at all.  Our server Morgan was friendly and EXCELLENZT.

The food was better than I expected.  I am not a chain restaurant person, so I expected the worst.  The food was actually pretty good. 3 stars.

I had the "special" summer salad which had strawberries, grapes, mandarin oranges and pecans in it.  It was like dessert!   

My ribeye was overly salty - which was a shame as it was grilled PERFECTLY.  Next time (if there is a next time - I am in no hurry to rush back here) tell them "No prairie dust" - the salt seasoning they put all over the steak.

I also has a sweet potato (minus the cinnamon sugar topping they usually put on it) which was great - but it's pretty hard to mess up a plain, baked sweet potato.

Prices were high for a chain - but low for a steakhouse.  It ain't the Palm - but it's OK.

3 stars.

OK.

Not nearly as bad as it coulda been.

This place is getting a little "old" in more ways than one.
When I first landed in Philly - about 3 year ago, I was looking to find a replacement for my old NYC sushi spot.

Fuji Mountain, at that time, was close to my office and offered a profusion of rools.  The Sunshine and Florida rolls are really, very tasty.

Now the prices are up and quality is just OK.  I did order a lovely Toro-lover's platter which was a special and it was a good value and had lots of toro.  2 pieces of Chu, 2 pieces of  "O" and a negi-toro roll.  I still dream about that one!

But lately when I go for lunch and sit (solo) at the bar, I am not treated really well.  Seems odd to me.

Anyhow, I have also taken to Shiroi Hana as of late. Even more recently, I have discovered Vics - right nearby.
I guess Fuji Mountain is just not for me anymore.  There are better places to go now.

The food was surprisingly really GOOD for a chain and the decor was nice enough.  Service was good as well - but the noise level?  Deafening and the place was loaded with kids - mine included.

The veggie salad is great - and it's enormous - 2 of us shared it easily with leftovers.

And for $7 a slice - the ginormous piece of Red Velvet Cheesecake (sooooo good) was enough for 3.

This was (shockingly) my first EVER visit here - and I really liked it.  Not a healthy place, as Michelle C. says - but tasty grub for sure and not too pricey.  (Save for the cheesecake.)

I am only rating the facilities for conferences/banquets.  I stayed in a different (cheaper) hotel overnight while attending a conference here.

The facilities themselves are 4 star and the hotel provides a variety of room sizes and configurations for meetings.  However, the plated meals were absolutely bland and awful.  Chicken was dry and bathed in a (jarred) marinara sauce and an overly sweet balsamic reduction.  Brown and wild rice was overly salted - to the point of inedibility.  The best thing?  Steamed asparagus.  Cheesecake for dessert was frozen for sure.

Gives a whole new meaning to the "rubber chicken" dinner.

In the mean time, the meetings themselves were fine - and water/cold drinks were provided for during breaks.

No major issues, but based on the food I sure as heck would NOT have my wedding here. Or any other event where guests want GOOD tasting food.

Solid, nostalgic, "traditional" Chinese American food - with BIG portions and great values for eat-in at lunch (weekdays lunches are 5.95 - 6.95).

Lunch for 3 of us WITH TIP was $24.  Wow.

Friendly service and clean comfortable digs.

The Moo Shu Chicken for lunch comes with 2 fresh pancakes.
My 6 year old enjoyed her steamed "light & healthy" chicken and broccoli.

It's not Asian Fusion, It's not "modern" Chinese, it's old-school combo platters with white or fried rice (which was freshly made and good, by the way - loaded with pork and egg!).

NICE!

I had a manicure here many months ago.  It was not particularly memorable nor was it unpleasant.  It was just middle of the road.

There are better - and worse - places nearby.

It was, indeed, quick. And they are accessible for walkins.

Nicely laid-out, large, chain-style pet store with supplies for dogs, cats and small animals.
They had the Eukeneuba my pup eats - but the price was just average - not low and not high.
Good in a pinch.

They also have a grooming area.

Seems better than "big chains" like pet smart and petco.
More and more I order dog food on line. (Especially if shipping is free).

The best place for inexpensive bagged dog food?  Newtown Square's Seed & Feed - it's small and dirty but so cheap!!!!

This is a review of the Le Nails on the STREET LEVEL of the Gallery Mall near the 10th Street entrance.

I had a mani pedi ($35 for both, $12 mani, $25 pedi) yesterday and "Lisa" at table 1 (they have 9 mani stations and 5 pedi thrones) did a nice job.

While I am still leery of pedicures and santitation, it "seemed" OK here.  They use OPI polish and decent base & top coats.  The pedi inculded a short exfoliation with scrub and a decent massage.

I would not RUN back here, but if I need a manicure and am nearby I will return.

Just OK - we like the Pep Boys in Broomall or Wilmington, DE better.
We come here on occasion for parts.

Lackluster service - and one time I needed help there was literally nobody at the front registers.  Someone eventually came up from "the back"n I called out for them.

Odd.

Ok, my best friend calls this place Icky Vicky's - because if you are a big gal - this is NOT the place for you.  Victoria's secret is a place to buy "every day" underwear.  It is mall-quality, mass produced bras, panties, sleepwear, loungewear and now - really poor quality fragrances and cosmetics that bilk thousands of teens and young 20-somethings out of millions each year - and their mama's too!

If it sounds as though I am being harsh - well...

...I Kinda am.

anyhow, I get my typical five for $25 plain cotton string bikinis there and whenever I get a "free panty" coupon in the mail I run right over.

I am definitely not a a Power Shopper at VS - I much prefer high end lovelies like La Perla or Agent Provacateur for the specialty goods.  But for an everyday comfy cotton undie?  VS is my go-to spot.

Just don't ask for help from the teen-aged, undereducated, underpaid staff (although they'll probably offer to help you).  And don't even THINK about coming here over a busy lunch hour when the lines are crazy long.

I  was so excited to try poke on, as I love poke and chirasi bowls, but there were a few things that are in need of improvement, the main one being that the salmon did not taste fresh to me.

Now, it is hard to tell under all the toppings and sauces, but I could still tell.

The staff was friendly, and all the toppings looked great, save for the wilted cucumber slivers, which I thought were pickled cucumbers - they looked that wilted.

Greens are fresh, but no romaine available.  Only spring mix.  

Next time I will get a bowl sans fish.

Extremely slow service but...  BUT...  the clerk (female) was extremely knowledgeable and helpful when I finally got up there (They have 4 or 5 registers but only one was open).  Finally a second lady appeared. And then vanished.  And later appeared again to start working a 2nd till.

I needed to ship a package to Canada and this is not my "usual" USPS office, so I am glad it was here.
It was a long wait but in the end everything was fine.

They sell some basic packaging supplies, greeting cards and postage related products here, also.

Do not expect to get "in and out".  You will wait.

Walked in for a lunchtime slice (to go, definitely to go - people!) today.  Got a mushroom slice for $2.00 even and walked in and out.

Ate the cheese-coated slice (not greasy though - bonus) with a very fresh crust, - at my desk.  The crust was definitely the best part - I was able to eat all of the crust and not throw it away as I often do.  It was medium thick (not too thick) doughy but COOKED and not at all burnt.  Nice crust, Brandywine!

Now I need a nippy-nap.

I feel carbed out!  Sorry, Brandywine - but I'm sticking with John's Place (no slices there, though - only Red-Sauce veggie pies for me.)

I would definitely consider ordering a take-out pie from Brandywine in the future.

Oh - and the service I got was fine. A nice hispanic?? lady was behind the counter and 2 guys were cooking in the back.

And in case you care, they sell Red Bull.

You can sample a gazillion kinds of pickled items - including pickled eggs and pickled tomatoes - however noe of them are the "Real" jewish half sours that I love.  Theirs are OK - but not that great.  

That said - their non-pickled items (they sell all kinds of slaws, salads, puddings and mixes) are expansive.  They also make terrific sour cream & onion flavored popcorn (of all things!) all served up by kind young ladies.

If you need potato salad they offer at least 3 different kinds.

Sorry - but with the passage of time the SLOW service (I cut them a break because they were brand new and i thought they'd get their act together) is now unbearable.

It took me 12 minutes to wait in line (only 2 people ahead of me), order, get the sandwich made, get the salad made, pay and leave.

Also without any more promotional coupons a bagel & cream cheese is $249 plus tax and over $3.00 if I dare to put a slice of tomato on it.

I am getting discouraged - because I do love the rosemary olive oil bagels.  But not at $3 a pop.

It's OK.  Just OK.  Now that Thai Chef & Noodle Fusion is open right near my office I may never need to come here again.  I gotta have my Tom Yum fix every now and again and un until now Erawan was just about IT in terms of Thai-near-my-office.

The service is always friendly - that I will say - very, very nice gals waiting tables and very smiley.

I usually get Masaman Curry - tofu or chicken - and of course some Tom Yum or Tom Kha Soup.

I am not a big Panera fan, but my coworkers are. I usually get a "pick 2" combo for lunch and in winter, I will try a soup with salad.  This time (summer) I tried the watermelon salad and it was very nice.  I always get dressing in the side, in case I do not like it, and to control the amount.

My kid likes the Mac and cheese here.

It's a safe choice for lunch. Spent  $11 with no drink.  Seems high for glorified fast food.

I have passed by Joe's (often noting the long lunchtime lines) and NEVER gone in - until today.  And, boy am I glad I did.  I had a delicious slice of tomtato pie topped with spinach (no cheese).  

It was very good and $2.75 for the slice.

My friend had a tomato, cheese & spinach slice which also looked good - but she got the EGGPLANT (which I had not noticed) and that looked Awesome!  Next time I'm gonna try the eggplant.

Nice decor for a pizza joint, too.  I will be back (but not often - as I am not a pizza-lover).

I stand by my previous review.  I came here for a "ladies luncheon" in the larger event space - again - beautiful at first glance but then you notice that rugs/carpets are old and chandeliers are loaded with dust.  The ladies room with 2 stalls was inadequate for our group of 88 people and stunk.  No ventilation in there.  Eew.

Service was fine but the 4 servers were way understaffed  (4 people for a seated group of 88 at 10 tables.)

Food was lukewarm - we had a choice of pasta primavera (again - I skipped it now!), a cheese omelette or salmon.  I opted for salmon which was edible but boring.  They use the cheapest possible foods to keep cost low.

Parking is kinda weird, too.  They have a very good looking European guy flagging in cars - later he served us coffee.

The place is very, very odd. 
But it is inexpensive so my group keeps having functions here.

This place is odd.
For every positive there is at one corresponding negative.

At first glance, I thought, "Oh, this place is nice"  but as I explored the place (like a big 3 story old house with the owners living on the top floor, party rooms on the other 2 lower floors), it looked dated and in need of a good clean-out.

This is NOT a restaurant.
Inexpensive foods were used - tasted fine - but nothing to write home about.

I have pasta primavera - penne in "red" sauce with a few green beans and carrot slivers on top.

Salad had precisely ONE grape tomato and ONE slice of cucumber.  (Could you spare it?)

Tiny, tiny glass of diet coke.

Not bad -  and nice for a gathering if you need it due to location - but I would NEVER have a wedding here.  Possibly a luncheon or "shower" but not something truly important.

Service, too - odd.  One waiter was smiling and friendly and attentive - the other cold and grumpy.

You win some, you lose some.
This place is decidedly middle-of-the-road.

A small bowling alley that is somewhat underground - it almost looks closed even though there is a big lit sign saying "Open".  Clean and very kid-friendly.  2 pool tables.

BYO (food) B and bowl a game!

Tip:  There is a coupon on their website for $10 off.

Decent coffee in a bar (or is it a decent beer in a coffee shop?), plus they have live music at night.

I usually get a cafe au lait and leave.

I sincerely hope this is the right Tonelli's that I am reviewing.  We had them cater an event for about 30 people - ordered pizzas, tomato pie (excellent) 2 kinds of stomboli's, a hoagie tray and pasta salad.

All were promptly delivered and tasted great.

Would definitely use them again.

World's apart from the vile, horrid Chuck E. Cheese's in South Philly.
This Chuck E.'s is actually, barely, mildly tolerable.

Less crowded, more games than work, shorter lines to get food and redeem tickets for cheap plastic "prizes".

My 5 year old is in Heaven here.  My husband and I?  Not so much.

Prices must have been adjusted because today my beloved Rosemary & Olive Oil bagel with lite veggie CC and tomato and cucumber was a mere $2.89.  Servise is still slow as molasses and I was the first one in line (2 people in line at 11:50 AM).

Try to go BEFORE the lunch rush and after the breakfast rush or you will be waiting and waiting.
