If I didn't love that darned Rosemary & Olive Oil Bagel so much (and I really shouldn't be eating them that often anyway - calorie and carb-city!) I would never come back here - but the siren's song is hard to resist.

I am not a big Cosi Fan but this location (in a strip mall in Wayne/Berwyn/Paoli ish) is close to my office and the Salmon Salad I got ($10 ish) was decent.

Iced coffee was bitter.

Service was quick and very pleasant.

A decent lunch alternative.

I wanted to love it.  Really, I did.
I had the fried Chicken, mac 'n cheese and collard greens.

All were they way they are supposed to be.  (By the book) 
But the mac was way to heavy - and I didn't happen to get any of that good crust on the top layer.

The chicken was sooooo salty.  Like eating saltines in the Sahara.
And very, very greasy (but hell - it is FRIED chicken.)

The greens were perfect.

I give them a 3 stars for food and the grotty digs of the RTM and the SURLY (down-right nasty) service I got from the counter lady really made me feel like just leaving.

The 30th Street Station location is WORSE.

As saladworks go, this one is pretty decent - and in the vast culinary wasteland of this neighborhood, it is a welcome and convenient (if pricey) choice.

Home of the $8.00 salad, saladworks offers salads, soups and panini sadwiches (which I never get - as I do not like them).

I have figured out the exactly right salad for me using the "create your own" option.  Thus, I rarely deviate from my "usual".

The greens are sometimes rusty - so I opt for spinach or spring mix.
I also do not care for the rolls, so I never get one.

It's an option for a quick lunch and I am glad they are here so I don't have to eat pizza every day.

3 or maybe 4 stars - but too "average" to really justify 4 stars.
I stopped in for lunch and needed quick and cheap.  That may have been a mistake - this place can be quick, but it ain't cheap.

So I cheaped-out and got the express lunch (Which says it's $9 on the front door menu - but then it says is $10 on the blackboard.)

So for $10 you get a choice of soup (Minestrone OR Italian wedding) or salad (House or Caesar) and then a choice of a personal pizza OR a 1/2 sandwich.

I got Caesar salad and 1/2 a chicken parm.
The chicken parm was very good and served on a fresh, hot toasted roll (carb overload - especially since they also give you garlic rolls - which are LOADED in garlic.)
Do not eat those garlic rolls if you have an important meeting or presentation after lunch, LOL.  I brushed my teeth at the office and I still taste the garlic.  Wow.

The salad was just OK - not the best Caesar and not bad by any means - a bit over-dressed and heavily sprinkled with parm (which some may enjoy.)

I am in no hurry to rush back here, but if I did I would bring more money and go for dinner and get the "full experience".

The $10 cheapie lunch is just "Meh". (Serves me right!)

Oh - my server, Erin was a doll - giver her a raise.  She could use it!

Even post-renovation, Wilmington station is pretty sad.  The good part?  Less crowded and smaller that NYC or Philly.  You can get Amtrak or SEPTA here.

The building itself is historic and architecturally significant.

Restrooms are nasty - but much improved post-rennovation.

Location, location, location - and this is a good one.
EVerything you need - for the most part from stationery to toner to computer stuff.

Nice to have it in Center City.

Customer service is meh and prices are high (you gotta pay that Center CIty rent!).

My husband had a basic Lube/Oil/Filter done here about a year ago because we happened to be nearby.  They were very quick and seemed to do an OK job (but what the heck do I know about cars?  I write the checks, baby.).

They did recommend alot of un-needed extras (did we want new wiper blades?  Did we want an upgraded this or that?)  but we did not take the bait.  Thus we escaped with our wallets (and hopefully our Hyundai) intact.

Super slow service on a Wednesday morning at 8:15 am. One lady just plain left, but I stuck it out and got my $4.50 iced half-caff latte.  

The good news? Close to my office.
The bad news?  Don't come here if you are in a hurry. 

Clean restrooms.
A Shiseido store that also carries Quiora (from Japan) and other lines.  Mostly catering to the Chinatown crowd, nice ladies selling products & accessories.

Food is fine, service from Mandy is always terrific.  Stick with chinese dishes and skip the sushi.  Spare ribs, house special wonton soup and candied walnut shrimp are my parent's go-to meal.

The place is never crowded. I guess they survive on take out business. 

A good choice for Chinese.

It's in the Gallery and while it's decent - ,any of the pastries are too "gloppy" for me.  It is, indeed, cheaper than DiBruno's - but it is not nearly as good as Termini Bros.

The cookies have brightly colored sprinkles and thus, My 4 year old just adores it here - but she's a kid and would eat cookies just about anywhere.

Birthday cakes here are moist and tasty - a good option if you work in the area and need an office cake in a pinch.

Nothing for ambience - GET TAKE OUT - but for fast and tasty pizza with a medium thick (not thin and not thick) crisp crust - this is a great place.  Our law firm had a few lunches catered with NUMEROUS pies brought in including Plain, White. Veggie (so great), Sausage (pellets), and Pepperoni.  

The attorneys feasted with gusto.

A decent nay-bor-hood joint.  Jewknowamsayin'?

A perfectly average Wawa (old school, no gas) with a star deducted for the super-hectic parking lot. Be careful!  A zillion people coming and going is an accident waiting to happen. 

Meanwhile I got my $2 iced latte and got in and out.

Unscathed.

Wow - there are still a few Happy Harry's left in business.  Just the name makes me a little nostalgic.  Basically this is like a Rite-Aid or Thrift Drug - sundries, magazines, cosmetics and a pharmacy counter.

Not bad!  Very good for cheap school supplies, too.

Had a very good Cafe Au Lait here this morning on my way to a SATURDAY training session.  (Oy!)  Service was fast and friendly - even on a Saturday.

The only downer?  The aggressive homeless lady who asked me twice for change and then followed me around to the coffee condiment bar and hovered while I put Splenda in my au lait.

Not Saxby's fault - but not a great way to start the day.

Have not been back in a while and quality and cleanliness have slipped.
So has service.

Very inexpensive and tasty Viet specialties - complete with V-Pop videos playing on a flat-screen.

Bun Hoi was OK - a little greasy (I was surprised).
Crispy pancake was SOGGY - but it was loaded with shrimp, pork and crunchy bean sprouts.
Spicy chicken over broken rice was very simple and good.

Took home an order ($4.95) of summer rolls for el kiddo.

This branch of Old Nelson is located in 30th Street station - so you are a "captive audience" - and thus pay the higher prices for snacks, coffee, cold drinks, decent sandwiched and salad items (they have a full deli).

A decent choice when waiting for a train - and better than fast food.

Stick with Chinese dishes here.
The salmon teriyaki was overcooked and the sushi was not great.

Not in a hurry to come back.

Absolutely just OK.
Pleasant service, acceptable decor - and do NOT get the over-sauced Pad Thai.  (A dud.)

But some good things?  A very good wonton soup with light, delicate wontons and a non-greasy broth, (Winner) and decent shrimp with Grand Marnier (read: Mayonnaise) sauce and sweet candied walnuts.

Like I said - decent but not great.

World's apart from the vile, horrid Chuck E. Cheese's in South Philly.
This Chuck E.'s is actually, barely, mildly tolerable.

Less crowded, more games than work, shorter lines to get food and redeem tickets for cheap plastic "prizes". Better clientele.

My 5 year old is in Heaven here.  My husband and I?  Not so much.

Just OK - we've had better and worse teppanyaki meals in the past.  My husband and I were squeezed in at 5:45 (the last seating for the "early bird" prices with 8 other local-yokels including a well behaved 5 year old.

The room was already steamin' hot from the other teppanyaki table that had 3 kids - one of whom (maybe age 2) screamed every time a fire was lit.  That sucked - because that was almost our entire meal.

Meanwhile the act is pretty typical with the onion volcano (if and when we come back our 8 year old will love it) a big pile of so-so fried rice and OVERCOOKED steaks and shrimp.  The shrimp were nearly rubbery and my "rare (I always ask for rare at a teppanyaki and it always comes out over done) steak cubes were medium to medium well.

Oh well.

It was an experience. Oh and the guy ext tome ordered a sushi meal with pale tuna and blah looking fish.  No way I'll get sushi here.

Not thrilling - but it's an option in the land of suburban chain restaurants.
And kiddos LOVE the show.

I had not been back to Erawan in years - but I remember why.
It's just OK.  Better than 2 stars and not quite 3.

We went out as a group of 6 and eveyone had one of the lunch specials ($7.95 - $11.95 depending on what meat you pick.) It's a good value as you also get a small salad and a choice of app or soup.

I had the Tom Kha (my very favorite soup) and Erawan's version is good but not orgasmic.  The salad is iceberg with a few veggies and a yummy peanut dressing (standard Thai-American restaurant fare).  

The entree is where things went south today.
I got Masaman curry (which I love) and asked for tofu.
The order came out with NO TOFU - none at all.
They forgot to add it.
They were sorry.

Nice man brought cubes of hot steamed (naked) tofu in a bowl and I threw it in.

Rice was over cooked to the point of tasting like congee.

Meanwhile - the staff is kind and attentive.
Prices are cheap.

Food is just OK.

We need a more up-scale Thai joint in this part of the city.

This is the FiveBucks in the lobby of the big Marriott in Center City and it. gets. busy.
And crowded.  And messy at the sugar/creamer station.  And attracts a few vagrants who are quickly ushered away from tourist eyes,

Meanwhile, I NEEDED a latte and I latte I obtained.

What a rush.

Try not to come here from 7:30 - 9 AM on a weekday.  Mob Scene.

Wow - are they still in business?  This restaurant - right on the corner of 2 major roads, has been a landmark for decades.  The median age of the patrons (and servers) is about 60.

They offer a great choice of old fashioned home-style platters such as welsh rarebit and chicken croquettes.

It was fun to eat here as a child and even then, felt like a nostalgic throwback to another era.

I hope they are still in business, as I have not personally eaten here in many years - but I gave 3 stars in anticipation that by now they MUST need a cosmetic overhaul.  Back in "the day" we even saw fashion shows here sponsored by the Chamber of Commerce and other groups.

And we ate fattening food and iceberg based salads.

What fun!

A good choice for a TAKE OUT (there's no where to sit really) sandwhich or some Boar's Head Cold Cuts, yougurt, cold beverages etc.  It's 1 step above a Wawa in my book.  They also sell cigarettes -especially handy if you are having a nic fit.

Glad they are around.  This area of the nabe needs all the retail help it can get.

The era of the American shopping mall is slowly grinding to a halt - with the demise of the Granite run mall and slow decline of Concord and Springfield Malls (Concord has many empty stores.)

The good part?  Plenty of parking - and at lunch there is a Chick Fil-A and a grub burger bar (have not tried), a Sbarro, Auntie Anne's Pretzels and more.

There is also a Bath & Body works and a Victoria's Secret for when I need one nearby.

Glad it's here but I bet in 10 years it won't be.

I don't really like or claim to "know" BBQ - but for a chain restaurant this place is good enuf for me.  I usually get the lunch size BBQ chicken.  The cornbread/muffins are like cupcakes - so sweet and good.  The spicey green beans are too hot for me - and the beans are mushy.

I do like the  place for my 3 year old - there is alot of "flair" all over the walls - camping, hunting and fishing.

The bathrooms are labelled setters and pointers.  (Bah-duhm-bump...)

It's very, very inexpensive and makes for a good gift-card gift.  I gave Famous Dave's gift cards to my cleaning lady and babysitter last Xmas and they loved that!

They also served 4 or 5 kinds of BBQ sauce.  The original is my fave - and the sweet one is also nice - but it is quite sugary.

Try it once - but this is not a pit-masters haven.  It is a TGI Fridays with a BBQ theme.

Disappointed with our last 2 visits.  We have come to the Doylestown Saladworks for about a decade - maybe longer - and since Covid hit it is just not great.  Prices are up to around $10.49 - $10.99 for a salad.

Last time - no pasta and NO ROMAINE.  Only crappy iceburg that was turning brown.  Oh - and some other ingredient we like was out too, I forget what.
Oh - and no more shrimp.  

Very disappointed.

Please step up your game, Saladworks.

We have eaten many meals here - including Brunch and "special occaision" meals.

I also stayed at the B & B in the late '90's - and it was fine back then - not sure how it is these days.

The restaurant offers classic American fare and decent prices.  It screams "Mother's Day" to me - and we often do go here for that day.  Nice appetizers, as DJ M. has said - and a friendly bartender.

Years ago they had a pianist on Friday (and/or) Saturday at dinner.

Always crowded and definitely not my favorite place to shop but when I am in this area, this is where we go for all the essentials.

Opens at 7 AM - and if you go around 7:15 on a week day (Tuesday - Friday) it is less crowded.

I have never used the full services areas like the deli nor the seafood counter - I just grab dairy, produce and shelf stable items and go.

Mid-priced - decent sales.

The worse part? Crowded. Lines for checking out and crowded aisles.
I was just informed by a FB friend that Plumsteadville Inn closed in December 2009.  What a shame.

Got a cheapie ($6.00 - and a $2.00 tip) polish change here yesterday by "Jenny".    It was quick and easy - which was what I needed.  Not a place I would ever consider going to for a pedicure.  (They have 2 pedi-chairs crammed against the back wall.

But for a Philly nail salon this was typical.  Not too clean, but not filthy.
A mani is $10, Pedi is $20 - get both for $25.

Just OK.   They carry Limited OPI, Essie and "VS" an off brand.  They used industry grade, cheap base & top coats.  You can have the good stuff on request - but they will charge $1.00 extra.

You get what you pay for, ladies.

They also offer brow waxing.

OK, my husband (back then fiance) and I went here ONCE about 3-4 years ago and i will try to remember what I can.  I know that I loved it and he hated it, so I am splitting the difference at 3 stars.  (I'd probably give it a 4 for the Chicken Francese entree I had, and for chatting with the chefs in the semi-open kitchen.)

Service was good, but DH did not like his pizza (margarita) at all.  Too thin, too burnt tasting, too expensive.  he went on and on.

Meanwhile, i had a great time and (being fresh outta Manhattan at the time) thought the prices seemed pretty "normal".

I would like to go back and try this place again.

While some of the good food is quite good, there are too many things that went wrong for me to rate this higher than 2 or 3 stars.

Service needs work.
Stat!
We were one of 2 parties dining at 5 pm on an empty Monday night and had problems getting a fork, getting water, getting anything.  I literally had to get up and find somebody. Twice.
No bueno!

Also our original table had not one but at least 3 tiny flies buzzing about. So we asked to moved tables, the flies followed.  Not pleasant.

The good itself was hit or miss. Simple dry-fried string beans were tasty. Cabbage in a pumpkin soupy sauce was not.  Shrimp fried rice was very basic, not orgasmic, but good.  The pork belly bun appetizer is worth a try.  Buns are fresh and the pork belly was delectable.   Contains peanuts so beware, my allergic diners!

I would come back, but I am in no rush to do so, which is a shame because the decor is lovely and everything on the menu sounds better than it is.

We have eaten here twice - and the first time was a 4 or 5 star experience - that Brian roll is AMAZING.

But...

There's always a big but...

The second time we went - a busy Saturday night - the fish was just not fresh.  It was kinda icky, actually.  The restroom also was dirty and gross.

We will not return.

What a shame.

Very friendlies service but my chicken gyro was woefully dry.  Pit was not "fluffy" either - kinda stale-ish tasting.  
If there is a next time, I will try a "regular" gyro or a tuna melt.

Running out of options for lunch around here.
They serve breakfast here and I may try that.

Inexpensive - $6.75 (or $6.95 as a lunch special with fries.)

Update:  My office got 3 pizzas from Mystic (Mistic) for a company lunch - 2 plain and 1 pepperoni and they were quite good, actually.  Maybe Pizza is what I should stick to here?

4 stars for the fabulous service by Shaun
2 stars for the mediocre food that may have made my 9 year old sick.

We stopped in - famished - and wear from a long day, at about 9 PM on a Thursday night.  The place was nearly empty so we got bright, cheerful service from Shaun - who is a lovely lady.  She even decorated my kids hot cocoa with whipped cream.

The restroom appeared clean but smelled horribly of old urine (Eew.).
Normally this would be enough to give a place 1 or 2 stars - but Shaun's service is carrying my 3 star overall rating.

Stick to coffee and breakfast foods and you'll be OK.
Skip the greasy chicken strips (kids menu - a steal at $2.99 - but not if they make you sick), and also skip the pasta dishes.  (Overuse of dried oregano.)

My husband had a grilled chicken sandwhich which looked very good.

If you ever read my other reviews, you may already know that I am not a fan of chain restaurants - but in a pinch this Bob Eveans will do.

And hopefully Shaun won't be there long - she's studying nursing and is well suited for a care giving profession.  She's terrific!

OMG - so overpriced for what it is.
I just had the $14 triple - an open-faced grilled cheese, French onion soup and a small salad, plus an iced tea.

My friend had an $18 burger and a beer.

Lunch was $52 after tax & tip.

Very nice food - but not THAT nice.
Sheesh.

Oh boy.  Where do I start?
Lots of things have changed at Fork.  Some for the better - but most are not.

Before I dive in - let me just say - or scream - this:

NOT GOOD FOR KIDS!!!!

Our fussy party of 4 included my not-so-fussy 8 year old - who has dined at many Philadelphia spots.  Before we went I saw "Crispy Chicken Nuggets" on the "Bites" menu - so I knew that was what we would get for her.

BOMB!  Dark meat chicken chunks in very pale (nearly white) tempura batter made the young lady frown almost instantly.

So we asked if the "Spaghetti al chitarra" (Homemade spaghetti with butter, scallions and crab) could be made as just spaghetti with butter?  What a fuss ensued - and after negotiations, yes - they brought her a small plate of home-made spaghetti DROWNED in butter.  And tried to charge $18 for it (which is the normal price when it comes with crabmeat.).

So disappointed.

OK - so "kids meal fiasco" aside - how were the grown-up dishes?
Not bad.  Salads were the stand out - my kale salad was terrific (Matyson's is better - as Fork's is a bit too vinegary in my opinion), and my friends split the "Roots" - a unique preparation of seasonal root veggies.

Appetizer pastas were SMALL and $15 - $16 each.  Yikes.

Our server is a great guy - and I just knew I had seen him before!
But the whole "not sure if we can make pasta with butter" thing just sat with me very poorly.

Even Ellen herself (the owner) cam out to chat with us - and I pretty much told her all of this.  I don't think it will matter one bit in the long run.
4 star food and 2 star (maybe even 1 star) service.

I won't be back. And there is no way I will deign to bring a kid in here.  (They made it very clear she was not welcome.

This was our long-time home-town wawa, somplete with smokes, drinks and snacks.  The parking lot can get crowded so be careful pulling in & out.  Over the years Wawa has really expanded it's brand and reach.

This wawa was pretty much the first one I ever was in.

2 star food but surprisingly 4 star service - we sat at a table in the bar area.
11.95 for an Italian Hoagie?  Really?

I had a classic wedge salad which was fine but I asked to top it with a grilled salmon filet ($8.95 additional) and it was bone dry and flavorless.

Blargh.

The good news?  Super close to where I am working and quick service at lunch time.
Have a drink but eat elsewhere.

Alas, the pop shop may be fizzling.

I would love to be able to give this place a 4 or 5 star - as it is just so preciously cute and the food is great, but the decibel level and service leave much to be desired.

Three of us, including my 4 year old, had lunch here today and the place was jammed.  The servers were so over worked, they just couldn't handle it.

For now the frenetic pace has made me too pooped to pop.

And the noise level was deafening.

That said, DD enjoyed her "Captain Underpants" sundae (basically a cone-clown a la Friendly's) and my vegetarian friend (a different one) had a seitan cheesesteak.  I had a VAT of Cobb salad - so huge it was not finishable.  There were about 4 chopped whole eggs in it.  We took it home.

I would like to come back here again when it is NOT busy (is that ever??).  I bet it'd get higher marks.

Friendly staff - a few of which have been there for years, and also a few who appear to be "mentally challenged".  Kudos to Acme for that.

Meanwhile, the prices are fine (cheaper than Giant) but also they do not carry certain items like Hint Water (I have to trek to Giant or the new Whole Foods for that) and other organic goodies.  They carry Reed's Ginger Brew - but want 6.89 for a 4 pack.  Ee-gads!

Anyhow, I do shop here and will continue to do soas it is on my way home from work.
But for major weekend shopping it's Giant or Whole Paycheck for me.

P.S.  Your Newman's  lemonade was nearly 3 weeks out of date in the Dairy Case.

Yes, a guy does own this place - and he treats my 5 year old DD so very well.  She has had 2 manicures (polish changes actually) here over the past year and one time "jiji" (Not sure of her name) painted cute little lady bugs on her nails.  She was tickled!!!

I have never, personally, had any nail services performed here - but we like it as a place for my daughter.  They do very nice nail art and the polish lasted on her busy little paws.

A typical diner menu with variety and reasonable prices.
We went with a party of 3 including a hungry 7 year old who enjoyed her French Toast.

Service was Ok - but at the end of the meal when i handed her my debit card - after a quick glance at the check, she rang it up and returned me the slip to sign.

No tip line?

So I asked her - "Where do I put the tip?", and she says, "Oh, we do it beforehand".
I had very little cash on me so I left her the $5 I had and we left.

She basically deprived herself of the full tip  (Should have been $6 or $7.)

They need to explain this before the present the check,

Just dumb.

Meanwhile if I am in the area and need a diner - I would return.

It's fast(ish) food style Mexican - and you can get a decent taco platter for $6.99 ($7.99 if you want shrimp or fish).  I opted for 1 pork & 1 carne asada.  Both were good - but the asada had lots of onion on top - next time I will know to get it on the side.

Rice, beans & chips.

Quick service, big portions, no issues.

Gets CROWDED during the weekday lunch rush.

This homegoods is pretty disorganized - as many of them are - and we could not find anything we were looking for (magnets and guest towels).  We also came on the Saturday after Xmas so the place was crammed with bargain hunters and gift return-ers.

Will not be back so quickly.

Ok - I am being nice and giving 3 stars, but I really want to give them 2.
Don't get me started on UO.  We have a long post collegiate, complex relationship.  When they first opened and had only a few stores and seemed so cool.  It was the height of the grunge era back then.  And hot chicks and "hip" dudes worked there.

Now it's more than a bit played out and man, they jacked up the prices.  I mostly get accessories and socks here now - the pants fall apart.  (And for 60 bux??)

Oh I miss the good old days.  It seemed better back then."

This is the Starbucks right near the Whole foods and it's fine.  Gets crowded during peak hours and the staff is pleasant enough.

Smaller floorplan.

Parking here is a nightmare - and often there are no spaces - except for 2 resevred for the empty "We Buy Gold" store next door.

I often park in the shopping center (acme) next door) and walk across the busy street to get my four dollar latte fix.

Meanwhile - the service here once inside is actually good.  The afternoon female barista (3-5 ish PM) is terrific.  Can't remember her name.

Oh - and please clean the bathrooms more.  Blargh!

Got this to-go (eating here is a bit depressing)( but Judy and Beth - working the lunch line were friendly and polite.

Got a 3 piece dark meat platter with brocolli and green beans on the side.  (Came with cornbread).  Not good for you - but better than the 980 calorie BOMB chicken pot pie that my friends all got (It's tasty.).

An acceptable alternative to Tony Luke's and IHOP.

I coulda sworn I wrote a review for ladder fifteen a while ago - but alas - I guess I did not.  I am basing this review on a large event my group had in there upstairs, private space.  

We had about 90 people, an open beer, wine and well drinks bar (excellent) and appetizers (not so much).

Firstly, there was not enough food (in quantity) and the quality of the small platters of apps (place on the bar - not butlered) was pretty meh.  Pretzel nuggets with mustard dipping sauce (cheap!), Mediocre quesedillas, and a strange bruscetta with an unidentifyable brown meat-or-possibly-eggplant on top.  Still have no idea what the heck that was all about!

Anyhow, service was fine - bartenders were quick with our moderately-drinking crowd of adults in there' late 20's to early 50's.

Will I rush back here?  Probably not.

5 star service from Shana (sp?) and Kaitlyn (sp?) but 2 star food.
Absolutely DRY al pastor burrito - but I was too full from scarfing down over-salted chips to eat much anyway.  Took over 1/2 home.

Drinks were good - the pineapple cilantro Marg being the best of the lot.

Considering it was "Dining Under the Stars" (we had a prime table in the front of the house near the open window) it could have been worse.

I really want to give them higher marksand Ionly come here a few times per year - and the service is great but the food needs work.

A nice, affordable Italian BYOB.  We had a very, very large group in the private party room and had a choice of 3 entrees - and all were delicious.  Services was attentive and not pushy.  Decent atmosphere.

We also came here once on our own and had mediocre pasta dishes. 

We will be back, but not in a hurry.

This place has been here for years and it's, well, odd.

They have a create-your own salad section (similar to Saladworks - but cheaper), and a Japanese Food/Sushi section.

Very inexpensive.  Food is OK.  Just OK.

A cheap, quick lunch choice.

Pure fare tasted better when it was on somebody else's dime.
Yes, I LOVE the green detox juice - but it's $5.00 (and it's served warm - so ask for ice in advance if you can't stomach warm veggie juice).

My salad was $7.60 and tasted great - but again - I came in at just under $14 for a juice and a salad.

And service is painfully slow - as the barrista has to drip everyone's blue bottle coffee one slow drip at a time.

Bring cash and your patience if you want lunch here.

Average CVS - well stocked and clen but does not stay open late enough at night (Pharmacy closes at 8 or 10 PM?  Too early for those "sick kid" emergencies.

We had to go to Walgreen's for dat.

Right next to Chick Fil-A so we stop in quite a bit.

I have been coming to this particular old-skool (no gas station) wawa since grade school.

Smokes, coffee, tasty-kakes, hoagies and the day's newspaper.

No problems here - the parking lot gets crowded so PAY ATTENTION - but this is our go-to D-town wawa.

And we love it.

Went back again and service was much better but still a few off-putting things. (Food is great - especially chicken parm and anything with rosa /aurora sauce)

Charged $2.00 extra to have aforementioned sauce on kids meal (pasta and meatballs - and then no meatballs arrived.

Owner came around to see how things were BEFORE any food had arrived.  And he seems grumpy.  Weird.  Meanwhile our 8 year old likes it here so I bet we'll be back.
Wish they were friendlier.

A nice, basic Irish (real Irish owners & bartenders - and Irish music playing) pub with Irish and American pub grub.  I like it better than Tir Na Nog.  We had cute little "mini burgers" and a chicken quesedilla made with Boxty (really - the potato boxty like in Ireland) instead of a tortilla.

I would go back!

We came on a super-busy Wednesday for Dining Under ste stars - and miraculously our table was ready & waiting even though there were throngs of others.  The service was surprisingly good.

The food?  Just OK - and yes, I had read the reviews on yelp and yes, they are accurate - this place needs to step up their game on the food front.  Pizzas are not my thing - but 3 of our group of 6 (well - 5 and an infant) have pizza.    They seemed very doughy to me and many do not have sauce.  (Cheese and coldcuts on bread.)

My kid had the lobster-stuffed arrancina - and they were leaden with a greasy crusty exterior.  I have had better but the 9 year old loved them.

My dish was a fail.  Tasteless salmon with too-vinegary chopped tomatoes on top.  I ate the mashed potatoes and brocolli but left most of the fish.

Azie's Salmon Teriyaki puts Ariano's salmon to shame!

I will not be rushing back here.
Disappointing menu and food.

I have lived in the Pacakrd Building for 3 years now - and while the rents continue to rise & rise, the building is still good for us.  Great location and basically well run and well managed.

We wish they'd replace the 22 year old washer dryer in my apartment though.  It takes FOREVER to dry clothes and is a waste of electricity.

The entire building is 100% electric - so there's no gas bill - but the electric bills for heat and a/c - especially with our 15 foot ceilings (a plus and also a minus) - the bills are SKY HIGH.  (Pun intended.)

Some of the front desk staff are lazy - but most are very nice and willing to help you with dry-cleaning and packages.  Rita is the nicest of the bunch.

It's a gorgeous apartment for a luxury price.  Smack dab in the middle - of NOTHING.  (Broad Street bet. Vine & Callowhill).

There is "The Sunday Breakfast Club" aka homeless shelter 1/2 a block away so there are quite a few unsavory goings-on in the alley next to the building.  AND little police patrol.  Once we get home after work - we stay there!!!

We bought a microfiber sofa from Raymour back in 2007 (For about $600) and got very good use out of it, so we headed to this location (Yay for no-tax in DE) but wound up buying elsewhere.

Decent prices - and our sales lady (Shelly??) had been there for years and was so helpful.

We wound up buying somewhere else solely due to price.  We'll let you know what happens.

I have gone to the 21st Street location a few times - mostly when I first moved to Philly and did not know about other (better) places.

There is no atmosphere - but it is very, very reasonable for a quick bento lunch.  They used to serve a DELICIOUS inexpensive kalbi box but no more.  You can still get the bul-goki though - but it is not as good as the bul-goki at the Korean Place on Chestnut (I am spacing out on the name of the place between 20 & 21 on Chestnut).  It's MIRAN - that's the name.  MIRAN!!!

But I digress...

Menawhile do NOT order any sushi type items here.  The spicy tuna rolls were NOT fresh.  Stick to the cooked meals and rice bowls and you'll be fine.

You get alot of OK (some is good, even) foor and a LOT of rice for very little coin.

When you want the good stuff though, so elsewhere.
For dinner.

This is a lunch place.

Really.

We were stuck at Jefferson for 4 hours and needed a place to go to have a cappucino and kill some time.  Friendly staff - decently clean bathrooms, good coffee (I had an iced coffee, Mom had a capp.)

Not great but not awful.

We had a nice Saturday lunch here - and believe it or not - it was good and not too crowded when we came.  Now you can't compare this to Xochitl or Tequila's in Center City - but it ain't no Qdoba neither.  This is a middle of the roadMexican party-house with a good pre-mix margarita, fresh chips and tasty pico (salsa??).

We enjoyed our enchildas, thank you very much.

Just ok.
Service is spotty, food is hit or miss (decent but greasy beef fajitas, dry plantains and just-right black beans).

Meanwhile - a good place for a blackberry margarita (the classic one was a bit tart for me) or mojito (better).

Wish the food were better - especially for the price point.

I have actually eaten here.

Yes.

Gasp.

So shocking - seeing as I usually don't even consider fast food - but I have a weakness.  Every once in a business-trippy-blue moon, I grab an egg McMuffin here on my way to catch the AMTRAK train.

300 calories.
$2.99 (sometimes they have a buy 2 for $3 deal - but who can eat 2 of them?)

Egg Mc Muff.

What evs,

Oh - and believe it or not the Muslim ladies who run the place (at least on the morning weekday shift) are pretty darned pleasant. I was so shocked!

A stronger 3 star update based on ANOTHER large group function that we had in the upstairs party space.  Food was much better and much more abundant this time.  We also had an open bar with beer, wine and well drinks.  We had about 70 people this time and the atmosphere was more relaxed.

Thank you to Ladder 15 for accomodating our group.
The butternut squash dip was delicious and the Kim-chee Shortrib tacos were a unique twist.

The ubiquitous (and inexpensive) soft pretzel nuggets and odd quesadillas (what the heck is in those things??) were ever-present.

Getting better.
Kick it up a notch and put out SIGNS for the food items and maybe you'll get to 4 stars.

I stopped in (and got out quickly) for a much needed Blu-Ray player for a holiday gift.  Because I was shopping so early I was/am concerned about not being able to return it if the recipient did not like it but they have assured me (as writted a note on my account) that a post-Xmas return is fine.

Meanwhile, at first I did not see all the models of Blu Ray players - and the one I wanted appeared to be out of stock - but the sales associate brought one out from the back.

So far, so good - but I have not bought any "big-ticket" items here yet.

Since I now work nearby and there is not much in the way of choices, I walked in to Alessandro's for lunch today.  It was about 12:45 and crowded but not mobbed.  A nice lady named Christina took my order for a Chicken Gyro - no onions - and a drink to stay.  The total was just under $8.00.

My gyro came out (they announce orders over a microphone) in about 6 minutes and was hot and fresh - and loaded with sliced chicken breast.

Tables were clean and new looking.

Pizza slices (under a glass display) did not appeal to me, so I can't comment on their pizza yet - but for a quick gyro lunch - this was just fine.  I will porbably be back once I have tried out all the local lunch spots.

Auntie Annes' is the McDonalds of the soft pretzel.  High in sodium, fat and carbs (unless you skip the butter dip) they are tasty when hot & fresh.  They also have very sweet lemonade that, alas, my 4 year old loves and is almost never allowed to drink.

Once in a while, OK - but don't make it a habit!

Cedar Beauty Supply has an enormous selection of hair products (Weaves, Wigs, Hair, Accessories).  It does have a bit of a "'hood" feel to it and the lady who runs the salon next door seems to know alot about wigs and weaves.

I picked up a $4.99 styforfoam wig head for my teen daughter's project.
Also notices a bunch of VERY cheap pantyhose in the back ($1.39 per pair?  Whoa!)   So I got one and, as predicted, it ran/ripped less than an hour after I put them on.

Disposable hose.

Anyhow - I did not like the vibe here but I would come back if in the neighborhood and needed a specific item.

They have a small selection of MorrocanOil products in a locked glass case.

I wish I could give them higher marks, but the reviews here are pretty much right on.  This place is in between Meh and A-OK.  I will be kind and give them 3 stars - but the food is 2 stars at best.

Service was fine - although they screwed up my DH's steak burrito (He wanted cheese and jalapenos - both are an extra charge - they brought out a plain burrito.)
It also ticks me off that for tacos and burritos - EVERYTHING (even pico) is an up-charge.  For $9 - 12 (base price of burritos) you'd think they'd allow you some salsa and cheese.  TICKS ME OFF.

Also the salsa they serve with the chips tasted likeywatery ketchup-y shir-acha-ish sauce.  (The cholula on the table was better.) Chips were fresh and fine.

Shrimp Ceviche was good - but not nearly close to the best I've had.  Jicama atop the ceviche had turned brown and was likely prepped hours before.  FAIL.

Side of Platanos were a bit woody-potato-ey (I like Maduros - nice and sweet - and I had JUST had the plantains at Distrto last week.  Distrito kick this places ar$e.)

So - will I be back?  I won't say never, but I certainly would not rush back here.
I plan to try the other MEH-diocre Mexican in Media (M, M, M - I think I'ma gonna make new list) first.

PROS:  Cute place, Menu reads well, Good Service, OPEN SUNDAYS, Happy Hour is a GREAT value for margarita's and $2.50 STELLA ARTOIS!

CONS:  Mediocre food, upcharges for EVERYTHING on the taco/burrito menu, lousy salsa. No reservations unless party is 6 or more.

Please, Diego's - step up your game!

A neccessary Evil - glad it's here.  "Makes life in suburbia bearable" (to coin a phrase from below.

Just wish there was a La Colombe out this way - at at least a hipster mom 'n pop coffee shop.

Go, Media!

OK - I dare not tell you when I used to walk "up town" to Nat's - because then you will know that I am older than Pink.

Hell - I coulda baby sat for little Alicia Moore and her brother - but I digress..

Nat's has been a D-town staple.  For years.
Generation after generation of Jr. and Sr. High schoolers congragate here after football games and dances to have a (greasy) slice or a "wooder" ice in the summer.

I always liked Capri's Pizza better - but Nat's Sicilian pie is still a cheesy baseline for me to this day.

God bless 'em.  They're still here.

4 star food - Excellent and not too greasy.
However the icy service I received knocked them down to 3 stars.

I walked in on a Thursday night at around 8:25 PM.  It turns out they close at 9
Anyhow the place was dead-empty - nobody dining in but me and the only other person who came in was a local cop for take out (good sign).

The lady folding napkins when I arrived seemed genuinely miffed that I dained to eat dinner.

Anyhow - I was able to elicit a smile by the end of the night.
I ordered Chicken with Broccoli ($9.0) and brown rice (no extra charge - nice!).  I asked for it "light on the sauce, dry" and thus - it was perfect.  Fresh crunchy broccoli that nearly tasted sweet when I bit into it and lots of slices (not slivers) of tender whit meat chicken.

I will return - maybe next time she'll WANT to see me.

Oh and the teapots and silverware were very clean.

As Dan H. mentioned there is a $5 per person lunch, $8.00 per person dinner minimum.

I have lived in the Pacakrd Building for 4 years now - and while the rents continue to rise & rise, the building is still good for us.  Convenient Center City location.  Parking available in a covered lot.

We wish they'd replace the 22 year old washer dryer in my apartment though.  We asked & ask and they claimn that even a new unit will still be the same motor.  It takes FOREVER to dry clothes and is a waste of electricity.

The entire building is 100% electric - so there's no gas bill - but the electric bills for heat and a/c - especially with our 15 foot ceilings (a plus and also a minus) - the bills are SKY HIGH.  (Pun intended.)

Some of the front desk staff are lazy - but most are very nice and willing to help you with dry-cleaning and packages.  Rita is the nicest of the bunch.

It's a gorgeous apartment for a luxury price.  Smack dab in the middle - of NOTHING.  (Broad Street bet. Vine & Callowhill).

There is "The Sunday Breakfast Club" aka homeless shelter 1/2 a block away so there are quite a few unsavory goings-on in the alley next to the building.  AND little police patrol.  Once we get home after work - we stay there!!!

This is my 2nd attempt at China Aston Inn - this time I placed a $40 take out order (I did not call it in - just sat and waited for it - took about 12 minutes).

When I arrived on a Monday night at 5:40 PM - again - the place was EMPTY.
So empty that there was no staff - so I said "Hello?  Anybody Here?" a couple of times and finally a lady came out and took my order. She seems a bit pissed off at first and I wonder if it was the same woman from before.  This time I was able to soften her up a bit.

The food itself was fresh and hot when i got it home - chicken with String Beans and wonton soup were good.

Other dishes - not great - the Kung Pao was loaded to excess with water chestnuts and mushrooms.  Hardly any peanuts - and not very spicy even though we wanted spicy and asked for it that way.

Orange Beef was better - that one we asked for mild so our 9 year old could eat it - and she liked it.  (Fried, dark meat chicken chunks).

Not a holy grail - but a change-up from our usual Chinese place.

The place is always deserted - and maybe the odd service vibe and mediocre food is why?

A strong 3 - maybe even a 4 - for the expertise of Laura who help me to plan a small happy hour event for my office.

We enjoyed the Raspberry Wheat beer (3.50 is a decent price for it) and other drinks.  We also tried the salmon spring rolls (excellent) cheese-steak eggrolls (good not great) and southwestern springrolls (my husband liked these).

In addition the Hawaiian Pizza was very tasty - and the crust was freshly baked.  I also tried the Ale & Onion soup which tasted good, but was very, very oily - almost greasy from the oils in the cheese.  Eew.  It was OK as "french"-style onion soup goes but I have had better (and I have had worse.).

The place is MASSIVE - a great idea for private parties -especially on a night when you can enjoy the deck.

The best part of the night?  Meeting fellow yelpers Jessica E. and Chris from Delaware!  Thanks for coming out!

It's huge.  Between the Court & The Plaza you can literally get everything here- if you don't mind paying retail.    I usually eat at Ruby's with a girlfriend and then hit New York & Company.  (See my other reviews.)

Avoid at holiday time - it's a giant parking-lot filled with chaos and annoyance.

If you are a teenager - this place is 4 - 5 stars but I am officially a grown up now - so 3 stars from me!!!

My 6.5 year old kid and I popped in here on a dead Monday at about 5 PM.  Thankfully the place was nearly empty.  There are signs everywhere clearly stating their "Pizza Nazi" policies like, NO TOPPINGS, Cash Only, No restrooms and best opf all - box $0.25!  Wow.  I especially remember the sign "The customer is always WRONG".

Meanwhile the tatted-up, nose-ringed gal behind the counter was sweet as could be to my little one - who was the reason we got a $2.75 Ginormous piece of "Lorenzo's Oil" (Remember that movie?  They named it so for the pizza grease!).

She ate it at Supercuts next door.

She enoyed the pizza but said, "Mommy, it's not as good as the place I go to in Brooklyn!".

Out of the mouths of babes.

This is a review for the Bacco (new location) in the Doylestown shopping Center.  The food is excellent and the poritons are enormous.  Prices are moderate (about 13 for entrees).

But it took forever to:

1.  be greeted
2.  be seated (we wound up seating ourselves)
3.  get menus
4.  have someone wait on us
5.  get our food (cooked to order so that was OK)
6.  get our bill

It was like pulling teeth getting service - and the place was not busy.

Our party of 4 ordered Pasta fagiole soup (huge bowl for $3.95), linguini with (REAL) clams - so good, Chicken parm (served with a delicious side of mezza-rigatti pasta in a crushed tomato sauce), and I had the Chicken florentine.  It was terrific.

We'd like to go back but only if we have lots of time to wait around (for the servers) and thus I would never bring my little kid here.

Not bad.  I have only had a basic mani here - still too scared to risk a pedi.  Most Philly nail salons are soooooo filthy.  It seemed pretty clean here.  Better than Gomo and waaaaaay better than City Nails (aka Sh&tty Nails).

Bring your wn base coat if you want something good - they used cheap base coat on me.  But they did have Seche Vite top coat - which I love.

And they had chair massage - it was pretty meh - but I needed it - however lame it may have been.

SUPER SLOW SERVICE.
Decent food once you get it.

This is a review for the Bacco (new location) in the Doylestown shopping Center.  The food is excellent and the poritons are enormous.  Prices are moderate (about 13 for entrees).

But it took forever to:

1.  be greeted
2.  be seated (we wound up seating ourselves)
3.  get menus
4.  have someone wait on us
5.  get our food (cooked to order so that was OK)
6.  get our bill

It was like pulling teeth getting service - and the place was not busy.

Our party of 4 ordered Pasta fagiole soup (huge bowl for $3.95), linguini with (REAL) clams - so good, Chicken parm (served with a delicious side of mezza-rigatti pasta in a crushed tomato sauce), and I had the Chicken florentine.  It was terrific.

We'd like to go back but only if we have lots of time to wait around (for the servers) and thus I would never bring my little kid here.

This Chik-Fil-A is just OK.  Not as good or well run as the stand-alone shops in the suburbs - but the service is quick - and my little one loves the Chik-Fil-A nuggets kids meal.

Chik-Fil-A is just about the only fast food I ever let her eat.  We are not proponents of it.

I enjoy the side salad (minus the cheese) and it comes with (fattening) tasty croutons and honey roasted sunflower seeds.  If you ate all the condiments and dressing Chik-Fil-A offers with the side salad - you can easily pack away 500 calories.  Sheesh.

So be careful out there folks - it's a nutritional mine field - but it's decent fast poultry.  And your kids will eat it. (Not sure how great of a thing that really is.)

Yes it was a mem'rie filled, exhausting all day (take a personal day) extravaganza for my 3 year old and husband & I.

Even on a random TUESDAy at 10 AM (when they open) the place is freakin' mobbed and highway robbery for the admission.  (Not to mention $15.00 ($18 for us - we sprung for "elite" parking) for parking and $15 to rent a locker - which was a much needed evil.

Long lines for every attraction.  Water rides were PACKED.  There is no shade.  ROASTING!

I told the toddler - as she sleepily collapsed into her car seat with visions of Elmo dancing thru her pretty little head that she best remember this happy day for the rest of her life, because Mama ain't NEVER comin' back.

I had not been back in over 2 years - so 2 ladies from my office and I had lunch here.  Good but not great.  It also took a long time (15 -20 minutes) for the lunch to come out (nobody ordered apps nor drinks and we were on a strich time frame).

My fried-green-tomato blt was great!  But the side of green beans with tomatoes was nearly inedible.  I chose green beans as a healthy alternative to fries, but they came swimming in oil and loaded with a salty spice blend.  NOT what I was expected.  Next time I'll order them steamed or plain.

Also they gave each of us a $2.50 up charge for subbing a different side for fries.  Not the end of the world, but it would have been nice to know that before we ordered - and not as an added "bonus" when the bill came.

Meanwhile, I'll be back but I won't rush back.
Years ago I loved it here - but over the years it seems less thrilling.

This appears to be the Starbux inside the Target.
They are remodeling the store and closed it down for a bit but are reopening any minute now.  No real issues here - but I come at "off" times.

I am a Saladworks gal - but this location is just OK - I have seen better (and worse) in size, layout and cleanliness.

That said the ingredients are usually fresh enough - I had a spinach-based salad with shrimp & artichoke hearts.  $10 every time I go.

Super crowded during the weekday lunch rush - go before 11:40 AM or after 1:30 PM.

We had a very different experience from Mark J. below.  My husband ordered a whole small pie (baked fresh to order) - took over half of it home - of the "meat lovers" pizza - topped with ham, bacon, pepperoni, sausage and meatball slices.  (heart attack on a pie)  It definitely was not frozen.

I had a small veal parm sandwich light on the cheese.

The place was empty on a Tuesday night - and the pizza was good (not NYC quality - but HELLO - it's the PA suburbs) and the veal parm was on a great-tasting Italian roll.

No complaints here.
And they deliver to Wallingford!

Ah yes, the Dublin DQ - brings back pre-teen memories from the '80's.  And today the place has not changed all that much - still crammed in the summertime with fat, white mommas and their 2-3 kids in tow getting cones and such.

Cheap, soft-serve and mediocre fast food.

But when your 11?  It's a blast!

I stopped in for a quick polish change at 6:30 on a Monday (they apparently close at 7).  They tried to talk me into a mani ($13) and the polish change was $10.

The lady who did my nails (I honestly can't remember her name - she told me and I promtply forgot) seemed a bit disinterested and ready to call it a day.  Fortunately she did a decent job on the nails.

I also sprung for $15 (15 minutes) of chair massage.  It wasn't bad - not a "real" Licensed Masasge Therapy massage, but it was relaxing and I needed it.

I am hoping my polish lasts a long while.  I am only on day 2 so I will let y'all know.

Based on the other people's reviews I am not sure if I would gamble a pedicure here - but they do have about 5 pedi thrones and they looked "visually" clean.  The salon is big and has clean, wood floors.

A little more expensive than Nails by Chau or City Nails on the Square.

Oh - and the offer OPI Axxium gel nails.  Haven't had the courage to try this yet.  not sure how much they charge - and I won;t get them done here anyway when I do take the plunge.

I admire what Katie Cavuto is tyring to do here - especially in this area of the city.
However, nothing really appealed to me other than the $2.25 bottles of hint water (which I bought immediately).

Couscous looked good - but too expensive.
Love that they carry Griggstown Farm products.

Wish it looked more appealing.
And was more affordable - but the prices reflect the organic and higher-priced ingredients.

$10 minimum for credit cards.

We drop lots of money at Target - and this is the first time we tried this one.  We sure came on a BAD day!  The center of the store was all roped off due to water damage - and there were water-pumps and fans humming loudly.

So we got what we needed (lots of paper goods and cleaning products) and left.

Yech.

Got my hair and my MOH's hair and makeup done here for my June 2008 wedding.  Got a feeling the gal who did my hair is not there any more.

Prices were fair, and the ladies were very nice but NOT the most talented hairdressers.  In fact, the lady who did my trial did such a bad job I got a different person for the actual wedding day (who was much better.

They did do a better job on my friends hair and her makeup looked nice.

Going to a prom or wedding?  This is an OK choice.  But not mind blowing.

The also have nail services.

Hey - it's a Wawa and was there when we needed it.
Cigarettes, bottled water and wait - Girl Scout Cookies?  Sold out of somebody's trunk in the parking lot.
And the DO have a parking lot.

Yay Wawa.

It's convenient - and the Gallery Mall is right above it.
Pretty dirty, though - the bathrooms are awful.

This place should be called the Philadelphia Dosa Co. - they are really skimpy with the chutney - you get 1 little container (there are about 6 to choose from), and can purchase more.

Service is just OK.  Prices are fine.  Good for lunch - not great for dinner.
Oh - and they do not have any ice (We wanted some for our water - it was so hot in there (it's been a heatwave all this week in Philly).  The sell only bottled drinks - so no ice is available.

I tried the #7 - Avocado, Arugula, Tomato and what??  American Cheese?
WTF?  WHo puts cheese in a dosa?  And American at that? Kraft Singles?

Whatever.

The idli were lightly steamed and fluffy - easy to eat.

A nice addition to the culinary landscape - but by no means a holy grail.
A good choice for vegetarians. (Hold the American, please!)

OMG - sooooo busy on a crowded Saturday around 1 PM.
Meanwhile got a much -needed oil change.  No issues.

The food tastes fine - and the cafeteria style of "design your own" burritos, tacos and quesadillas is catching on fast -but don't be fooled.  It's still fast food - and it is super-duper HIGH in calories.  A typical burrito has 1100 - 1600 calories.  (Naked will reduce it by 330 - as the PLAIN TORTILLA is 330 whopping calories alone.)

That said - I do enjoy the Naked Chicked Burrito, no cheese, small (70 cal) taco-sized torilla on the side.

It's just too hard for me to "hold the guac" and save 220 calories.  That guac - for fast food guac tastes muy bien to me.

By the way - I think Jack-in-the-box owns Qdoba - I know Chipotle is owned by McDonalds.

FAST FOOD - people.
Eat under a health advisory.

Note:  In the summer they make a very tasty mango salsa.  You can get it on ANY burrito if you ask.

I have gotten 3 oil changes here over the past 18 or 20 months and there is always a wait.  It gets busy.  I have tried lunch hour (bad idea), Saturday (worse idea) and after work (not as bad as lunch, but maybe that is because I don't feel the stress of having to rush back to the office in under an hour).

Staff is competent and prices are fair.

No issues and so far I will keep coming back.
Gonna try a random time (like 10:30 on a Tuesday or 2:30 on a Thursday) one of these days to see if it is any less crowded.
Ollie's is a hit or miss place for housewares, beauty products, books, cleaning supplies, non-perishable food items.  It's "odd lots" of stuff that changes for any or no reason.

A very cute "strip mall" salon with a clean reception area and Kerastase Products for sale.
Prices were too high ($38 for a blowout - no use of flat iron) for me to justify coming here. I spent $25 for a blowout - no upcharge to use flat iron. (And in Center City I spent $30).

I would like to inquire about other services/prices but they have no web site.
Good news - they take walk ins.

Of all the places in Philly why, oh why, would I ever come here?
Three words.

Fifty Dollar Gift-card.

Or is that 4 words (2 words and a compound word?)?

Yes, folks, I won a $50 gift card good at ANY Hard Rock location from a charity auction so a good-sport friend (I love her - and she put up with Hard Rock well) and I decided to play cheap-meal roulette.

I read the menu online before we went and luckily, they sat us is the back room (the Philadelphia room) which is much less loud and crowded.

Our self-effacing server, Stewart, was attentive and kind - especially since I can be such a pain in the a$$.  I ordered a pomegranate martini and ask for it NOT to contain Sierra Mist.  (I mean, really, Sierra Mist?)  The $8.50 martini was basically vodka, Monin Pomegranate Syrup and seltzer.  It was fine and I was able to cultivate a buzz in about 12 minutes.

My friend wisely chose the shrimp fajitas which were served on a sizzling platter and tasted pretty good.  I poorly chose a great steak which was so gristly I had to send it back.  Poor, Stewart took it back and the next one they brought was at least edible.

But flavorless.

I literally had to put salt and pepper on it and was eyeing the A-1 (I HATE A-1!).
A good steak should have flavor on its own.  Maybe that's why they put "Cabernet butter" aka Country Crock on all the grilled items?

Anyhow - dessert was a BOMB. Over sweet cheesecake on a cardboard and wood-shaving crust.  Do not even think about getting the syrup-ed-out creme brulee here.
At least it was cheap ($2.99 for the dessert "bites")

Believe it or not - I am giving them 3 stars (they really deserve 2) because they were very accomodating to all of our requests and we had a fun time.

Would I come here again?
Not unless I had another gift card - and even then - I think I would re-gift!

7-Eleven is so old skool, but this particular location has saved us with a Sunday NY Times on more than one occaision.

I don't buy any food nor beverage items here.

Just grab an old-skoool printed newspaper and leave.

Wawa country, indeed - see Steven B.'s review - he is "spot on".

Average food, service and décor with average University City prices.
Tomato soup was good, Cobb Salad was just OK.  Brunch items looked like a better choice but I am low carb and many entrees were super high in carbs and/or calories.

Crowded  even on a Sunday for brunch.

Family Friendly (Surprised at how many little kids were here in addition to the college crowd.)

Good but not great.
A safe choice.

Stopped in to reminisce about old friends and the "old" Doylestown at Nat's - what better a place?  Tim was off (it was on a Sunday) but the pizza slice my daughter had was fine, and the cherry water ice (kid's size is prlenty) turned the children's mouths red.

Nice to see it's the same as I remember - even though so much about Doylestown has changed.

Nat's is a D-town institution.

Sooooooo hard to get an appointment here - and no late nights or weekends.  We came at 9 AM as a walk in and were turned away.  Very hard for parents who work - my teen comes here for birth control and preventive health care.

We love and support Planned Parenthood but it is darned difficult to get seen.

The doctors (once you get to see one) and practitioners are excellent and knowledgeable.

Parents:  educate your kids about reproductive health.  It is so very important to maintain an open dialogue from an early age.  Prevent STI's, unplanned pregnancies, abusive situations and so much more.

Sex is not a bad word.  Talk to your kids about sex.  Openly.
Now.

I went here 2 years ago - exactly ONCE.
My former co worker just LOVES this place and comes here regularly - for all sorts of things - even their overpriced manis & pedis (They wanted alot more than I pay at my "regular" nail bar).

Anyhow it's a lovely salon and the gal who did my hair (I forgot her name) was good, but for the price?
Nope.

Can't do it.

Upgrading to 2 or 3 stars as I finally got to eat a mediocre meal here.
Service was much better - our server Melissa was a doll, but I had a rotten avocado sliced all over the salad I ordered.  Blargh!  They comped dessert to make up for it.

French onion soup (in a chicken stock??? Sysco chicken base?) was on the salty side, but good.

I think I have given up on Minella's.

It's not horrible - maybe I' should have given it 3 stars?  It's been around forever - and has the cliched Monday night "colonial Kitchen" and King Henry's feast.  The chicken pot pie tastes like it was made with frozen veggies.  I have never been too impressed with Cock 'n Bull's dining room meals (nor brunch - which is tourist0filled and pricey.)

That being said - we actually had a CATERED event here in the summer of 2004 - my baby shower.  It happened to be great.  Well managed by Peddler's Village staff and the food was actually GREAt - 3-4 stars for chicken francese, fresh, crisp buttery green beans and caesar salad were stand outs.

OK.  I'll relent and give it 3 stars.  2 for dining room meals and 4 for catered events.

Hell, it's been around for eh ver!  (In junior high we'd call it the cock and balls.)

I honestly don't know WHAT to review.
My husband hated it - too high priced for him and old, dated decor and "meh" food to him.  Our 8 year old loved it - but she only had a $5 Bindi (pre-fab) frozen Coconut Gelato (served in a coconut shell).  We love those Bindi desserts - and so does half the restaurant world!

I enjoyed my food - Fettucine with Chicken in a pink sauce with a few peas (wish there were more). The dish is supposed to come with rigatoni but I asked to sub fettucine which they did.  Portion was small - but the sauce is very rich so I was fine with it - even though el kiddo nabbed a good 1/3 of it!  (Ha ha!  She loved it here.) Oh - and the dinner rolls, while served hot, were a bit stale (sorry).

The meatballs my husband had were just ok.  Kinda bready.  The ones I make are better (sorry, Gennaro), but the service here is better than Casa Prego.  Food is about the same and some things are less expensive here and others are more.

It has been in business since 1992 (according to the menu) and they need a makeover STAT.

Other than that it is a quiet, family-friendly spot with classic, "old-skool" Italian-American fare circa 1974.  And I kinda dig it.

Won't rush back - but I will be back - so please take note - and I pray things will have improved when I do.

Classic
Italian American
Family Friendly
Medium Priced (Could argue too high on certain items, very fair on others.)
Small - seats 50 max - largest table seats 6.
Family run.

Eatible Delights catered a meeting I attended on a Saturday in Center City.  they provided a nice continental Breakfast but lunch was just Meh.  Lunch boxes were a choice of sandwich (I picked tuna - and it was on soggy wheat bread) with packaged cookies, a piece of fruit (I got an apple - some folks got an orange or banana) and inedible pasta salad.

Disappointed in the lunch, happy with the basic breakfast.

Just like every other Manhattan Bagel - and in some ways, better than many.
A wide variety of bagels and spreads - to go.

Don't eat there.  

Staff works very quickly so know what you want.

Service is quick, but lines at lunchtime are very long. Be patient, they are doing their best.   CFA has now offered salads for a few years and I enjoy the Cobb Salad, no cheese, grilled chicken instead of fried nuggets.  It's still not healthy as it is loaded with bacon, but it tastes good.  The Avocado Lime Ranch dressing also tastes great, and adds on 310 cals per pack.  I try to use less, but sometimes I cave.

CFA is about the only fast food we eat. My vegan teen loves the waffle fries.

CFA is taking over the nation. I wish their political views were more in line with mine, but they just aren't.  Not LGBTQIA friendly.

I attended here in the mid nineties as a grad student at the School of Dental Medicine - and believe me, 3 stars is as generous as I can be.  I was harassed by a sadistic Bay Instructor, chased down Baltimore Avenue by "Hatchet Man" and generally had a miserable experience which may or may not have been the fault of the school.  Meanwhile, I got good grades - but transferred out to escape the scourge of West Philly at that time.  (It's alot nicer there now.)

I have a feeling the undergraduate experience would have been better.

Honestly, my expectations were very low and I fully expected Barnaby's in Havertown to suck.  (The one in Aston is just awful) Guess what?  It's didn't!!!!

We sat on the deck on a rainy Covid day at about 12 noon and had very tasty Irish coffees and standard bar food.  Prices were mid-range and surprisingly, service from Tina (she and one other lady were running the entire deck and bar) was good.  She is a doll - albeit way overworked.

I bet it gets crowded here on weekend nights.

Seems like an OK place for a happy hour.
A bit of a "frat -boy-turned-middle-aged-male" vibe.
Lots of big TVs for watching the Iggles.

Kudos to Tina.
Don't expect a top-tier dining experience - it's a BAR.  Totally a BAR.

$5 includes a soda or bottle of water and your choice of lamb or chicken gyro meat over rice or salad (I get salad which is iceberg, tomatoes, cucumbers, chickpeas and onion [optional]).  White sauce?  Hot Sauce?  Green Sauce?  Whatever yu wish.

Five bucks.

Not bad.

A bit overpriced and underwhelming.  The decor is very nice and service was fine, but the Steak Quesadilla was $10.99 (plus .65 - very cheap actually - for a small side of guac).

It tasted OK but for $12 ($15 with tip) that's a bit steep.

I would come back but I will not be running back there.

I brought my 4 year old daughter here for Dim Sum after the flower show, once we discovered that Ong's Noodle shop has closed.  We first tried Pho 75 but my dd wanted DUMPLINGS and Pho 75 doesn't have them.

Joy Tsin Lau sure does.  We had Har Gow (excellent), Shiu Mai (just OK) and Steamed Dumploings - very heavy/doughy with vile, bone-chip-laden, mystery meat filling.  BLECH!

Meanwhile, we also ordered Chicken fried rice with extra scambled egg - and dd loved that.  An enormous plateful for 5.95 - took alot home.

They treat us very well - but the digs are ancitent and the bathroom was freezing cold and FILTHY.  The floor was literally sticky.  Eeeeeeew!

1-2 stars for the dining digs and 3-4 stars for food (but skip the dumplings on the menu and get dim sum.)

You pick your seats in advance (online) and order food and drinks (full bar) when you get there.
Food is sub par and way over priced.

Movie experience was fine.

Movie tavern is a hair better but also sub par food (like an Applebee's) and pricey.

The kiddo loves it, so we continue to go.

It's pretty small and there are lots of homeless who gather here - but when they have an event it can be very nice on a warm summer evening.  Philly needs its green spaces - so I am glad its here - I just wish we could help our homeless community more.

My 5 y.o. is frightened by many of them.

This is my go-to CVS as it is nearest my house.
The (one and only) guy at the cashier was cute and also personable.

I had run-in to get Cadbury Cream eggs (not for me - really- for my boss.  I am trying to butter him up.  Seriousy - I don't  eat that $h!t.) and he told me exactly where to go.

Not bad.

Will be back.

I actually had a good experience here.  When I cam - about 7 PM on a Wednesday night - the place was nearly empty and I had a great cooked to order chicken cutlet sandwich.
The food was great and the side salad I also ordered had fresh (iceberg) lettuce and lots of nice tomatoes and cucmber slices.

I would definitely pick up another quick meal here.  Npot sure about the pizza - the slices didn't appeal.  Maybe a whole pie - freshly baked would be a better option.

Considering the limited amount of dining choices in the (dying) SPringfield Mall, my 8 year old was excited to get a chicken cutlet sandwich from Tony Lukes.

It was fine - but nothing to write home about.
I know Tony Luke (and his lovely new-ish girlfriend) and have eaten at the Oregon Avenue location many times.  It rocks.

This location does not rock.
But it is affordable and a viable alternative to the other mall choices.

2 or 3 tops.  Run of the Mill off the rack mens suits and separates.
If you don't care about looking like everybody else - or have little fashion sense or interest - then shop here.

It is CHEAP.  (And it can show!)

CM is like PC (Plato's Closet) but for grown-ups.
I boil everything I buy (or dryclean it).

That said, you can sift through the racks and sometimes find nearly new or tags-on-new clothing at a fraction of the price.

Caveat Emptor, baby.
Happy Hunting.

Too expensive but I wash in a pinch and needed gas N.O.W.
They also have a car wash.

No issues.

3 stars is really stretching it.
I have never, ever, EVER been an Outback fan - but my parents seem to love it there for some reason.

Anyhow, a female co-worker/friend suggested it so we went for a very early dinner at 4:30 PM.

The good part was because we were so early the place was empty and we got decent service.  The food?  Sub-par at best.  The best bite of the night was the steamed broccoli (which was loaded with butter, I think.)  Everything is oversalted/overseasoned.

I ordered the 10 oz. ribeye, rare - and it was tasty but way, way too salty.  Had I known (or remembered - as I have not been to an Outback since 2012) I would have asked for lightly seasoned. Supermarket quality steaks.  Definitely not Choice and NOT Prime meats here. It's a CHAIN, people.

The "steakhouse" mac & cheese was a salt lick.  Inedible to the point I had to send it back.
I asked for plain cavatappi pasta in its place.  PLAIN.  It came drenched in butter.


So if you are like most of middle America and like over-buttered, over-salted, heavily caloric food?  This is your place.

Meanwhile - we all ate and all survived.
I can grill a better steak dinner myself at home.
Seriously.

Always a long line during the weekday lunch rush.  I bide my time in line by picking through the toss-displays of umbrellas and boxer shorts.  Oh - and a sample of DREAM or HEAVEN if they have the testers out.

I have found good deals here - and it is an outlet so pickings can be slim.

If you are patient and don't mind a complete LACK of customer service, you may be able to find some decent clothing here for your kid or yourself.

I get socks here when I can find the kind i like - they are $7.50 a pair at the "regular" GAP and $3-4 a pair here.  SAME exact merch.  Just cheaper.

I love that!

I have only gotten juice here - not any food - but for juice (if 4 seasons is closed - which is was) in a pinch this place is fine. (Smoothies and fruit juices, a few vegetable choices).

Nice selection of middle eastern parties, too.

With so many choices in the RTM - this one is not up too high on the list - but seems OK.
Been here for years!

It's basically a pizzzaria - with BRIGHT orange & yellow decor.  It is mobbed with families and toursts (and tourist families) who have no rel lower priced options in Peddler's Village or Penn's Purchase.  A quick slice of pizza and a drink - and use the bathroom - and off you go to shop some more.

I wish they would have been more accomodating to us - as we had planned to take a large group here for my daughter's birthday.
No reservations on weekends.  Whatever.

It's OK.  And it's there.

Stopped in here for all things - breakfast?  A freshly grilled laffa with egg & cheddar.
A little light on the veggies - it was early in the AM and nothing was prepped yet.

I will come back and try them at lunch time.

Laffa was super fresh (grilled to order) and tasty.

I really want to give them higher marks as this GORGEOUS (large) facility has enormous potential, a top-ranked chef and a fabulous sounding menu.  Service was good, but dish execution had too many things wrong to be ignored.

My Kir Royale was made with flat prosecco - I clearly got the last of an opened bottle, but that is even forgivable if the meal was good.

My husband's dish was excellent - if a bit over-sauced (tender, home-made Cavatelli in s rosa/blush sauce).  I would discover first hand how heavy they pour the olive oil. I ordered the burrata of the day (m.p. was $17 - OUCH - but OK.) but that was NOT what was brought to me.

Instead i got a "doctored up" caprese - and I am a HUGE fan of caprese so I agreed to accept the (beautiful) plate and began to eat it.  Drowned in Olive oil, and the Plum tomato (served quarted) tasted fermented.  It was not visibly rotten - but it really, truly was.

I am happy to say they took the salad ($14) off the bill.
Please ease up on the sauce and oil!

Next time - and yes, there WILL be a next time - but not right away - I am getting a pasta (folks one table over had the pan-grilled chicken parm and another table ordered rigatoni with one enormous meatball) - they looked amazing.

This is really a 4 star place - and has potential to be a 5 star place - but we are off to a rocky start with 'Teca.

Oh - and the $8 Tira Misu in a mason jar is light as air and delectable.

Prices are far too high for this neck of the woods - but they have ALOT of overhead to pay for including party rooms and glorious pizza oven-bar that seats 16 and a HUGE cocktail bar, wine cellar and much more.  And they are STILL building.  WOW.

I am hoping they will make improvements and hit their stride soon.  We had a far better meal at the "original" West Chester "Teca in 2013.

See you in 5-7 months! (Can't afford sooner.)
This is a great special-occiasion or date (not neccessarily a first date) place.

Believe it or not I am pleasantly surprised in a good way by Rex's Pizza.  If you go from 5-7 PM Mon - Thurs you can get $1.00 slices and $2.50 beers.  My little daughter loves happy hour here - the slices not the beers!

I also got a tuna melt and a slice of Baklava to go one time.  The melt was really good.  Hot & fresh on rye bread.    The baklava was little dry.  I wouldn't get it again.

Meanwhile, this place is a little run-down and old-school (with plastic swivel chairs and orange booths.  But it's on our way from school to home - so for $1.00?  Ya can't beat it.  (Regular price $2.10 for a plain jumbo slice.)

Not sure how they are for take out - but i do know they have delivered MANy pizza's to my little one's old day care.  Every Wednesday was Rex pizza for lunch.

Oh - and the owner (maybe manager) guy is really nice.  And kinda cute - but he probably thinks I am waaaaay old.

A quick iced coffee from the kind Indian lady at the DD on the corner of 16 and I'm off...

This location is smaller than some.

Ok - I am being nice and giving 3 stars, but I really want to give them 2.
Don't get me started on UO.  We have a long post collegiate, complex relationship.  When they first opened and had only a few stores (I shopped at the one near Penn in the early 90's and will review that one soon) they seemed so cool.

Now it's a bit played out and man, they jacked up the prices.  I mostly get accessories and socks here now - the pants fall apart.  (And for 60 bux??)

Oh I miss the good old days.  It seemed better back then.

Penn's Purchase is not like it was by long shot.  The Eitienne Aigner outlet is gone.  Many of the outlets are not really that discountred anymore.  But I still go to the Aerosoles and Leggs/Hanes/Bally outlets.  Just never at Xmas time.  The place is a mad house of displace New Yorkers.

Loved it more a few years back - still like it, just miss my old faves.

This is now my go-to local Walgreen's.
So far it';s been just OK.  

Yes, the store is clean and well run.  Plenty of parking.
Not crowded.

But - they did not have my medication in stock (to be fair they got it in the next day and I did not have an urgent need for it), but it was inconvenient to have to stop by twice.

Meanwhile - the 2 female pharmacists I have spoken to were both great.

I'll be back.

A sub-par Chipotle with a "long, skinny" weird  layout and not enough trash receptacles.  They seem incapable of making a Quesadilla here - stick to the burritos and bowls.

Not awful but I won't be rushing back.

Fast food at its classic mediocrity.

We had a vey nice experience on a CROWDED summer Sunday around noon ish - we had a party of 6 and were amazed at how short the wait was -  it could have been much worse.

We all ordered different breakfasty things - Croissant sandwiches were a big hit. 

I had crepe - real crepes (actually just one big one) stuffed with FRESH sliced strawberries (not strawberry glop) and sliced fresh banana.  So good!

A nice gathering place with a salad bar and all the diner staples.
Parking lot was JAMMED with cars.

Ah, yes, the Chinatown Wawa.  It's a Wawa folks, so it's got smokes, drinks, junky snacks and most everything you need in a pinch.

This one is usually crowded (right near the bus station and the Gallery) and a little grungy.

I wanted to love it.  Really, I did.
I had the fried Chicken, mac 'n cheese and collard greens.
After all, if OPRAH loves their Mac (and I think she won against Bobby Flay in a mac smack-down), then so should I, right?!

All were they way they are supposed to be.  (By the book) 
But the mac was way too heavy - and I didn't happen to get any of that good crust on the top layer.

The chicken was sooooo salty.  Like eating saltines in the Sahara.
And very, very greasy (but hell - it is FRIED chicken.)

The greens were perfect.

I give them a 3 stars for food and the grotty digs of 30th Street.

This is a smaller outpost of Rita's with a few places to park and friendly teenaged gals running the show during peak summer months.  Our 8 year old loves it and a kiddie size is perfect (plenty) for her or for me.

Custard, water ice, blendinis - yum!

We like the Ria's in Aston a touch more for the big parking lot, though.

They're there when you need them for smokes, snacks and coffee.
Decent location and service.

It has everything you need for crafts at reasonable prices.  A good place for DIY wedding favors, kids crafts, art projects, framing and more.  And I am not one for glue guns - but wow - such a selection.

The staff is underpaid and pretty disinterested - so do your own research and then buy your stuff and move on.  There is a nice selection of Crayola and other kids craft items.

The lines on weekends can be painfully long at holiday times.

Service by Drew (Andrew) for out group of 6 ladies was terrific.  The food itself?  Meh.  Overpriced and not healthy.  But meanwhile we had a grand time and this is a mid-priced option for a girls night.

Relaxing (we went on a Monday evening and the theatre was nearly empty) and you can drink alcohol (albeit overpriced mid-grade stuff) and eat (calorie laden "fun foods") and watch a flick.

No issues.

I am seriously not kidding when I tell you that I came here with my (now) husband when we were dating and could absolutely not get any privacy.  

We stayed for one night only - maybe 6 hours really - and found the room to be clean and comfortable.

Don't ask, don't tell.

Garden Bar and 2 sliders (I got 1 beef and 1 turkey) comes with fries - I subbed mac 'n cheese for 1.99 more - NOT GOOD.  Gloppy Cheese-Wiz/Velveeta with 5-6 flabby elbows buried.

Meanwhile, the garden bar/salad bar was surprisingly good.
Beef slider was nice, turkey on was dry (Granted for both I requested mayo and ketchup on the side).

High calorie, moderately priced, bug portions.
Middle-American "safe' chain foods which I usually loathe.

Had a surprisingly decent time here.
(This is the one in Springfield Mall - there is also one at Granite Run Mall).

$8.95.  (Plus $1.99 - but I would not do that ever again!)

Pagano's is A-OK - just as yelp 3 star joints are.  An over-priced salad/hot food bar.  Good soups, pricey platters of hot food (often chicken cutlets and pasta) and pizza.  Plenty of seating and boy do they need it during the lunch rush.

A vast selection of yuppified bottled beverages.
