Great if you work at Commerce Square - especially on a snowy or rainy day.  Convenient.

Lots of options, priced a bit high.
I do not buy smoothies here but for a bowl of cut fruit they are fine - my 8 year old likes the pineapple and strawberries cut up in a bowl.

I am assuming this is the Starbucks on the lower lever of the Target at Springfield Mall?  If so - I had a perfectly acceptable experience here - ordered my usual Venti light ice green tea lemonade.

No issues.

Fourbucks aka Charbucks is pretty standardized.

I went on a weekday morning and it was not crowded - but I have seen it on weekends and it can get busy.

I do not like shopping here.  The produce is never what I want - or it's wilted.  The prices are OK for somethings, but that Freezer (frozen food) section is like navigating a maze.

Not a fan.

Super crowded on a Saturday Morning around 11.
Waiting in a very long line - and then again to pick up each hand-pulled drink.

Just OK as S-Bux goes.  But I was jonesin' for a $5 latte.

A great place to see a show (downstairs at any rate.)  We got great seats for Black47 and had dinner there pre-show.  The food was Irish themed (for Black47 and it was March 16!!!)

I thought my "boiled" dinner of corned beef and cabage was good.
The rest of the menu was typical bar food.  Not great - but not inedible as others have said.

The show itself was great and we had a balcony front row sofa to sit on - and beer to drink.

No problems for me.

I shopped here today and altough i wound up not buying anything - I did try on about 8-10 pieces and LOVED 2 of them.  Lisa, the sales associate, was very helpful fetching my size and I felt bad tat I did not buy the $118 jeans - nor the $488 mauve/grey dressy jumpsuit.  I just can't justify the prices right now.

But it was fun to get some new fashion ideas.  I loved the dresses.  So flowy and light.

Shopped here for dresses today - and Ann, was very helpful.  While I did not purchase the dress I liked most (it was $458 which is too high for me), I will check back in a few months to see if it goes on sale.  

I absolutely LOVE the dresses here - light, flowy fabrics and fabulous fit.  (If they have your size.)

Of course, by the time it's on sale my size (fat cow 10) will probably be gone.

I fel very fat when I shop here as usually they only go up to size 10 or 12 and they are usually gone.   If you are a size 4 or smaller (lucky, lucky, you) you'll have better luck.

Are you a big girl?  Don't come here!

It's hit or miss at Daffy's for me.  I usually miss, but when I hit, I hit big and it's usually Children's clothes or shoes (women's or kids in my case.)  I have scored some fine Italian-made kids wear for a fraction of retail here.

If they HAPPEN to have the size you need - you're golden.  Otherwise - don't count on much help from the under-paid, under-educated staff.  The lines at lunchtime can move at a snail's pace - so come after work or when you have time to check out.

And don't miss the shoe department.  I got some Timberland Sandals (one season late) that I still love to wear.

I am split on Sa Va - I like some of the designs and want to support sustainable sources for clothing, but I just haven't found anything I actually WANT to buy here.

Fun to browse though - and when I see it - I'll snatch it up.

And I thought the owner was very nice.

They are right near UrbanFront Pilates - so I hit them up on my way to or from class.

It's soooooo old school that it's actually fun to come here once every couple of years.

I attended a group meeting here and the upstairs banquet rooms are FULL of history.  The meals are like eating at a 1978 wedding or a 1983 prom.  COmplete with pre-set iceberg based salads, white dinner rolls with no nutritional value, and surprisingly tasty salmon with 55 gallon drum hollandaise sauce.

I actually get a big kick out of coming here - not because the food is so great (it's really not) but for the walls that reek with history.  (There are pictures of proms and highschool reunions from the 50's - and lawyers/legal assocaition meetings, and other stuff.) 

Such a cool places with old-school service and food.

And a reasonably priced place to host a group function.

Even my daughter (age 7) agrees that the yogurt here is 3 star - not as good as tutti frutti or yogorino.  On par with Sweet Ending.

The sushi is just "meh" - we tried the tuna triangle, BBQ Chicken triangle and shrimp nigiri.
Harmless enough.

If you come after 5 everything is discounted.
Manager is very kind to us.

Over-priced and OVER hyped.  I have not yet tried SKIN CARE SERVICES here.  A massage, however, is fine - its not as practitioner dependent.  I had one from IKE - and he is a gifted healer.

The product lines for hair and skin are upper-tier (and full retail prices, of course.) and the receptionist was professional without being "icy".

But for $100?  I can get more mileage from Ananda or my fave, Body Restoration.

They also offer nail services, but I have not yet tried these either.

Completely against my better judgement I stopped into this grotty looking nail joint just off of Market Street.  I got a mani/pedi ($25_) and prayed that nothing fungal would happen to me.

So far, the pedicure g-ds have been with me.  No problems.  A decent, sheap mani/pedi - but the place looks pretty awful anf the nail tech spoke almost Zero english.

Oh - and it was DEAD empty (just me and then toward the end of my services another lady came in for a mani/pedi.  On a summer Wednesday.

Old Navy is Disposable Clothing,  The Gap's low-end merch. The dis-interested, underpaid staff has a n "I'm too busy stocking to talk to you" vibe here - but all in all you can still get mass-produced, el-cheapo clothing here.

I very rarely get anything for myself at ON - the snooty law firm folks I work with could sniff that out in a minute.  Instead, I lavish my pre-schooler with $5.00 sneakers and 2 for ten jammy sets.  Oh and socks - love the cheap socks.

t's soooooo old school that it's actually fun to come here once every couple of years.
A Media tradition - has been here for-eh-ver! (Some of the waitresses have worked here over 30 years and you can tell.

I attended a group meeting here and the upstairs banquet rooms are FULL of history.  The meals are like eating at a 1978 wedding or a 1983 prom.  COmplete with pre-set iceberg based salads, white dinner rolls with no nutritional value, and surprisingly tasty salmon with 55 gallon drum hollandaise sauce.

I actually get a big kick out of coming here - not because the food is so great (it's really not) but for the walls that reek with history.  (There are pictures of proms and highschool reunions from the 50's - and lawyers/legal assocaition meetings, and other stuff.) 

Such a cool place with old-school service and food.

And a reasonably priced place to host a group function.

Honestly, this was fine.
Needed bottled water desperately and 7-11 was there.

Got in, got out, got hydrated.

Done.

I want to love it here - but the sushi is just Meh.  My salmon roll had no taste and husband's tuna nigiri was "not as fresh as it could have been".  Stick to the Thai dishes and you will be OK.  But even those need some tweaking - Tom Kha ($6 for chicken $7 for shrimp) was loaded with onions.  So. Many. Onions.  The Pineapple fried rice was tasty - but a bit greasy and again - so. many. onions.

Yes, it's winter.  Yes, onions are cheap.  But carrot, onion and a bit of zucchini is not enough for me.  I need some more green veggies - broccoli?  Peppers?  Something?

No more Thai iced coffee either.  *Sad Face*.

I like it here but I do not love it here.  
Every few years I come back and remind myself why.

I was dragged here again tonight by the inlaws who desperately wanted that 2 for $20 deal.  Honestly - the food, service & cleanliness were all way, way better than in the past.  I still loathe chain restaurants - and even moreso loathe crowds, but tonight wasn't too terrible from a culinary perpective.

The frantic (almost) 5 year old had a $4.99 hot dog (what a rip) with a cup of applesauce and an OJ.  The inlaws had a 2 for 20, as did my husband and I.  I played it safe with a burger - which was edible and not bad.  DH's chicken cheese penne was overly salted and the noodles were over cooked (so NOT al dente).

The inlaws split a vat of Spinach dip and MIL had a rather sweet 1/2 rack of baby back ribs.  FIL did not like the Quesedilla burger, because the tiny burger pattie was lost in the vast recesses of the large floppy torilla.  

Oh well.

At least the kid didn't scream.  Plus the 5 of us escaped from Applebee's for around $50.  Not bad.

I won't rush back but I expect to be summoned here yet again next summer.  I think once a year is far too often.

Thai food was excellent but sushi last night was just "meh".
My 10 year old did not like her maki but I loved the Tom Kha (sup) and Dumplings I had.

I still love it here but can no longer take the kid here.

Service was terrific.

It has everything you need for crafts at reasonable prices.  A good place for DIY wedding favors, kids crafts, art projects, framing and more.  And I am not one for glue guns - but wow - such a selection.

The staff is underpaid and pretty disinterested - so do your own research and then buy your stuff and move on.

The lines on weekends can be painfully long at holiday times.

Just OK.  Great concept though and big comfy seats with tray-tables so that you can dine (in total darkness) while watching a flick.

The bad part?  Awful formula-cooking food cum Applebee's-meets'TGI Friday's served by dis-interested twenty-somethings.  The good part?  You can't actually see that horribly wilted salad in the dark theater.

Meanwhile, my 10 year old went gaga for this place so we shall return.
Oh - and they serve booze.

There are Qdoba people, Chipotle people, El Fuego People and none of the above.

I am more a Qdoba (sans tortilla, sans cheese, try to get the calorie count down).

Meanwhile, Chipotle (which is now corporate fast food owned) is an inexpensive and FILLING (even the salad or bowl options are HUGE) lunch or quick dinner.

Their meats (Chicken & Beef are the only ones i have tried) are spicier (more peppers??) than Qdoba.  Also they use white meat - Qdoba uses thighs.

It's OK by me.  A-OK - in the true yelp 3 star way.

This location is new and relatively clean (crowded at lunch time on weekdays - deserted at dinner.).

The service was great but we happened to come just before the shop was going to close for a week-long vacation, so the shelves were nearly empty - which is actually a good sign that they make everything fresh.

My 9 year old bought a $2.00 White Chocolate (confection) Golf Ball-shaped lollipop and she enjoyed it.

Can't wait to come back at Easter or Christmas and see everything they make.

Limited hours - so be aware of that.

Hart's Tavern - right in PV servs an important purpose - to give shoppers an alternative place to grab a bite and a brewski at a place OTHER than the Cock 'n Bull.

I miss Jenny's - the old restaurant that is now Earl's Prime.  (Don't get me started) and Hart's is easier to deal with than the spotted hog - which is loaded with strollers.

You can get a decent (if overpriced) sandwich here and chill out for a while before returning to the throngs of holiday shoppers.

Barnaby's is simply a bar.
That serves food.

It can also accomodate large and rowdy groups.

We came on a relatively quiet Monday night (thank goodness) with our 7 year old who promptly told me she hates it there.  DH & I both had half priced burgers (Which for $4.50 each was a great bargain.)

Service was fine - nice young gal.
Food was unremarkable.

Not my cup of tea, but I bet we'll be back - it's very close to our new house.
Decent coffee and a few sandwiches and snack items.  Plus:  It was actually open at 4 PM.  (Most places close at 3.  UGH!)
Closed.  I didn't think they'd make it and they have closed

We took our 7 year old to a performance of "Hershel and the Hanukkah Goblins".
The facilities are not as nice as the Arden, and the performance was not as good.

We love to support the arts and will continue to attend plays here, but we really like the Arden better - especially since tickets here were also not cheap $25 for adults and $16 for kids for this particular show.

Also there are no refreshments offered - so bear that in mind when you come.

This place is both dated and weird.  And I KNOW Madams Saito (I went to Dental school with her son years ago).  She was, back in the day, the sushi queen.  Now her place is in serious need of a makeover - menu and decor wise.  

The sushi was just "meh" and we did not care for the "french" (was that really french?) items we tried. 

Sorry to be so negative - and my 3 stars are generous - but it's time to get with the times, Mme!

A decade later and Suburban station has improved a wee bit.
A few more restaurants to choose from and better lighting on the track level.

Still a bunch of creepy characters and the restroom is awful.

We need to invest in our public transportation in America.
So grateful from SEPTA, AMTRAK, MTA, LIRR and the worst of the lot?  NJ Transit.  You think SEPTA is bad?  It is terrific compared to NJT.

Even though I am NOT a cheese steak lover (I rarley eat them - maybe 1-2 times a year), and I like Jim's better than Pat's, I prefer Pat's to Geno's.

I am also friends with a member of the Olivieri family - so I have to like Pat's better,

I order (quickly) a chicken cheessteak 'wit provolone and 'shrooms.

Too bad it's always so packed there's nowhere to eat. What a greasy mess!

I passed by this place in Suburban Station on my way to work so I tried the breakfast scrambler (no tots) and for $4 (and change) it was fine - nothing orgasmic - but the bacon was nice and crispy.  Not enough tomato, even though I asked for extra tomato in lieu of the tots.

Would not rush back here.

Service was medium (not fast, not slow - a few minutes to make it fresh - do not come if you are rushing).  Guy behind the counter was very nice.

This place is carverous and huge.  That said they had a limited amount of cashiers at the main entrance so be prepared, there may be aline if you dd not pre-purchase your tickets.

Theater itself (we were in Theatre 3) was actually clean and comfortable and a bit on the smaller side.  Loud audio and reclining chairs.

No issues.

It OK.  A welcome D-town neighborhood edition - and on Spring and Summer weekend mornings, the joint is jumpin'!  They offer bagels in a variety of flavors and a selection of cream cheeses and spreads.  

Your basic bagel type fare.  Good - but not mind-blowing.

I have had one massage and one chiropractice adjustment here.
The massage was fine.  I did not like the adjustment at all.  The Dr. was totally different than the woman I used to see in New York.

I wll not likely return.

They also offerr yoga classes - which sounds intriguing.

Interesting and strange combination of menu items.  Italian and "dinerish" and then sushi.  Whatever.

Meanwhile if you stick to the salads (huge and excellent) and sandwiches, byou'll be OK.  I did not care for the sushi here.   We ordered salads to go one time when we really needed food right before my wedding.  2 chicken caesars and 2 diet cokes were promptly delivered to a nearby hair salon and were we EVER grateful.

So thanks to Cafe Allesio for filling a need and serving up decent Italian fare (mediocre sushi) and AWESOME salads.

Returned in 2013 for the Pompeii exhibit which was - ok - kinda small. Just OK for me.
Our 9 year old enjoyed the day.

Many Exhibits were broken.

I think they need a boost,

Faux-juice bar.  The smoothies are loaded with calories.
I only get one thing here and that is fresh wheatgrass juice. And sometimes - it ain't all that fresh.

It's the closest to my old office - but unless you want a milkshake (Like the Mocha Blast) or another caloric treat - this is not a true juice bar.

Oh - the blond lady with the LONG colorful nails - who has worked here a long while - is a doll and very efficient.  She deserves a raise.

Great for a quick lunch to go (or eat in at high bar stools or on a summer day at one of 3 small outdoor tables.

Sushi is made daily in a refriogerated case, but they will make fresh maki and nigiri to order if you are willing to wait.  (It's worth the wait for fresh hamachi scallion maki or the "Honeymoon Roll" - a delish concoction of Shrimp Tempura inside and Salmon and Avo outside.

They cook Yalitori bowls, Bi-bim-bap, Udon, Teriyaki Boxes and Gyoza/Shumai (frozen) at the hot food station, too.

Good prices and great for a quick fix.

Tip:  Don't just grab the pre-packed sushi - have them roll your maki to order.  Much better that way!

The place is under construction/outdoor removation and it looks just awful, but inside Kiersten treated us well and the basic food was about the best I havve ever had at an Outback (I am not a fan).

Salad was fresh (Iceberg, 1/2'ed grape tomatoes, a few cubes of cucuumber and croutons).  steak was a bit overcooked (asked for medium Rare got medium).

El kiddo inhaled a 7 oz. salmon filet and broccoli.

When my 12 year old finished hunting through the carnage at Plato's Closet we stopped here to check out the shoes and active wear.  TJ Maxx can be "hit or miss" but when you hit, you can hit BIG.  

Snagged 2 pairs of sporty shorts and a pair of sandals just in time for summer for $46.

Yay!

This location is not as nice as some and yet much nicer thatn, say, the South Philly one.
3 stars.  Middle of the road.

I would give them 4 stars but they are closed in the afternoons/evening rush - so if you HAPPEN to be there in the morning this is a cute spot to grab a cup of coffee (or a latte or tea, etc.) before you get on the SEPTA train to Philly.

I sure wish they stayed open later.

I have come in and out of this store so many, many. many times.
And always empty handed.  And so much BLACK and white.  Don't you people know about color?

The service is kinda snotty and prices are just too high.

It's a shame.

You're KIDDING me?  4 & 5 star reviews for this place?

Really?

OK, it's better than La Tolteca - but it is not great.
It's MEH.  MEHxican.
It looks like an old Wawa or 7-11.
In fact - I am leaning more toward 2 stars - and here's why...

A good friend and I had lunch here - he had a "special" burrito stuffed with shrimp & chicken, covered in a cheese sauce and a green tomatillo salsa - not bad.

I had a mediocre "soft" chimicanga stuffed with beef tips.
Not horrible - but not great.

But what really got us were the chips 'n ketchup, I mean salsa.
This was NOT fresh salsa.  It was most definitely bottled and really tasted of canned tomatoes and vinegar.

It seemed like ketchup.

Weird.

Our server was a nice gal, but disappeared around "may we have the check, please" time.

If you are on a "lunch hour" don't come here.  It took us 70 minutes to have lunch.  Or at least tell them you are in a hurry.

So - if you want Mexican - avoid La Tolteca and only come to El Tapatio if you have no other alternatives.  And in this part of Delaware?  The MEH-xican American pickin's are slim.

Note:  Went back again.  Still 3 stars.  The chlicken flautas are good - but greasy.  Beef flauta was pretty bad.  Decent guac.  We'll probably be back again soon.

This is a BIG CVS right near the Uno Pizzeria in newtown Square.
I usually shop at CVS or Walgreen's for cosmetic and OTC medications.  This one has ample parking and is much nicer than the one in Paoli near my office.

It is also a but nicer than the Aston location but not as good as the Lima/Media location which i now consider my go-to CVS.

Not sure how late the pharmacy is open - many close earlier than I would prefer - especially when you have a sick kid in the middle of the night.

Break out your little red ExtraCare card and get to shoppin'!

Glad it's here.  Seems to have a more limited selection?  No Quesadillas?  Or at least not on the streamlined menu.  No matter... I wanted a naked burrito and they had it.  Fast service.  $9 no tax (it's DE!)

Prices are WAY too high to justify buying fancy-schmancy sandwiches and "gourmet picnic" type fare.

Just OK.

Not a fave.

I prefer Qdoba to Chipotle - but in a pinch this newly opened location (next door to a Starbucks, and down the strip from Trader Joe's) is OK for a quick bowl of carbs & fat.

The chicken was over cooked, so maybe next time I will try the steak.

Guacamole is good.

Totally average Dunkin.
When I went there was no line as it was about 2:30 PM on a weekday.

Got an iced coffee - got in and got out quick.

Better than expected and save for the milipede infestation (saw 3 of them in a one night stay) room was fine.  (Furniture in "living room" part of suite was a bit dated.

Bedroom was fine.

Food service is mediocre (banquet style catering) but the staff was friendly and helpful.

Came here for a conference - would not stay here otherwise.

Oversized and Overpriced - as Lori H. so succinctly said.
My DD and I went here for Shavuos/Shavuot and shared a single blintz ($5.00) which was overly stuffed with "meh" sweet cheese filling and served with "blueberry glop".  DD was upset - she wanted real fruit.  She's 6 - she knows what good is.  She told me later that she liked "last year's place" (Delicatessen - they no longer do dinner) better.  We always have jewish-style food and blintzes on Shavuot.  (google it.)

The latkes (1/2 order is 5 latkes - PLENTY) were delish and the Dr. Browns and Fresh OJ worked, but the fried kreplach (they very same ones that I love in the soup) are deep-fried.  Yuck. So disappointed - I wanted pan-fried.  Never again.  The came topped with a mountain of greasy fried, sweet onions (OK - but a grease fest).

Our server Claudine was accomodating and we like her!

But to get that 4th Star back, I guess I'll just have to stick to the soup.  (I get the Chicken soup with Matzoh balls and Kreplach (I like both and will pay the extra charge.)  It comes in a vat and I take nearly everything home.

It was $27 (plus tip) for 3 appetizers, 2 drinks and 1 enormous (and woefully dry) $3.75 sugar cookie with sprinkles.  We have enough for lunch the next day.

Oh - and per our server - don't get the giant black & whites.  They're dry.

So sad to have to downgrade - but the truth's the truth.

All that said - I'll be back for soup soon with my gal pals. And "new" pickles (half sours).  Love those.  And I will try the Kasha.  Hope it's better than Herschel's.

It's a Wawa, but it happens to be the closest one on my route from office to home (or vice versa) so I am glad it's there.

Grab some coffee, cigs, a junky snack, a banana or a meh sub.  (Sorry - that's "hoagie" to you.)

We need more supermarkets (not Wawa's) and dry cleaners in Center City so I am glad they are here - but still wishin' for more grocery choices.

Hey - one man's trash is another's treasure.
I have come here since I was a tween - when my granmother was still alive - and boy did she have a gift for scoring at a flea market.

You can find loads of jewelry, furniture, household goods (china and flatware, planters, etc.) old chothing and shoes (yech!!!) and much more.

It's a bit disheveld - but it's a FLEA MARKET a la Mary Fisher's of the old days.

Hours vary seasonally, so check before you trek. (They are not open every day - usually weekends and 1 week day - at the time of this review it was Wednesdays 6 AM - 4 PM).  Lots of vendors pack up by 2 or 3 PM though.
Bruing cash - many do not accept plastic but more and more do.

Also you can graba cuppa joe at the diner next door.

For a chair massage (in a throne-type chair), this is fine - albeit pricey - and a decent way to kill time in the Philly airport.

It's usually not  that crowded.

Glad it's here.

For 3 years this was our go-to ice rink (the only game in town, really) but now that we live in the 'burb's we go to the one out in Aston which is bigger, cleaner and nicer (and offers a full service bar/snackbar).

Meanwhile, this rink is a much needed outlet for kids who want to learn to ice skate in Philly. They offer lessons and also hockey.

My (then 5-7, now 8) kid loved going here.
So glad we took her to the public skating sessions.
A good birthday party option as well.

It's cold inside - bring a jacket!!!

A single ice surface facility with a few USFSA - figure skating (minor) competitions each year.
A decent place to practice.  Limited ice times due to single surface.  Lockers room, small snack bar.  Public skate times vary so check before you go.

They also have a pro shop with mostly hockey gear for sale, but the best part is Frank.

Frank gets 5 stars for sharpening my figure skaters Edeas over the past 4 years. We love him and pray he never retires.

Just OK.  Stopped here for a needed sundry and got side-tracked in their (strange and centrally located) photo department.  

Service was fine.  No major issues - but I like my "regular" Walgreen's in Aston better.

Our brand-new (2 days on the job) waitress seemed overwhelmed - but somehow got us through a decent enough lunch.  I had my usual - Matzoh Ball Soup (served in a vat) with Kreplach added.  (And a Diet Dr. Brown's Cream Soda).

Classic , heavy, jewish-deli-insipred fare served in HUGE portions with prices to match,

Whatever you are getting - soup, salad or sandwich - SPLIT IT with a friend. (Or take 1/2 home).

Gut-busting, not mind-blowing but good.
Oh - and the smaller sized cookies the give you with the bill?  I wish they sold that size - perfect!

This is my 11 year old's go-to 5 below for pollyanan gifts, girl scout projects, last minute birthday party gifts and cheapie electronics (Like a selfie stick for $4.99) and accessories.

Is it my favorite store?  No.  But it is nicer (and more expensive) than a dollar store - it's a FIVE dollar store.

Great for tweens & teens - and even a few things for the parents.

I have eaten here twice and briefly considered it for a rehearsal dinner location (based on its location - near Doylestown & Warrington).  They could not accomodate our large group, so we opted to go elsewhere.

That said, Via Barolo has some decent food - you have to know what to order (do not get fish here!) and ask them to go light on the salt.  In my opinion, the food here runs on the saltier side.

Pasta was cooked al dente - and very good.

If I ever go back I will stick to salads and pasta dishes.

It's OK.  We went to Ted's because the line for PF Changs was "not worth the wait" long.  Had some burgers (Bison is offered,of course) and I had a decent salad.

Nothing to write home about.  Some of my family and friends love it - but I just think it's OK.

We have also been to the one in Philly where my little girl likes the mac 'n cheese.

Pleasant service and decor.  And not nearly as mobbed as PF Changs.

Chain pseudo-Brooklyn-Italian (Immigrant cuisine circa 1954) in whopping huge portions.  (Only recently has Buca Mio - for one - become an option.)

They make a passable Chicken Marsala and decent pizza.  It is, indeed, carby goodness!

I have my ordering down to a science - especially when dining alone.
I get a side of fettucine alfredo with the alfredo sauce on the side (so I can control the amount of glop).  A side order is HUGE.  Then I order ONE SINGLE (yummy) meatball - which is the size of a small baby's head.  (*ouch, the imagery*).

I then slice up the meatball and put the red sauce ("It's Gravy if you're from soufilly") and a bit of the alfreddo over the pasta.

A tasty heart attack on a plate.

The decor is loud and so are the clients.  This is the only restaurant I've been to where the table in the kitchen (it's a hoot) is QUITER than the tables in the dining rooms.

Check out the "pope room" and the ladies room while your there.  What a hoot!

Gourmet - mais, non - but fun?  Why, yes!

We attended a 7 year old child's birthday party here - 26 kids and about 20 grownups in 2 separate dining areas.  Service was amazingly smooth for a party that large and chaotic.  All had salad (caesar or classic), bread and baked rigatoni.  Kids got to "make their own" pizza" in shifts at the chef's table in the kitchen.

Bucca is not the greatest food - but for a 7 year old's luncheon party it's a neat choice.  The kids had a ball.  The adults took excedrin.

Sasa and Kyle and our other serves were amazingly patient. Thank you!

This McDonalds was the first fast food restaurant in D-town and it is still there today.  As McDonald's go it is well run and fairly clean.  It is, however, a McDonald's after all and I just can't stand their food.  Maybe the fries are OK, but I am not a fast food lover.

Toppers has been around for-eh-ver.  They were the first to popularize the day spa to Philadelphia back in the early '80's.

Back then Toppers was in the Bourse and was pure luxury.  They'd even pick you up in a limo for your "queen for a day" of beauty.

Nowadays - a lot of the shine has been diminished.  The rude (and disorganized) reservation system and lines at check in and check out really take away from the over-priced just OK massages and pedicures that I have gotten.

I can't speak to the salon (hair/make-up) services - but for spa treatments - there are better places to go.

That said I got a gift certificate for $100 here and I gave it away to the receptionist in my building who was absolutely thrilled and delighted with her first-time ever massage.

But for a jaded, ex-NYC day spa owner, toppers needs to re-tool it's customer service and therapies in order to continue its legacy.

Try Terme di Aroma, Spa Elysium in Chestnut Hill - or even the pricey Phoenix, instead.

Finally had a chance to dine in at the (not so) new location in Media and my issue is NOT about price - the prices seem pretty fair, actually.

I ordered Pico & Chips (I have had their delicious pico several times before - as a take out item - they add chunks of avocado to their pico making it super yummy). and for $5 they should have called it CHIPS and pico.  there was a 4 oz paper cup of pico - so I ordered another ($2.00 more) so my friend and I could share.

Also it took a long time to sit and wait for it - i think somebody goofed as I sat and sat and sat (and took a few phone calls) and eventually had to ask at the counter where it was.

Finally my friend & I ordered salads (we both opted for small "side" salads - fairly priced at $6.) She had the Caesar and I had the beet salad.  They should have called this KALE salad as it was basically a plate of balsamic vinegar-dressed kale with a glob of beets on top (best part) and 3 balls of goat cheese.  There was no mention of kale nor goat cheese on the menu - and I am not a big goat cheese fan. Not ordering that again!

So for $13 I ate 1/3 of a side salad and some chips & pico.

Hardly the greatest dinner ever.

Also - I wanted to get a single (fish?) taco as advertised on the website but now you must order 2 or 3 tacos - no more single taco orders.  I hope they will reconsider this and bring it back.

They need to update the website menu.
Also there are inconsistencies on their printed menu at the restaurant (Cheese plate pricing on page 1 does not agree was cheese plate pricing on cheese list (page 3).

I will be back and we love the owner - they are a terrific member of our small Media community, but I honestly, have had better meals.
Next time I will order a real "plate" and see what transpires.

Oh - and the eggplant parm (I thought about ordering that - when I saw it on the website menu) is no longer on the paper menu.

Many small things "wrong" added up to a lower rating than I had hoped to give.  The place is very nice, and I hope my next experience will be better.

For ice rink food - this is pretty darned good.
The Pub is between ricks 3 & 4 - there is also a snack bar between rinks 1 & 2 with a more casual feel.

Both have great views of the rinks (ntach) and chicken parm, meatball subs and hogies, salads and decent drinks.

Very impressed - and glad to be able to get food when we are at the rink ALL DAY watching our kid.

Had a perfectly lovely lunch here with a girlfriend.  I played it safe and got the amazing matzoh ball soup with kreplach.  For $8.95 - it's served in a large vat.  I took over half of it home.

The new pickles are also delish.

Service was good - but the tiny tables and lunch crowds causedmy friend to have her soda spilled - fortunately it spilled all over the table and not much got one her.

Come for dinner - or after 2 PM when the lunch rush dies down.

I agree with Chrissy R.  The food is very, very good and high quality -but it's just not worth the price.  However, they do carry a startling assortment of gourmet chocolates and snacks.  

The salad bar option allows you to try a small bit of the items that appeal to you.

They used to have a slew of designer cupcakes, too.  Not sure if they still do.

I prefer to shop at the CVS or Walgreen's nearby, but in a pinch I have shopped at this Rite Aid.  I will also check here if for whatever reason CVS or Walgreen's does not have the item I am looking for.

It's OK but not my favorite and I never get prescriptions filled here.

Good in a pinch though.

Stopped in today at 7:40 AM and there was NO LINE.
Do not come here over lunchtime (11:30 - 2 PM) or you will wait and wait on the line.

Got in and out quickly.
No issues today.

This is a staple for us - as we can take our 3 year old daughter there and the plac is never that crowded.  She likes the fried chicken dumplings and we like the Tom Kha Gai soup.  As for the regular chinese style dishes - they are good but not outstanding.

The prices are reasonable - although they did go up last time we went in.

The Shu Mai are huge with lots of meat (pork, shrimp and fake-crab) filling - but I would not get that again.

I did enjoy the chicken with sugar snap peas.
They carry good quality products but the staff are space cadets.  (Sorry - you are nice but flakey).  I have never liked shopping in here and only came here due to its close proximity to the office.

This is the Starbucks attached to Macy's.
We really needed a "fix" so we stopped here on Black Friday and the place was crazed.

Meanwhile we got through the line and were duly caffeinated.

Glad it was there.

Tiny outpost (no seating/standing room) of Dunkin.
Got an iced coffee here with no issues.  (Went during the summer at 8:20 AM)

I'm not much for updates - especially if nothing has changed- but a friend & I had a nice lunch at Asia on the Parkway today.

It was exactly as it always has been.  Good vegetable dumplings.  Good Tom Kha soup.

Efficient service got us outta there in time for my friend to go back to "the foim".

Also - during the snow of 2010 we ordered delivery from Asia - and it was very good - and a life saver inour snow-bound state.

SKIP the shumai.  Get the chicken or veggie dumplings instead.

Sorry.  I am getting less and less impressed each time I go.  I have been thrice.  The first time (the best of the 3 - so I returned) I had some delicious and fresh rolls at lunchtime.  It was not crowded and service was good.  

The second time I came I had a platter of sushi and it was not as fresh as it should be.

The last time I went - and I will not return, the service was just awful.  The $17.95 maki I ordered, while HUGE and containing ingredients I like, was dripping in 3 kinds of gloppy sauces.  Go easy on the sauce, guys.  Use fresher fish and pare down to basics.  Some things don't need tempura crunch AND eel sauce AND spicy mayo AND whatever that other glop was.

I am consistently underwhelmed by Pietros and thuis do not eat here often,.  There are much better places IMHO to get Italian-American food.
They do make a decent pizza (but Rustica in Northern Liberties is much better) and serve large plated entrees of decent - not memorable - chicken, fish & veal.

The pasta was, indeed, al dente - which was a plus.

Service was fine - but it was crowded and very loud.  I don't like to sit outside - the whiff of auto exhaust from Walnut Street is not my idea of a fine dining al fresco experience, so we were trapped inside with the hoardes.

Don't go on a Friday night, is all I can advise.
Maybe don't go - try Le Castagne instead.  (19 & Chestnut)

Oh, I really wish I could give this place higher marks - but I just can't.
Meanwhile I have been here now a bunch of time - always for a weekday lunch because they have relatively quick service and are located near my office.

Meanhwile - try #75 & #81 (both burritos) off the lunch menu.  I get the #75 made with chicken instead of the beef tips, and I like it much better.
Avoid the beef here - not great,

It seems to be coated with Cheese-whiz.  Weird - but oddly good.

The chips & salsa still kinda suck.  The chips tasted like bagged ones (slightly stale tasting) and the Salsa it kinda like jarred Old El Paso.

Disappointing, but yet we return again and again.

And it's still way better than La Tolteca.

And the service is friendly (and as I just said - quick.)
Selene is very sweet.

This is, indeed, a small outpost of Ann Taylor - but I did have good luck here on a few occaisions.  One - during a sale - i snagged alot of cute knit tops & sweaters at insanely cheap prices.

I also came here last week with a holiday gift card I received - and lo & behold - everything in the store was 40% off - so i got a nice petitie sized (thus no shortening or hemming required) "interview" suit.

Ann Taylor is a decent place to get work-a-day clothing.

A fun place to poke around - neat clothing and accessories - but kinda snooty service and high prices kept me from actually buying anything.

Cute just the same.

Really?  I am not impressed.
And I am not easy to impress, so you may want to take that into account, but my late lunch on an EMPTY Saturday at 2:30 PM was just OK.

I had the sushi/sashimi combo (served with a california roll) and 1 piece of ikura.

The tuna sashimi was not as fresh as it should be.
Tamago is frozen
Rice was hard.

Absolutely unimpressed.

Sushi Nami in Paoli or Azie in Media are better (not to mention Doma and Zama in Center City).

We buy liquor here on occaision because it is convenient.
I think the PA liquor laws are really strange and generally nonsensical.

People have complained about my old review, so now i will simply say they make decent burgers & shakes.  Is it akin to Shake Shack in NYC?  I don't think it's nearly as good and the burgers are smaller.

Want more deets?  See grubstreet's write up.  It was perfect!

This is a review of the Ann Taylor LOFT location in Liberty Place.  (There is also an Ann Taylor - non loft - on Walnut street a few blocks down.

LOFT is a the lower-end "casual" line put out by Ann Taylor - and for me it's better in the spring & summer than in the winter.

Moderately priced "corporate casual" duds that are moderate quality.  It's hit or miss for me - for whatever reason I do better at the "regular" (and higher priced - but not during a sale)  Ann Taylor.

Not the greatest service - and the place is, indeed, packed with stuff - Hockey Skates galore.
I was able to consign a $404 pair of figure skates in excellent condition.  I asked $200, got offered $100 - which I reluctantly accepted.

I just wanted to get rid of them.  So after the 50%/50% comission I pocketed exactly $50.

Better than nothing.
And better than the $22 they offered to buy them from me outright.

The spa itself should be a 4 star place, but there are too many cracks showing in the proverbial armor.

Firstly, I should mention that my facialist, Amanda, was very nice and knew her stuff when it came to basic skincare and Aveda products.  Because they are an Aveda spa - they are forced to use this line - and while many of the products are good, a few are just not worth it.  Amanda "played it straight" and did not try to sell me un-needed products.

The massage therapist, Tracy, seemed great, too.  I did not have a massage today - but may come back to work with Tracy.

Locker room was clean and nice.  There was NO WATER in the glass-windowed wiating room.  It does seem a little weird to be waiting around in your robe and people in the pool can see you.

Also, nobody even mentioned to me that there was a pool and hot tub - ort else I woulda brought my suit and planned to arrive early or stay afterward.  DRAT.

Oh well.

Maybe next time.  

4 stars for Amanda.  3 for the way the place is run.  Get it together, ladies!

Got a large group that likes to drink?
Need some "safe" food choices?
Want a private room?

Then, G. A. P. is your place.

I came here with a group of 27 people and we were easily accomodated in a private room (with our own bar and buffet area) and service by Michele was excellent.

The drinks during happy hour are cheap enough - 1 beer and 1 well-tequila margarita ran me $7.

The food is fine.  Chicken or Eggplant parm, penne marinara, veggies and over-cooked roast beef with rolls and horseradish.  Not great but not awful either.  Very "safe" and everyone enjoyed the dessert tray with brownies, pound cake (looked like Sara Lee) and mini canolli.

We had a great meeting and would definitely have events here again.

There is even an old-fashioned ballroom (seats up to 150, I think) huge with it's own dance floor and restrooms - suitable for a down-scale wedding or a bir rehearsal dinner or graduation party.

This place is HUGE and has many configurations for groups large, small and massive.

This Acme (a larger one) is on my way to work so today I literally ran in and out at 7:20 AM for a quart of milk and box of instant oatmeal packets.

The place was nearly empty at that hour so it was no biggie.
Friendly cashier, too.

No issues and I know I'll be back.
This is the Acme on Rt. 252 near Rt. 30 in Paoli.

2.5 stars - I am giving them the benefit of the doubt.
I stopped in here early one morning because it is across the Street from Penn Medicine where I had an appt.

Good a simple bagel with cream cheese.

Nothing special, nothing horrific either.

Glad they were around.

I do not get the appeal of Outback.  My parents and inlaws love it.
I do not find it worth "the wait" (and on weekends there is always a wait) and the food is very "blah".

I had a ribeye and a baked sweet potato (told them not to put the butter and brown sugar glop on it) and it was OK but sertainly not on par with a fine steakhouse.

The wedge salad was covered in 2 dressings (balsamic glaze AND blue cheese) - thank goodness I had them on the side.  Plus it comes with bacon, blue cheese crumbles and onions which I omited.  A big old hunk of FAT on top of a wedge of iceberg.  Yick.

That said, our 7 year old ate evey one of her 4 kiddie-meal BBQ ribs plus ate every last bite of the (well-buttered) broccoli. They also make a surprisingly good mac-a-roo and cheese (penne in a creamy cheese sauce).

I am not a big fan - but for family dinners - it beats Applebee's.

I was STARVIN' like marvin after a fabulous pedicure at Spa Elysium (see my yelp review of that, too.) and needed sustainance.

I considered a few other plkaces - including the French Cafe which was so packed and disorganized that I had to bail out.  (Will yelp that soon.)
So I cautiously entered this PACKED pizza spot (1 PM on a gorgeous Spring Saturday) and ordered a single slice of silician pizza topped with eggplant.

YUM CITY!

So delicious.

I would like to come back and try more things - just not on a Saturday at lunch time.
OK, I am upgrading the Liberty Place Ruby Schmoozeday's.  The new mini burgers are edible and my husband digs the Cheddar Burger here.  But again - I never eat here on my own volition.

This is a review for Rastelli Direct (rastellidirect.com) a direct marketing website where you can purchase "restaurant quality" frozen meats and foods.

The good - everything is beautifully packaged and individually flash-frozen and vacuum packed.  I enjoyed my veal-leg slices and could cook just ONE at a time which was great.  The also ship right to your door with plenty of dry ice.  The website is easy to use and your friend (whoever refers you) gets 5% credit from your purchase.

The bad - in order to get the prices to drop from ridiculously expensive to insanely high, you either have to join as a Rastelli Consultant (minimum monthly order requirement) or join the "Smart Shopper" program - which drops the price 20%.  Still too damned high.  And they try to lock you in to a monthly auto-ship feature.

Oh and the $19.00 (about $16 after the discount) Steamazing frozen entrees (2 for 16 is ridiculous still) were glorified lean cuisines.

No thanks, Rastelli.  The quality just does not justify the price.  (They have to build in comissions for your upline.)

I will order again - but not every month.  No way.
My steaks are gonna continue to come from Omaha.

Sashimi is the true litmus test for a sushi spot and Jasmine is just fair.
Red Snapper was obviously a previously frozen fish (still had ice crystals).  Escolar?  really?  Ick.

The tuna and salmon were fine.

Good service and decent maki, but for a true sushi connoisseur, this is not your spot.  But hey - you're in DELAWARE.  So for that it's still pretty darned good.

Next time I stick to the basics.  I come here about once a month.

Yes, it's cheap (especially if you get the $6 steam table - and especially if you show up at 11:30 or so when everything is fresh), but it's not that great somehow.

I ordered the Coconut Soiup (with Tofu instead of Chicken or Shrimp) and today is was bland.  One-note coconut milk.

So disappointing.

I also got Pad-See-Yew (wide noodles with chinese brocolli and dark soy with scrembled egg and tofu (I got soft tofu instead of a meat or fried tofu.)  Good but also bland.

Next time I will come on a Friday - the only day they serve Masaman Curry - and stick to the $6 steam table.  The $10 I blew on a (huge) lunch today wasn't worth it.  But at least I won't need to cook dinner.

While the Midtown IV is my fave, the Midtown III (Different owners) is a few bloacks way and is a bit less grungy and good for a cheap quick breakfast or lunch.

The waitresses here just aren't as sassy as at the IV, but it is still the "diner" experience.

God Bless the American Diner.  We need it, we love it!

This is the Cosi by Barclays and well, it's THERE.
So that gives it a star by default.

This area is a "trapped" for lunch scenario.
You need coffee?  An overpriced faux-puccio?  That weird bread they serve?

Never been a Cosi lover but this one is a necessary evil.
And in a pinch - you can interview here too.

Ten or eleven years later and nothing has changed - save for the prices which are a tad higher.  Old-school Greek-Owned and operated diner with American Classics (good for eggs and bacon - even for lunch) and old-pro waitress that say "What'll it be, hon?".

The food is exactly what you might expect and the décor is straight outta 1974.

"Gimme a whiskey down,  two on a raft, Mac."

I just don't know WHY so many people in opur office love this place?  They rave about the ham on pretzel bread (MEH).  They rave about the salads (MEH).

They even rave about the Cinnamon cream cake - and while it does taste awesome - a "serving" is over 1100 calories.

No thanks.

I'll walk across the Street to the snob-cast center instead for some local (NOT!) goodies from La Scala.

It's OK - but it's just MEH.

I echo Monique's review below in that this is a reasonably price zoo that is good for small kids (6 & under) but you need to bring your own food and water, and avoid the cafe.

Staff are friendly and easy to talk to.
Giraffe feeding is $3.00 to feed them 2 pieces of romaine lettuce.  Totally worth it!
They have 2 adorable giraffes.

Not a great zoo - very small - but good.
This is the Panera in the Lawrence Park Shopping Center and it is just like every other Panera - maybe a tad grottier.  Not great and not bad.  Sandwiches, Salads, Soups and Breads/Pastries.

Typical Irish-style local bar - with live music and a great outdoor "alley-space" to sit outside on a warm evening.

Parking is tough.

Food is decent enough - with all the pub-grub staples.
I had the Cobb salad - and my mates had classic burgers with fries.
Kim - our server - is a tough cookie who is fantastic with the regulars.

Good times - and lots and lots of booooooooze!

NPR - we were FORCED to listen to it as kids - my parents just love it - things like "Fresh Air" with Terry Gross and other shows.

I remember thinking how BORING it was.

Still kinda do.

Bring money and patience and a book or e-book to read and enjoy.
The food is fairly good for breakfast/brunchtime or a snack (coffee and pastry).  Not great for a true lunch or dinner.

I enjoyed my croissant and coffee and lingered over a magazine.
Attended a graveside service here. Man, this place is big and complicated. Funeral home organized everything well. The cemetery itself seemed fine.  Expensive to be buried here.

It's just OK.  Way passed it's prime - but the cute location is fun and they now offer some strange "game meat" choices on the menu.

Back in the '90's we'd come here for brunches and celebratory dinners.  It was good for graduations and such.  Today?  I might not choose it.

Note:  We also investigated the Inn (across the parking lot) for a potential wedding venue - but it was not what we were looking for.

We stopped here on a slow July 5th and had a surprisingly good experience - even though it was clear that the manager is a jerk and most of the waitresses hate their jobs.

My french onion soup was actually good - not overly salted and full of beef stock and roasted onions - melted cheese and crisp crouton.  No issues.

DH ordered a short stack (3 pancakes) and they were fluffy and hot (not leaden!) and served with cheap-a$$ syrup.

Not a holy grail but we were pleasantly surprised.  Steven B. is an accurate source of info., though - so next time we'll head to a different place.
We stopped here when very hungry and the place was nearly empty.

My teen is a competitive skater so the Public Skate is not her thing but she enjoys the River Rink from time to time each winter.  Lots of special events here too.

Gets crowded.

We attended a low-scale (no catering - we brought in pizza, chips and brownies), minimally decorated, no booze school function here.

We were VERY lucky to have a member of our school community who knows the owner.
This is a very nice (and importantly - large) ballroom which easily accomodated our group of 175 (with plenty of room to spare and a large dancefloor).

Would I have my own wedding here?  Probably not.  But for other events - family reunions, etc, it's a good pick.

I can't speak to their in-house catering as we brought in our own food. (Again - someone knew the owners, you normally have to use their food.)

Meh.  I had the Cobb Salad here and substituted "roasted Shrimp" for turkey which proved to be a pricey and needless mistake.  The Shrimp were over cooked and rubbery.

The salad itself would have been just fine (Next time, IF there is a next time sticking to Turkey - I pray it is not dry.)

Avocado Ranch on the side was tasty.

$13 salad.  Blargh.

Oh - one bright spot - Service at the front counter from Natalie (sp?) was great and she ubbly, sassy, smiling personality.  They kind lady (Keysha?) who brought us our dine-in order was great, too.

They get packed during the lunch rush - location, location, location.

Pag's is, indeed, pricey - but hey - you're in DOYLESTOWN.  They serve decent pizza with yuppy ingredients like pancetta or prosciutto.

The main restaurant has great pasta dishes. (This is the Cafe next door.)

the gyros are the best thing they make ($7 - and 4 stars).  The spanakopita is not that good.

Greek salad was OK - but not mind blowing.

With all the fabulous choices in RTM (and trust me - I love greek food) I usually find myself drawn to Thai or some other place over Olympic.

A big plus - they have their own seating so at least you know if you get a (tasty) gyro there that you will usually be able to get a stool to sit and eat it on.

Less crowded than the CVS at 19 & Chestnut - and it's on my way to work so I stop at the Walgreens on JFK from time to time to fill a prescription, pick up sundries or (twice) get photo processing.

No major complaints and no major praise - glad its there.

This is now my go-to (near work) Starbucks - as it is closest.

Can get crazy-crowded during peak times.
Some of the baristas are terrific and others not so much.  There is a young guy with dark hair who is super funny and bright - and been there a long while.  He is great.  (Can't remember his name.)

If you can snag seating in the back it can be a decent place to get work done.

Parking in this shopping center has always been and still is a nightmare. (Lunch rush, Holiday time etc.)

Try to come at odd hours and you'll have a better experience.

Great idea in concept but 3 stars in execution.  The would NOT take my couch because it had a small tear in it.

Oh well.  I free-cycled it away.

We don't "do" fast food - but when you have a 2-4 year old and need a play-room this is a great choice.  Our daughter gets a 4 nugget kids meal with fruit (instead of fries) and lowfat milk.  Then she plays - sometimes for a whole HOUR in the play room.

A great break for mom & dad.  Cheap.  Not too nutritionally horrible.  (But we don't come more than every 2 weeks.)

However, recently our daughter discovered that they serve Lemonade.  Our lowfat Milk days are numbered.

NOTE:  Recently (May 2009) the play area has gotten stickier and dirtier.  It needs a good floor to ceiling cleaning.

This is a nice, typical VS store - but it is not the closest one to my house.  I came here to redeem my "free panties" coupon - and basically went in and out - no issues.

Seems fine to me.

We had a good first experience with the service department here when we took our 2006 Sonata for inspection.  $407 later we passed.

Hmmmmn...

No major issues with Olde City Taxi.  I usually call a few hours before I need a cab and it is usually there on time.  Some of the cabs are pretty shoddy - it's on a car by car basis.  Some are 1 star - others 4 or 5.  Cabs in Philly cost even MORE than in NYC.  Who knew?

I agree 100% with Steve S. this is a Chipotle-esque pizza spot - and I got the mini ($4.97) loaded with veggies.

Not bad!  A thin crisp crust (bordering on burnt - so they need to be careful) and lots of goodies.

No issues.
Quick and cheap.

Stopped in to get razor blades and a few cosmetic necessities for my teen daughter.  Easy in and out, ample parking.  No issues.

Did NOT get prescriptions filled here.

I had walked passed this place but never cared to go in - so for whatever reason i stopped in yesterday for a manicure and (yes, really) a pedicure.  It looked clean - but I can not say what the sanitation situation is until I wait a while.

Meanwhile, Kim (who is pregnant) did the mani and pedi and did a nice job.  Not mindblowing - but acceptable.

Not sure if I'll be back but $30 for a mani/pedi is very reasonable.

I would probably NOT ever get eyelash extensions here (or anywhere, really.).

They take credit cards but tip must be in cash.

I had a good 4 star and a lousy 2 star experience at the Old Nelson inside 30th Street Station (used to be a Saxby Coffee a few years ago).

The first time I cam I bought packaged goods (A cup of Haagen Dazs, actually) - paid and left.  No problem.  It was a 4 star day and nice to see the wide variety of products.

But TODAY I decided to order a breakfast sandwich.

FAIL.

For $2.49 (You order at the counter - she writes it on a colored post-it note and then you go pay a la manual Wawa) I chose egg & cheese on a bagel.  Sounds simple, right?

So they make it (and I swear I saw a microwave was involved and I immediately knew this would not be pretty), wrap it, bag it and I march off to my office.

5 minutes later I unwrap this steming hot MESS of wax paper (microwaved-glued to the bagel).  I spent a good 2 minutes trying to pick off pieces of soggy wax paper from the bagel.

Threw half out - it was unsalvageable.

Ate the egg and cheese insides with a kinife and fork - eggs were nuked and horrible.

NEVER again for an egg sandwich - but yes for a quick stop for "packaged" goods - and they have an expansive cold beverage selection.

Cashier and counter folks were friendly - but please, take heed - NO MORE NUKING the egg sammies, OK?

Cute place with good - but not overwhelmingly good - sushi.
I had one order of yellowtail sashimi (for $7.00) and a Polar Bear roll - which was basically an alaskan roll topped with white tuna. ($13.00)

That's it.  I didn't have much - and I was still kinda hungry - but cash has been tight.

Service was great because the place was dead empty on a Wednesday night at 7:45 PM.

Again - it's good - and worth a second visit - but by no means a holy grail.

In the Old Days (Before the folks who own HomeGoods and Marshalls or whatever big chains they own - bought Christmas Tree Shops), CTS was only in Massachussets - mostly on Cape Cod and sold Holiday Decor.

Those days are looooooooong gone.

Now it's more like a 5 and 10 - random cheap home goods, food items, paper products, children's toys, lawn furniture and seasonal decorations (Halloween and Christmans come to mind).

This location is not one of the best - but I will  be kind agive it 3 stars - but it's more like 2.5.

CTS is becoming more and more like a Dollar store - but things cost more than a dollar.

I miss the old fashioned, quaint, New England CTS of old.
But, those days, alas, are gone.

Rice's has been around for years and years and it ebbs and flows, expands and contracts basedon the seasons and the economy.  It's now $1.00 for parking (get there AT 7 AM when they open - by 9:30 AM the place is packed.

We scored some American Girl clothing (hand made), a tutu for our 8 year old, hair ribbons and sparkly no-name nail polish for $2 a pop.

A few produce people - but more "stuff" than food this year.

Once a summer is more than enough for me.  It's part street fair, part farmers market, part flea market, part mart.

A classic experience.

This is not the one on Germantown Ave.  This one is in Old(e) City on N. 3rd Street.

Bone Appetite sells doggie (and kittie) gear, treats, pet food, supplies and custom-made (expensvie) bakery treats.  Akin to "Doggie Style", but a smaller feel & vibe.

The dog treat my daughter selected was $3.25 and was super-small.  (Not cool, but I'm a sucker and bought it anyway.)

They also have a PAWS cat (or 2) up for adoption at any given time.

Friendly front-desk lady - knew her products.
Surprisingly GOOD prices on ZEKE's hip-action treats.  I shoulda got some - it might have made up for the over priced doggie baked goods.

It's been 2 years since we last visited 4 dogs but some things remain the same - lovely dining under the big green tent, and a vast array of fine cheeses in all forms all over the menu.  (The chef is apparently a "cheese head").  If available do not miss the $16.50 Caprese salad with sweet heirloom tomatoes and creamy, rich buratta.  Wow.  If you do not like cheese or are dairy averse - this may not be the best restaurant for you.

Ironically, nachos here are a disappointment - although plated on a cedar plank (cute) - but not enough toppings to justify $13 nachos.  French onion soup was good - but also pricey at $11.

Lunch for 3 with NO ALCOHOL was around $80 - ouch.
Far too pricey for what you get.

On the plus side?  Dogs are so welcome - and there are many cute dogs to pet while you vist.
On the minus side?  ONE tiny ladies room and always a line.

Run but teenagers and extremely slow service - bordering on ridiculously slow.

Meanwhile our 8 year old loves it here and we hosted a "sundae party" here for she and 5 of her little friends last September.

We have been back a few times to eat - and prefer this location to the SPringfield Mall one - but you have to tell them you are in a hurry (maybe even if you're not!) to get your food in a timely fashion.

Avoid the iceberg-blah salads.
Burgers are OK - a bit greasy.
Ice cream is the main reason to come at all.

Got kids?  They'll like Friendly's.
Got tastebuds?  You may not like it so much!

I am torn - the food is 4 stars but there are too many other things that need attention - mostly decor-wise - like dust-covered bread plates and a dining room that needs a makeover, stat.

The business has been around for 11 years and is clearly family run.
Shrimp scampi was very basic - but good.  I asked for it light on the sauce (oil/garlic) so that was a good move.  Frittata for lunch is a good and tasty value.

Bread was cold and dry (and sitting on the table waiting for us).
Not great.

I can cook alot of these things at home just as well.
I would return but won;t be rushing back.

Really?  So old school and no wraps.  It's wheat, white, rye or a roll.
Limited choices.

Not my scene at all.

Terrific little old ladies behind the counter though and very inexpensive.

Sterling Pig is yet another creation by the same guy who brought Media Diego's (OK), Belle Epoque (Can be great can also be so-so) and Picasso (Not good - and shares the SAME KITCHEN as Belle).

Decor is Rustic at SPB and my husband enjoyed a specialty IPA.  ($6).
The food is way, way over priced especially for the meh quality.  My Flank Steak salad had a small portion of delicious sliced steak over a bed of boring mixed greens with 3 (no kidding, 3) tiny cubes of diced tomato.  I asked for more tomatoes and they were brought.  No cucumbers were  available.  For $16 that is kinda steep.

DH also had flank steak - his was also a small portion (too small in his opinion) served with grilled zucchini, red and yellow peppers.  $22.  (Whoa.)

Our kid had the pulled pork sandwich ($14) sans coleslaw.  It was very smoky and kinda dry.  She added BBQ sauce to it.  Brioche bun was tasty.  

The fries that came with the sandwich could be a memoir all their own.  They literally glistened with grease and were so oil-soaked it was almost comical.  They were presented in a cute "mini fry-basket" lined with paper that el kiddo said "was (clearly) not doing it's job".
No way for $6 I would have ordered a separate side of these oil-slick fries.

Unless I am dragged here by fellow Media-ites, I am in absolutely no hurry to return to SPB.

Stick to the beer and you'll be fine.

Convenient and easy to get in & out.
I have never come here for prescriptions - only to pick up a few items here & there.\
No issues for me.

Christmas Tree Shops were soooo great when they were a Cape Cod original.  They are now owned by the conglomerate that owns Home Goods & Marshalls.  So yes, you can still get great deals here on home decor and knick knacks - but it also has more of a "Dollar Store" feel to it.

Meanwhile if you are planning a party, wedding, event or Holiday-themed get together - you really should check out the DIY items and paper goods available here.

Also a good deal on certain PET SUPPLIES and random summer items.  Changes seasonally so check back often.

I have no issues here - I never dine in - I stop in for breakfast usually a Whole wheat "Bagel-Thin" with low-fat veggie cream cheese, tomatoes & cukes.

The spinach & cheese "specialty" bagel looks great but i can't seem to justify the calories.

I never get coffee here - I don't love it.  I prefer Charbucks or Dunkin'.

My 9 year old loved it here but I think Yogurtissimo (on State Stree) is better.
There is no free water - luckily we brought some or we'd have had to buy 2 bottles.

The yogurt itself seemed fine but the toppings were not as fresh (fruit looked mushy) and more candy-based.  (Of course the kid loved that) Also the cute orange & green decor while fun to look at - the chairs are not comfortable.  At all.

Lady at the front was nice - and ran the place single-handedly.

We'll return if my kid wants to - but I would not go here again on my own volition.

Well run store with helpful staff.
No issues.  Got in & out quickly - even the weekend before Xmas.

For whatever reason it was busy in here on a Thursday "after work" - around 5 PM.
I had the famous "free panty" coupon - but I also needed some 5 for $26 cotton undies and was in DIRE need of hosiery - as mine had a run.

The pantyhose I selected?  $16.  No sale! Yikes.

Meanwhile the line was pretty long to check out but they got another lady to open a second register and that helped.

The usual Icky Vicky experience.
A very good hospital but extremely long waits in the ER for triage and care.  Unacceptable to wait 75 minutes with a 9 year old.

It's OK.  Not great (and certainly not 5 star), but it's passable for an urban supermarket.

Big pluses - home delivery and Italian products.

Somewhere between Meh and OK.  We bought a laptop from Best Buy yesterday and waived all their extra charges for geek squad and useless warranties.  Now if anything goes wrong, we're on our own. 

Oh - and we waived the $99 installaion fee - so we are installing MS Office ourselves (this isn't rocket science, people). 

The 17 year old high school student who helped us (Nick) was reasonably intelligent and put up with my husband and I agruing while our 7 year old was bored as hell and getting whiny.

What a drag...

Meanwhile - still a decent value for laptops and big-screen TVs.

This Domino's is located right next door to where my 9 year old gets her hair cut, so one day she was famished so I ordered her a small plain pie (plenty left to take home) and it was ready in 12 minutes.

Do I like dominos?  No.
Has their quality improved lately?  Yes.

And the staff here are friendly and attentive.

Grease-laden, high caloric and NOT my thing - but in a pinch - it's OK.

Take out only. 
Large delivery radius.

You get what you pay for - yeah it's cheap to fly Southwest but everything costs extra.
Want to board first (so that you have a snowball's chance in hell of getting overhead space for your luggage)?  Pay for it.
I absolutely loathe their "cattle call" approach to seating.

Need a snack?  Pay for it.

Want to be able to change your ticket or G-d forbid refund it?  Pay more for it again.

Yikes.

Flying in this country sucks in general and Southwest can suck a little less (or alittle more depending on your viewpoint).

Bon frikkin' Voyage!

They re-modeled.  Looks much cleaner now.

I am not a big DD fan - but the coffee is fine.  I don't eat the donuts (which are not freshly baked - and usually taste stale to me) and NEVER eat the 400 PLUS calorie breakfast grease-wiches.

It's a good place to get a Vanilla Iced Decaf or a quick cup of joe when it's cold out.

And they sell gift cards - a good $5.00 "I don't know what the hell to get the mailroom guy" gift.

But that's all.

A cute men's tie store in the bottom of Liberty Place.  Too expensive unless you get a sale item.  Ties are colorful and nicely displayed. Medium quality (not high end, not cheapies.).

Need a tie badly?  Pick one up here.
Or an ascot or pocket square.

Or a lame father's day gift.

Vitamin Shop is a huge chain and offers nearly every supplement you can imagine.  Just be careful as some are animal derived (if you are a vegan - you gotta be really careful at TVS) and many come from lab created sources.

A good place to pick up some Co-Q 10.  (I'm a big fan of my Co-Q.)

They are a huge chain - and if you get the membership card - there can be some good deals.

Excellent service from Brett.
I had been avoiding coming here for years as it never appealed from the outside and I was certain it would be "just a bar" on the inside.

And I am partially right.

However - when surrounded by good friends and great conversation - we had great food and service as well.
Maybe the stars were properly aligned?  Or maybe I am de-volving into a Delco chick?

I had a BLT with Avocado with sweet potato fries and it was perfect.  For $5.25 my "well drink" of cheap vodka, cranberry juice and a splash of seltzer was just F.I.N.E. fine.

Live (loud) music - even on a Tuesday night at 10 PM.

I do believe I shall return.
Pleasantly - even shockingly surprised.

A centrally located, convenient Walgreens.  I have had a few prescriptions filled here and the lines are better than the CRAZY CVS on 19 & Chestnut.  

Happy it's here.

Photo processing is decent, too.

Panera is one of those "chain" pseudo-fast food places that seems like it would be great - but the calorie and sodium counts on most dishes (except salads) are super high.

The 1/2 order of pasta whas over 500 cals!
That said, my 9 year old likes the mac & (gloppy white cheddar) cheese here.
I had a shrimp salad that had 4 smal shrimp it it.

Lunch for 2 was over $20 with NO DRINKS.
Yikes!
Kinda high for fast food, don't ya think?

This place is new - only about 6 months old - so it is still very clean and seemingly well-run.

I was excited to try this place - but also bummed when I found out that Ong's Noodle House (the former restaruant in this sapce) had closed.

But the gorgeous fresh coat of green paint and renovated bathrroms and dining area - along with a Half Chinese/Half Sushi Bar menu had me!  So last Friday me, my husband and our active 4 year old daughter dropped in for a quick dinner.

DD's gyoza were the best part of the meal - freshly cooked and perfect. (Even if frozen.)  DH had a greasy, heavy chicken lo mein, and a spicy tuna roll that he enjoyed. I tried a specialty roll - at $11.95 I expected better.  It was stuffed with Shrimp Tempura and Cucumber and coated with spicy tuna (not the best I've had but OK).    What killed it was they literally DUMPED a load of Tempura Flakes all over it.

Now don't get me wrong - I like tempura "crunch" but this was over kill.

I also ordered a green salad.  I should have known better and ordered the ultra-sweet orangey-ginger dressing (again - I've had better) on the side.  The iceberg lettuce and sigle slice of tomato were fresh and crisp.  Not gourmet - but good.

It's a solid 3 star joint.

I am torn between 3 and 4 stars.  The prices are high for what you get.  My husband and I came here on a weeknight - and the bar area was PACKED.  We found out later that there are 2 for 1 roll specials at the bar.  Sure wish we had known that before we sat in the dining area.

Oh well.

Our server was friendly and attentive - and had GORGEOUS hair. (Irrelevant - but fun to know).  We ordered drinks ($7.25 for a White Cape Codder - essentially vodka and white cranberry juice) and perused the menu.

I walked over to the sushi bar to stare at the fish.  Looked good - but the tuna looked not-so-fresh.

Meanwhile we ordered some rolls - the "Crystal Palace" topped with chunks of lobster - was a stand out.  The "Wilmington (aka Fattening) Roll" was deep fried salmon and mayo and onion.  Not for me!

The $10 order of 4 "lobster" shumai came in a rich, delicious cream sauce - but the dumplings themselves contained very little lobster (nearly all filler) and were not worth the money.

We did not have dessert.

I liked it here - and it has a sexy "bar-type" vibe.  Good for a date place.
Would i rush back here?  Nope.  Doma or Shiroi in Center City Philly are more my thing.  That said, this is probably the best sushi you can hope for in Wilmington.

Closing for good on April 30.  (Final open mic and party on April 27 & 28).
I will miss Thursday night Musical Quizzo with DJ Big Mike M.
I will miss Brett H., the best server I have ever known.

I will not miss the grotty digs that were sorely in need of a renovation nor the overpriced and average bar food.

Thanks for many years of service to the Media area.
You shall be missed.

Kennedy Fried Chicken serves all the typical fried foods and burgers as well as a few "halal-style" (Gyro over rice, Chicken over rice or salad) platters.

It is not $4- $6 - more like $7 - $9 - I got a gyro platter over rice with a drink for $8.99.
Nicer than NY Fried Chicken down the street - and better service but you pay a buck or two more.  The grilled shrimp is way, way over seasoned.

They also sell about 8 flavors of ice cream.

Super fast.

Decent rates, smallish but clean rooms.
In-house Starbucks and a small mediocre restaurant - and Chili's for room service (What-ehv).

VERY convenient location though - you can walk to everything and you are steps away from the Broad Street Line.

Added bonus:  watch the "Parade of Lawyer" and jurors march into court on weekday mornings.

Added risk:  MANY homeless panhandlers abound.

My husband ran in here today for an EMERGENCY pie to take to his brother who is stuck at HUP and craving Pizza.  He ordered a calzone and a Quattro (pick 4 toppings - one per 1/4 of the pie).

He said everything was fine.  Thin crust, decent toppings and since the pie was made fresh to order it was tasty and good. (Not stale).

Not bad for a chain.  My 3 year old daughter likes to watch the "pizza man" make pizza - so she, of course, loves it here.

It's better than Olive Garden - but not as good as Bensi's - in the "Scheme of mock-Italian chains".  It is also less noisy in atmosphere and decor than the obnoxious Buca di Beppo.

I'd go here if it was nearby - but would NOT go out of my way to eat here.
At least it's not too expensive.

This Wawa is always PACKED and people are coming & going.
Decent restrooms and a reliable place to get coffee, food etc.

No issues.

Solid.  A good choice for salads - and even noodle bowls.  You pick the ingredients and can control calories and fat.  Pleasant "green" sleek decor.

I tend to stick with the salads - but a few of the bowls and soups look (more carb-heavy) good.

How in the world do you rate a stop on the MFL?  Relative to others?  This one, as many are, is dirty and gross.  It is convenient to Penn and Drexel and other University City areas.

As David mentioned you can't buy tokens here - but I use a pass anyway.

Be careful at night - as is common sense in any major city.

I had a surprisingly delightful (yes, delightful) lunch at Champps - and my expectations were not high (I have dined at another Champps and am not a big fan).

Someone else paid (add a star right there).
Lunch special of pasta (any kind you wished) and a 1/2 size greek salad were very good.

HUGE portions of run-of-the-mill formula cooking - but if you choose wisely you can get a decent meal here.

Tip:  Come after the lunch rush (we were here around 1:30 PM) during the week when the place is much less crowded.

So surprised I liked it as much as I did.

I had no issues - and decent service when I popped in on a Sunday afternoon to get a dozen donuts (for 7 hungry kids) and an iced latte (for me).

In and out quickly.
This is a pretty "chi chi/shi shi" store for second hand womens fashion.You can actually find some great items here.  Not cheap, though - but way nicer than most consignment places.

Cheap, decent, low-budget sushi (and bubble tea) tale out.  2 complaints?  No Hamachi (yellowtail) and all the "crab" is fake crabstick.  A plus?  Tasty "summer rolls".

Prices are moderate and it's a good place for take-out or a working lunch.  Glad they are around.  Curiously enough they also supply sushi to Friends Select school a few days a week.

Not a holy grail - but a great, quick sushi alternative - and right near Jefferson and the Gallery.

My mom (who's in her 60's) gets her hair set here every 1-2 weeks.  She used to see a great lady named Venus - but I think Venus is long gone.  For a quick, cheap blow-out or wash & set it's a good choice.
Fair prices and decent sandwiches, Breakfast and lunch items.

This review is for the pre-made sushi (in a refrigerated case at lunch time) only.
The Salmon Avocado Roll (Alaskan) was excellent but the Phoenix roll (Tuna outside was fine, inside - not so fresh) was not as fresh as it should be.

In the mean time, so far, so good and I may return to try some cooked items.

$3.50 for the Alaskan Roll (It's $5 on the menu) and $6.75 for the Phoenix - which I will not order again.

What choice have we got?  We live at Broad 'n Vine - and Jakes is 1 block away.

My little daughter LOVES it here and gets 1 slice with black olives.  
She also loves to look at "the Mummer on the wall" - they have a pretty colorful mural of Philly-stuff all over the walls.

I have tried the pizza - which when fresh - is pretty decent.  The pastas are not worth the money - I can make this at home.  The Chicken Chees-steaks and Chicken Parm sandwiches are both good - and large.  My dad & I split a chicken parm last time we were there and It was plenty.

Note to moms:  They do not carry MILK - so bring your own.

3 stars is the absolute most I can grant to a pre-fab chain with average food and cattle-call service.

We were dragged here for my mother in law's birthday and it happened during "Lobster Fest".  For $30 I got the Lobster lover's plate with a very nicely done rock lobster tail, a tough, dry overcooked Main lobster tail and a small blob of baby shrimp and lobster micro-bits alfredo (I luckily was smart enough to get mine with no alfredo sauce).

Edible?  yes.
Good?  Some of it was good.

But I am still not a fan of this place.

3 or MAYBE 4 stars if you get good service.  (Ours was fair.)
We arrived at 1:15 on a Wednesday - 2 of us - for a late lunch.

Our cheerful (and obviously new) server seated us and brought water right away.  After a while we each ordered chopped slads but with different items omitted and added.  After a VERY very long wait (for salads!) they salads arrived but neither mine nor my companions had tomatoes (and we wanted them and they were supposed to have them).

So very quickly the salads were brought back with the tomatoes and were fresh and crispy and very good.

Then the bill came - my friends salad (which last at $8.50) was $8.50 but mine was $12.00.  Wow.  I sure wished I had known that omitting bacon and adding chicken would cost me $3.50.  Again - not the end of the world but considering I omitted one protein in exchange for another, I kinda hoped they cut me a vbreak or tack on 2-$2.50 max.  Even LaCroix Rittenhouse only charges $4.00 for a chicken breast.

OK - enough raggin'.  The salad was good - crisp romaine and delicious dressing.

I will return - but I'm not in any great hurry.  (We picked it for location near my friends school.)

Oh - and they serve Capogiro Gelato (nice) - but we didn;'t get any.  They also have some outdoor seating, and an espresso bar.

Every once in a while I splurge on a $5 Breakfast sandwich to go.  It's supposed to come with a free Illy coffee, but the lady usually lets me get iced tea.

Well today was not a good day at DuJour I guess - the place was much busier than usual (usually mornings are slow there) and the guy at the counter wanted to charge me for the iced tea (Their unsweetened iced teas are great - by the way) but I told him that I always get iced tea in lieu of coffee.

So I waited for my to-go sandwich and waited some more and the girl at the vcounter packed up my order and then let it sit under a heat lamp.
Never called my name or anything.  So I waited some more and then I noticed my name on the bag and said, "I'm Karen" and she reluctantly got me my sandwich.

Whatever.

I won't be back for a while - but that said the sandwich (made to my specs - egg, cheddar and tomato on an english muffin) was great.

I wish they'd be a bit more friendly/service oriented.

Wow - i am surprised at the negative reviews here.  We came here back when they first opened and were so new there wasn't even any signage.

Honestly, I can't really remember what we had but mine was good and I remember a terrific drizzle of very high quality balsamic vinegar was used on one of the dishes.
