My compnanion did not like her meal at all, but i loved mine.

Also it was very loud in there (semi open kitchen) and for a small space, it was cramped.

Not the best I've had - but not bad. Perhaps they've tweaked things since?

Dayum that's some expensive-ass popcorn.
But it comes in a scrillion flavors, sizes and packaging options.

This starbucks is located in a big "Gateway" shopping center and is my go to after I hit up Saladworks or the deli or the Taco joint at lunch time.

In the morning it's swamped but at lunch I can usually get my four-bucks (try almost $5 for a Grande Iced Macchiato) caffeine fix.

Le sigh...

This is the CIBO carry out in Terminal B - and even though it's airport food (overpriced and usually awful) my 8 year old got a kids penne & meatballs (one meatball actually) that was cooked to order and actually quite tasty - and $8 after tax.

The male cashier was funny and provided comic relief while we waited for the food and my $3.26 bottle of Fiji Water (Oy vey!)

Meanwhile - el kiddo munched down that penne and seemed to really enjoy it.

Ah yes, the D-town-D-Q.
Brings back memories - of Quickies and Arby's and the multitude of fast-foodie places that once occupied this spot .

Oh, and the short-lived catering place that had delicious mocha cake - but I digress.

There is now - and for years has been a Dairy Queen in D-town.  Decidedly less "white-trashy" than its longstanding Dublin counterpart, this fine, soft-serve selling establishment gets busy mostly in the summertime with lots of kids screeching for their cones.

The food at DQ as a chain has historically been really awful, although I have heard their hamburgers and sandsiches have been recently re-vamped.  I usually stick to blended shakes, blizzards and small kiddie cones for the little one.

DQ.

It helped make Britney Spears who she is today.

I pay hommage...

Between 2 & 3 stars.  I feel generous today and they HAVE renovated oveer the years so that is a plus.
Not a holy grail by any means, but they have friendly "lifer" waitresses along with new "young kids" who serve you and service is QUICK and good.

The food - however - is "classic" (read: heavy) and not that great.
Breakfast or burgers are a safe bet.

Now that Granite RAun Mall (on its last dying legs) is our  closest shopping place, we came here on a Tuesday night.  My 7 year old desparately needed a new pair of sneaks and some winter boots.

SCORE!!!!!  The boots were priced as marked, but the $44.99 sketchers rang up for $14.99.

SWEET.

No lines at all - the place is a ghost town.

Bonus:  Sears carries (limited) land's end products.  I loveeeeee Land's End.

It's a chain and it's 2 steps above the Olive Hell-Hole.
My little daughter loves the pasta here and portions (even the non-family style ones) are ginourmous.  You'll need a doggie bag for sure.

Cheap, decent red-sauced fare heavy on the garlic.

A good time, but by no means a holy grail.

Stopped in at 11:45 on a Monday and the place was empty.
Started to fill up a bit by the time I left,

Very tasty (and bug) BLT for $6.75.

Basic, good "bar food" and sandwiches and lots of beers on tap.

Not bad!

Food was 4 stars, service about a 2.
I was dining alone - and is often the case - they tried to put me at the bar (high top) and I asked nicely to please be seated at a lower table.

They gave me one (it was not yet busy - early part of lunch crowd, and I know what a pain it is to seat a single) and then basically ignored me.

That said, my $9.99 half BBQ chicken salad was delicious - I added $3 worth of avocado.
I love their herbal ranch dressing.

I will be back but next time with other diners.  Dining alone here is not fun.

Not nearly as bad as I had imagined.
We have lived in Media for almost 5 years now and I have passed by Q's many times and it just "never appealed" - but we needed a bite (and some booze) after 9 PM.

On a week night.

And it Media - they roll up the sidewalks at about 7:45 PM.

So we had quesadillas (fine), prime rib egg rolls (just Meh) and a few mid priced drinks ($6 - $7 mixed drinks)  It's a bar, not fancy.  Mediocre "bar" food.

Plus they have Quizzo on Wednesdays.  I just might be back!

Meh.  Meh-xican.
The good?  It is very inexpensive - I got a single enchilada for $3.50 and Guacamole for $5 and that was quiteenough for me.

Platters are $10 - $12 and cheaper at lunch.

Decent service - and it was nice & quiet when we went (late - like 8:30 on a Wednesday).

Not great - but not awful.

I wouldhave likes some pico de gallo with my chips (the salsa was just ok) but it was $3.00.

About 3 to 3.5 stars for friendly service, a clean restroom and decent dining area.
Out of our group of 5 - not one of us had pizza.

Kids enjoyed their jumbo hot dogs and fries, chicken tenders.
Ladies liked the basic, but crisp iceberg house salads. (I got mine without onions.)
A small chicken parm sandwich here is plenty big - and the veal with spinach was - just OK.

We'll be back - and we'll let you know how the pizza is.
Great for kids and families - lunch prices much cheaper than dinner - and big portions of (just OK) food.
They may be closing in 2015.

Service and food waxes and wanes depending on the day/server/cook on duty.  In general I usually find something to eat here - especially breakfast food - like pancakes and omelettes.

My parents like the chicken pot pie here - which is extremely rich, caloric and loaded with chunks of white-meat chicken.

Not my fave - but a solid option for a cheap, no-fuss meal.
And big pots of decent coffee.

2 star service, 3 or maybe 4 (for fast food) star food.
Maybe.

I can here at an off time ( 3PM on a Wednesday) and the place was empty.
One table of 2 eating in the front and 6 (yes SIX) uniformed staffers eating and chatting at a back booth.

Order counter?  Empty.

So I asked "Anybody working?" and one guy got up and walked to the kitchen door and shouted "You've got a customer".  I guess taking a break is priority over customer service.

Anyhow - they are young kids running the joint.

So I ordered a chicken sandwich and classic fries (showstring) for my 12 year old at her request.  Came to $9.80 after tex - no drinks.  Ouch.

She loved it though - even their own "private label" ketchup.

I would return - but I am not a fast food chick.
It's a glorified fast food joint.

The true test will be when I try a burger here.
The chicken seems fine.  Like any other chicken sandwich.

There are alot of Bonte's around.
This is for the one on 17th Street near Chestnut.

The waffles here smell better than they taste.  To me they were just OK.  The coffee, however was very good and not "burned-tasting" like Charbucks.

The DD inside 30th Street Station near the McDonalds is fine - the one up by SEPTA is a bit grosser.

All in all - they are the same-old-same-old  DD we all know.
I get my occaisional Iced decaf french vanilla with lowfat milk and a splenda here on my way to the train.

Nice Indian-American staff move as quickly as they can during the rush.  I give them alot of credit!

Damon, Rick's son is a terrific guy and the food we had at our 200+ person corporate BBQ was good - but honestly?  Not great.  The ribs were definitely good - falling off the bone but very charred tasting.  Pulled pork was a bit dry, but totally "saveable" with sauce.  Chicken was dry as the Sahara.  Not OK. Again, over-charred for my liking.

I really wanted to give higher marks, but due to the "burnth taste" (some people love this) I just could not.

I bet in the restaurant (our event was onsite - not at the restaurant) the quality is higher.

I had not been back to gomo in a long, long time - over a year - since my last experience was so "meh" - but on Friday I was pressed for time and in serious need of a polish change (no time for a full mani, even).

By some miracle - even though gomo's was "hoppin'" busy they squeezed me in for a quick polish change and I even got 10 minutes of (just OK  but so needed) chair massage while they dried.

Big con:  The "therapist" (and I use that term loosely) chatted in Korean the entire time she massaged me.  Chattered LOUDLY.  Not relaxing.

Big pro:  the older Russian lady who did my polish change clearly knows her stuff.  She's been at Gomo's since they opened 19 years ago.

I want to give this place higher marks, but I just can't.
Why?  Because the food it just not that great.

Here's why...

First of all this place is VERY kid friendly - so if you want a quiet spot, this is not for you.  We were seated near the front door (which blasted us with frigid air each time someone opened it) and next to us was a table of 15 middle schoolers.

Oh my.

So that aside, our lovely young server (Blake?  She told me her name twice and I still did not retain it.) was attentive, friendly and 5 star all the way.

By now the noise is nearing deafening.
We get our apps/snacks.  French Fries (an enormous order for $4) and $12.50 for the tuna tartare which was drowning in 3 types of sauces.  All sauce .  Could barely taste the fish.  It's a shame because in concept this could be a wonderful dish.

Next came a cup of beef chili with sour cream which was good but the beans were a little hard/tough.  Not too spicy (which for me was a good thing) but if you are a chili lover you may find it too mild.

Dessert was the best part and even it was not that great.  A home-made "Chipwich" - 2 chocolate chip cookies with chocolate (or vanilla) ice cream in between.  Enormous - and we took part of it home.

All that said, I will return to Christophers - but with Teresa's and Matador and Paramour all nearby - there are better dining experiences within a quick walk.

Christopher's is a great place to take your over-indulged, entitled children (Mine included - but even "the princess" would balk at the over sauced tuna tartare).

A safe place to take the kids and grandparents in one fell swoop.  Avoid peak times (like Saturday and Sunday breakfast, and you'll be fine.

The $4 "Five" breakfast - 1 eggm 2 pancakes and 2 pieces of bacon (or sausage) is a good value.  Kids meals are also decent here for kids 12 & under.

There is little atmosphere and as a result - prices are low.  You can get a very good massage here from Katherine.  (Dawn - my favorite - moved away.)  Linens are clean and tables are comfortable and adequate.

There is alot of turn over in the therapists, and I suspect they do not make much money.  

It is NOT a spa/luxe experience - for for a chair massage - or a quick 30 or 60 minute table massage its a solid quick fix.  Often you can just walk in - but I like to call and make an appointment.

When corporate cafeteria meets expense account meets cliché meets enormous beer list, you get a place like City Works.

I was treated to lunch here on my company's dime (Thank goodness because the food - while good - is not awe inspiring.)  It's actually about 4 stars for Food - the prices, service and NOISE are what makes this place less than ideal.

I am glad my coworkers are good conversationalists and smart however...  I could not hear them.

You can not hear yourself think in here.
I am not old.  I am not an old fart, but man, Lunch on a Friday was crowded (we somehow got a table right away so that was lucky) and NOISY.

I had a $15 salad that was worth about $11.
Copious amounts of "parsley" fries were served to everyone BUT me.  (Salads don't come with fries - and that is just fine.

Pineapple Cider sounds intriquing as does Space Dust IPA.

It's amazing what a little marketing can do.

Corporate America should keep this place afloat for years.

Poco's has been in the bottom of the Courthouse Motor Inn on Main Street in D-town for years.  And in all those years the food has never improved - yet people still go here and many, many people LOVE it.

Just not me.

I don't HATE it - it's just "Meh"xican.  Boring, nacho-esque Ameri-mex.  (Or worse, Pennsy-Mex?)  But I do love Doug Esch - and all the D. Esch boyz.  Lot's of nostalgia for me at Poco's.

Save me a barstool, pour me a margarita, rocks 'n salt - and I'll be downing nachos along with the rest of 'em.

It a basic, fairly clean, safe, cheap, Perkins,
Not my choice for a gourmet experience - but if you want coffee and pancakes - and if you have kids and are budget conscious it's a fine option.

This location (Doylestown) gets packed on Sunday mornings after about 9 AM.  So go early or very late, or else there will be a wait for a table.

Out party of 7 was seated right away at 8:35 AM on a late summer Sunday.

The kids breakfasts are huge and caloric - the chocolate chip covered Pancake Bear or the Sprinkle & whipped-topping laden "Rainbow panckaes" are a big hit with our little girl - but man are they BAD for her.

Service is a bit spotty and often there are no creamers, or no jam or something is missing that we need.  If we ask they will get it for us.  Weird.  

The breakfast rush is quite a scene for sure here at Perkins.

Oh- and there are sometimes COUPONS in the Daily Intelligencer - so be on the lookout for those.
It's OK.  Not too bad for diner food. We had brunch/late breakfast here and the french toast and pancakes were just fine.  Decent South-Philly.

Seems very chain-y.
Food was greasy and they do use American cheese.
Food was meh - and chips are indeed, thick and stale tasting.

Service was fine (Thus the 3 stars) as we came early (11:50 AM) before the lunch crowd got going.

It was edible and "meh".
If a coworker insists, I would return but I am in no hurry to rush back.

Don't hate me, but I prefer Starbucks, Dunkin or even Wawa to Saxby.  That said this is super convenient - right inside the doors to the Liberty Place shops.  I have gotten a latte here before and it was fine.  Not amazing, but what I "needed" at the time.

Same kinda (high) prices as a Starbucks.  Beans taste roastier, if that is even possible.

The best coffee is still La Colombe in my opinion.  (Or Blue Bottle if you can get it freshly made.)

I am not an Old Navy fan and generally regard them as "disposable clothing" that you can wear for a summer or three, but I was in dire need of shorts and Old Navy delivered.

Not a bad choice - and as ON's go this one is well organized with plenty of cashiers at the front counter.

Lady running the changing rooms was friendly and nice as well.

Got in, got shorts, got out.

Bam!

Nicely presented food - but the quantity was pretty skimpy - but that may be because of the reduced bugdet our building had for parties this year.

Anyhow, Miles catered our building's annual holiday cocktail (really beer, wine & soda) party and set out some antipasto (delicious olives, caponata, artichokes with long, tasty stems) cheeses, dried fruits and fresh grapes, a few dessert items. (Frozen creeam puffs and pre-made tartlet sheels filled with gloppy cream. A few cannoli.)  Uninspired. (But it beats chips 'n dip.)

As said before -presentation was lovely.  Service was great.

The also butlered a few platters of seared tuna with a wasabi "cream cheese" on a crispy-fried chip.  They were delish!  The cranberry chicken spring rolls were odd tasting.  The beef brisket sliders looked vile.  I passed.  Friends enjoyed the mini crabcakes and toasted "grilled cheese" one biters (with goaty-goat cheese.  Baaaaah!).

All in all, the servers were friendly and efficient, but the food was just OK - and there was not enough of it.  

But hey - it was "free" (we pay enough in rent throughout the year to justify a holiday bash!).

We came with an extremely large (over 25 people) group and had reserved the big green tent outdoors. Our server was a little "snippy" but very efficient and a good server.  She just seemed a bit pissed off for most of the time we were there. Note:  they will NOT split the check on weekends,

The food was very salty and heavy (especially what we ordered) but presented nicely.
Most of all though - it was over priced.  $15.50 for a pulled pork sandwich?  $17.50 for my 10 year old's fish & chips?  Ugh.  Oh - and sodas are $3.25 each NO refills.  OUCH!

But there are cute doggies there (a very dog friendly place) and it's great fun to sit outside.
We do not live near here, and unless we are going canoeing again and North brook or coming here with locals we likely won't be back any time soon.

We had no real problems with the service at Bistro 24 - and clearly breakfast is a better way to go than lunch/dinner fare.  I had a seafood Cobb salad that was just OK - the avocados was very under-ripe and I did not eat them.  My friend had blueberry pancakes and they looked great.

Young servers and trainees following them around.

Clean restrooms.

No issues.

People are raving about this - but my experience was just OK.
I spend nearly $5.50 for a large iced latte (more than Charbucks) and it was warm.  Not enough ice.

The line was long and moved very slowly.  This is not a place to come for "commuter coffee" - it is way more leisurely.  The ladies working up front were friendly and kind but moved oh-so slowly.

Maybe my inner Manhattanite is showing but for the speed, price and lackluster latte, I'm sticking to Wawa or Charbucks.

Mid-priced sneakers, shoes and sandals for men, women and kids.
Decent selection and decent prices - often buy one get one 1/2 off, etc.

Better quality than payless. Not as good as "real" shoe stores.

I can usually snag decent summer sandals here and my husband who favors a "casual" work shoe got 2 pairs here recently.

The Doylestown store is much cleaner and nicer than the one in South Philly.

We're pleased enough to be repeat shoppers, but true fashionistas may balk.

One of my close friends and i enjoy the food here - and the service is great - but today there were soooooo many flies.  In the rest rooms, near our table.

Eew.

Please do something about this!

Catering by Miles catered our holiday party again this year.
The service is fine and presentation is nice - but the food is just "run of the mill".

We had hot & cold butlered hors d'ouvres - a few were good - lobster pot-pies and pigs in a blanket, some (again) vile-looking pulled pork sliders.

2 table stations had a variety of nice cheese, vegetable crudite and dips, plus steam tables with hot bow-tie pasta in a marinara sauce with bits of vegetables and meatballs in it.  My 7 year old loved it.

Desserts were also butlered.  Frozen cream puffs, tiramisu bites and mini cannoli.
